story:
Hello everyone!

Thank-you for visiting my campaign page. I am looking to raise some funds to help towards the cost of having my first solo art exhibition in the autumn.
If you know me and my previous work you’ll be aware that I am usually more craft based, however, 2020 being the strange year that it was, it freed up some time to work on some new things.

 At the time  I was living on the edge of Thetford forest and got really interested in the Breckland landscape I was so close to. I did lots of walking, photographing and just generally letting myself go a bit wild. By the summer it was very clear a theme was emerging in the things I was creating and a natural body of work was building. ‘Anima’ is the result of that exploratory year.

'Anima' is a mixed media show encorporating wooden, ceramic and textile sculpture as well as photography, paintings and other experimental mediums such as chalk, bronze and bark. The works I have made are joyful and full of wonder, playful and fun. I am having the exhibition  in celebration of these things, as well as to raise awareness of the Breckland landscape and why it is so special. Although much has been lost to large fields and pine trees, so much of what remains is still accessible; I want to encourage people to have their own adventures and find the magic in the world around them.

My goal amount means that it will be a well put together and quality experience for everyone to visit and remember!

What the fund raising is for -

I am grateful to have received a small grant from the Oppenheim-John Downes Memorial Trust which has funded some printing costs, and to have found a willing sponsor for the bar(!). Everyone who visits the exhibition will be given a free small booklet and postcard with information about the exhibition and the Brecks to take away with them.

I would like to offer everyone who comes to the Preview evening a free drink and then there will be a donation bar with the money split between myself and DesignerMakers21 to help with fundraising towards the purchase of their building. Any funds raised over the initial amount will be split similarly.

I have estimated the cost for putting on the exhibition and Preview evening which may run a little under or over depending on final costs -

  • Advertising printing £120
  • Venue hire £125
  • Card and postcard printing £150
  • A5 exhibition leaflet and card to give away to each visitor £225
  • Preview evening refreshments £150
  • A 'walk round' style video of the exhibition, professionally filmed and edited as a visual portfolio/record £450
  • Framing prints and works £650

Supporter's Perks -

I have got a whole host of lovely perks for you to say thank you for supporting this idea of mine.

There are a range of original one-off pieces in wood and bronze, little studies and experiments handmade by me during this project, as well as some exclusive cards and prints. You can also have first dibbs on the large framed photo prints that are being exhibited as well; there will only ever be one of each at this size printed! (Although smaller sizes will be available to order).

If you need any more information or photos about the perks please do get in contact (IGG seems to only let me post one photo which is not very helpful!).

Everything Else You Need To Know -

An online 'snap shot' preview will be available to view from 3rd August at www.thewoodlandhaberdasher.co.uk/anima

Everyone is welcome to the Preview evening on 3rd September, 6.30pm-8.30pm at DesignerMakers21, St Nicholas Street, Diss. Come and see, touch and smell! First drink free and then a donation bar.

The exhibition will be open for a month from Thursday 9th September until Saturday 2nd October during normal shop hours. If you can’t make it there will be an awesome video available shortly after, which will let you have a  ‘walk round’ to see all the pieces close up.

I am so excited to share this work with everyone. To be able to work on such a large and immersive project was a transforming experience which will echo through future work and explorations. The organic nature of the project has expanded my horizons and helped me grow my confidence as an artist and not just as a craftsman (although spoon carving will always be my first love!).
 
If you'd like to find out more about me and my previous work please visit www.thewoodlandhaberdasher.co.uk or www.facebook.com/woodlandhaberdasher
 
Copy a full flyer from www.thewoodlandhaberdasher.co.uk/anima
 
Please spread and share the exhibition on social media or by suggesting places to put physical flyers and posters. I can post out A5 flyers if you would like some, just get in touch.
 
If you need any more info or have questions please do ask,
Thank you
Fay x

story:
427 gallery is in trouble - we have been left without money for next years rent! We were 4 minutes too late to submit an application to the Latvian State Culture Capital Foundation for support of non-governmental organizations in 2020. It must be pointed out that SCCF still doesn’t have an electronic application system - refusing to accept projects that often have very humane flaws (misspelled names or miscalculated numbers in a spreadsheet) is simply their choice that frequently takes out important cultural operators.

This means that we’re once again left without hope of continuing our program next year as it was an important chance to secure at least our day-to-day expenses. Since its foundation in 2014 427 gallery has become an important space in Riga providing adventurous exhibitions and events with artists both Latvian and international artists. See our previous activities on our website!

Save 427 gallery and help us continue our program in 2020!

 

~~~~~~~~~

 

427 pastāvēšana ir apdraudēta! Šoreiz tā muļķīga mūsu kļūda - 4 nokavētas minūtes pie KKF durvīm, kas īpaši rūgti šķiet tieši šodien. Tomēr negribētos, lai tik neveikli beigtos mums un, ceram, arī jums nozīmīgas galerijas pastāvēšana, jo bez finansiāla atbalsta mēs gluži vienkārši nevaram atļauties uzturēt 427 fizisko mājvietu Stabu ielā 70.
Kopš dibināšanas 2014. gadā 427 ir kļuvis par būtisku pieturpunktu mākslas mīļotājiem Rīgā. Mūsu programmai arī attālināti seko līdzi cilvēki no visas pasaules. Esam izstādījuši, mūsuprāt, interesantākos pašmāju māksliniekus, aicinājuši aizraujošus viesus, rīkojuši pasākumus, koncertus, ballītes, lekcijas. Šī gada pasākumi ir bijuši rekordapmeklēti - piedzīvojumu nav trūcis!
Tāpēc šajā mirklī aicinam jūs atbalstīt 427 galerijas pastāvēšanu arī 2020. gadā - kopš 427 pirmsākumiem Rīgas mākslas aina ir kļuvusi aizvien krāšņāka un aizraujošāka un gribētos domāt, ka 427 galerija ir atstājusi savu nospiedumu. Atbalstiet 427, kas bez jums vienkārši pazudīs! Katrs ziedojums mums ir īpašs, tieši tāpat kā katrs darbs, ko mums tuvie mākslinieki, draugi un domubiedri piedāvājuši atbalstam!

 

Anni Puolakka - Parasitia (with performers Marta Trektere and Ieva Tarejeva), 10/10 – 08/11/2019. Photo: Kristīne Madjare

 

427

 

427 gallery was found in April 2014 to bring new ideas, great artists and a new shift in the landscape of Latvian contemporary art. Over 40 exhibitions have been organizing since then as well as performances, concerts, parties, readings, a wedding, and other intermissions.

Over the time 427 gallery has been a restaurant, an enclosed squat, a strip bar cast in concrete, a beer brewery, a ritual site, an empty night club with the biggest disco ball in the Baltics, a graveyard, a dance floor from the Education Ministry of Lithuania, a fashion runway, a beauty salon, a dating game, a lip-sync contest, a traveling box a.o.

Viktor Timofeev & Alexander Iezzi - Aminals, 25/01 – 1/03/2019. Photo: Līga Spunde

 

2019 was a great year for 427 gallery with artist and curator Marta Trektere in charge of the program. We’ve seen a glimpse or two of Viktor Timofeev both in Riga with Alexander Iezzi or in New York operating No Moon. There have been also appearances of Botond Keresztesi, Emma Stern, Līga Spunde, Sandra Kosorotova, Tea Stražičić & Nick Zhu, Eoghan Ryan, Beth Collar, Bogna Wisniewska, GolfClayderman, Anna Slama & Marek Delong, Anni Puolakka and Maren Karlson.

After hearing of our problems many of the artists we have worked with responded with the most wonderful generosity and offered 427 their works as ambassadors of our program and activities. You can donate money and also get great artworks from the artists we love and cherish - Bora Akinciturk, Vitaly Bepalov, Indriķis Ģelzis, Philip Hinge, Ieva Kraule-Kūna, Inga Meldere, Daria Melnikova, Jaakko Pallasvuo, Emma Pryde, Anni Puolakka, Anna Slama and Marek Delong, Joe Speier, Līga Spunde, Tea Stražičić, Viktor Timofeev, Hanna Umin, Evita Vasiļjeva, Elīna Vītola and Amanda Ziemele, Nick Zhu!

In 2018 427 gallery launched a campaign to raise money for it's 2018 program. Back then we were lucky to raise 73% of 10 000 euro goal which allowed us to pay for rent and other day-to-day expenses. This time we're setting the bar at 10 000 again - it's an amount that we need to operate 427 gallery throughout the year! And we promise that 2020 will be the year when we deliver perks 10x as fast as before!

 

We have crafted a great next year with exciting artists exploring transcendental materials and following curly thoughts. Help 427 gallery to make the next year’s program happen!

Anni Puolakka - Parasitia, 2019. Photo: Ira Brut

story:
Hi friends!  My name is Shelsea Dodd and I am a figurative ceramic sculptor born and raised in Binghamton, NY.  I received my BFA in Ceramics from the Maryland Institute College of Art in Baltimore, MD, in 2013, and this past spring I completed a two year post baccalaureate program at the University of Alaska Anchorage in Anchorage, AK.  While in Alaska I was given the opportunity to move to Helena, Montana, and join Studio 740 as a long term resident artist.  This residency is a life changing opportunity for me, and I am asking for your support to help me take full advantage of it.

Studio 740 is a unique artists' studio and creative think tank in Helena, MT, founded by contemporary ceramic artists Beth Cavener and Alessandro Gallo in order to build a professional community for emerging and established artists.  In Studio 740's mission statement, Beth writes, "My mission is to collaborate with other artists to establish a full time professional studio practice, foster a lively exchange of ideas, feedback, and technical support, as well as introduce them to curators, collectors, and galleries."  Some other current and past residents of Studio 740 include Hannah Cameron, Perry Haas, Sara Catapano, Jamie Bates Slone, Brooks Oliver, Kelsey Duncan, Noah Riedel, and Giselle Hicks.

As an emerging artist just out of an academic setting, being a part of the artist in residence program at Studio 740 is an incredible opportunity for me and my career.  I will have the environment, facilities, time, and support to nurture my studio practice while working alongside some truly inspiring artists and humans.  In addition, I will be able to be immersed in and contribute to the extensive and wonderful ceramics community in Helena that has steadily developed around the Archie Bray Foundation for the Ceramic Arts.

As you can probably imagine, driving from Alaska to Montana towing all of our earthly belongings in a U-Haul trailer was an expensive endeavor that depleted much of our savings.  I am asking for help to fund my residency at  Studio 740 for one year so that I can dedicate as much time as possible to my studio practice and the professional development of my artistic career.

My $6,000 goal includes studio rent for one year, the estimated cost of clay and glaze materials, and the estimated cost of kiln firings.  By not having to worry about these basic studio expenses, I will be able to fully immerse myself in making and growing as an artist.  Any donations made that exceed my goal will go towards anything I have underestimated, such as glaze materials or firing costs, studio rent into my second year of residency, and other miscellaneous studio "wish list" items and equipment.  Every bit helps, and even if I do not reach my goal, all funds raised will still go towards funding my residency as much as possible.

By donating to this campaign not only will you be greatly helping me with this life changing step in my career, but you will also get to claim some exclusive perks I designed just for this campaign.  I'm super excited about them and I hope you all will enjoy them as much as I enjoy making them!  They will all be made here at Studio 740 and shipped out to you!

I'd like to take the opportunity to share a bit about my process and the perks available as part of this campaign.  I build my sculptures solid on pipe armature using a low fire earthenware clay body.  After being roughed in, they are cut up, hollowed, and reassembled.  My surfaces are completely ceramic, created using layers of terra sigillata, underglaze, oxides, and glaze through multiple firings.  My color palette is greatly inspired by art nouveau color schemes.  (The Venus and Bison below are both "Terra Cotta")

A few of my perks are designed to be customized past color, such as the Custom Animal Wall Head, and the full sized Custom Animal Wall Sculpture.  Please message me your requests and we will work out your one of a kind piece!  (Please keep my personal style and artistic liberty in mind when claiming one of these perks.)  If you have any questions or requests regarding color, animal, or a specific custom order idea please feel free to message me!

A note on delivery times and shipping: I apologize for the shipping costs, however, it is quite expensive to ship anything ceramic, especially sculpture, which tends to be larger and heavier.  My work has delicate pieces, such as ears and horns, and I have to pack them meticulously, usually double boxing them, to make sure they arrive safe and sound to you.  I assure you I did my best to get you the cheapest and safest shipping rates possible!

You may also have noticed that domestic shipping to the US is the only available shipping option.  Because of the variety in sizes and weights of my perks, accurately estimating international shipping to multiple countries became very complicated.  If you are an international backer, don't fret, please message me and I will be happy to work out a custom shipping rate for you!

As for delivery times, my goal is to get the perks out to everyone as soon as possible.  In most cases, that will be well before the estimated delivery dates.  The building and drying processes and multiple firings that go into making my sculptures can be time intensive, so please bear with me while you wait for your perk to arrive.  Again, please message me if you have any questions regarding this!

I'm often overcome with gratitude for whatever good fortune landed me in the ceramics community.  I'm so proud to be part of such an amazing group of artists and humans, scattered near and far, brought together by clay.  I'm incredibly excited to see where this new adventure will take me and my work, and it wouldn't be possible without your generosity.  I can't thank you all enough.  Anything you are able to contribute, whether it be a donation or by sharing my campaign on Instagram and Facebook, is greatly appreciated!  For anyone interested I have included my artist statement at the bottom of this page.  If you have any questions at all (shipping, custom orders, etc) please contact me.  Thank you guys so much!  You are the absolute best and I am so so grateful to you!  Cheers!

The following is the artist statement from my recent solo show, "Queendom Come."

The animals have always lent themselves to me: a character, a vehicle, a symbol.  Like so many before me, I have harnessed them for use as I see fit.  I am primarily interested in livestock and other domesticated animals, as they are the most accessible to us, yet exist in an abstract state to many people.  The ubiquitous carton of milk has become it's own entity, completely disassociated from the cow it came from.

Our treatment of livestock is too often mirrored in our treatment of our fellow human beings.  These animals are viewed as unfeeling and inanimate, and human minority groups deemed inferior are reduced to something subhuman, something beastly.  My experiences as a queer woman in today's political climate have sensitized me to these nuanced archetypes.

I want to create awareness for these issues inherent in our culture, while extending a message of optimism through appreciation and empowerment.  By creating narratives that depict strong female characters, either fictitious or historical, I am to celebrate feminist issues and represent women and queer people.

The world my work lives in is an idealized one: built upon historical references and personal symbolism.  I urge the viewer to investigate further and question what lies beneath this romantic veneer.  Through facilitation the confrontation of a degree of disquiet, my hope is to inspire introspection and a reassessment of one's reality.

will be happy to work out a custom shipping rate for you!As for delivery times, my goal is to get the perks out to everyone as soon as possible.  In most cases, that will be well before the estimated delivery dates.  The building and drying processes and multiple firings that go into making my sculptures can be time intensive, so please bear with me while you wait for your perk to arrive.  Again, please message me if you have any questions regarding this!I'm often overcome with gratitude for whatever good fortune landed me in the ceramics community.  I'm so proud to be part of such an amazing group of artists and humans, scattered near and far, brought together by clay.  I'm incredibly excited to see where this new adventure will take me and my work, and it wouldn't be possible without your generosity.  I can't thank you all enough.  Anything you are able to contribute, whether it be a donation or by sharing my campaign on Instagram and Facebook, is greatly appreciated!  For anyone interested I have included my artist statement at the bottom of this page.  If you have any questions at all (shipping, custom orders, etc) please contact me.  Thank you guys so much!  You are the absolute best and I am so so grateful to you!  Cheers!The following is the artist statement from my recent solo show, "Queendom Come."The animals have always lent themselves to me: a character, a vehicle, a symbol.  Like so many before me, I have harnessed them for use as I see fit.  I am primarily interested in livestock and other domesticated animals, as they are the most accessible to us, yet exist in an abstract state to many people.  The ubiquitous carton of milk has become it's own entity, completely disassociated from the cow it came from.Our treatment of livestock is too often mirrored in our treatment of our fellow human beings.  These animals are viewed as unfeeling and inanimate, and human minority groups deemed inferior are reduced to something subhuman, something beastly.  My experiences as a queer woman in today's political climate have sensitized me to these nuanced archetypes.I want to create awareness for these issues inherent in our culture, while extending a message of optimism through appreciation and empowerment.  By creating narratives that depict strong female characters, either fictitious or historical, I am to celebrate feminist issues and represent women and queer people.The world my work lives in is an idealized one: built upon historical references and personal symbolism.  I urge the viewer to investigate further and question what lies beneath this romantic veneer.  Through facilitation the confrontation of a degree of disquiet, my hope is to inspire introspection and a reassessment of one's reality.

story:
A tool is only as good as the artist that wields it, right? Well, some tools are just plain awesome! After trying out a Wacom Cintiq, I absolutely fell in love with it. It felt as natural as drawing with a pencil on paper, and I knew having one would be a great investment for my art makin'!

Why should you help me get one?

I currently work as a graphic designer, yet doing work for other people just to sell things is burning me out. I want to create for myself and for an audience that appreciates the creative projects I want to do. So, getting a Cintiq would be the first step in a new creative venture that will hopefully lead to better and more fulfilling work.

Just like going from drawing with a mouse to drawing with a tablet, display tablets are the next level up for a digital artist. Sure, having a display tablet isn't going to make me a better artist, but it will make me more efficient at art-making by allowing me to create in a more natural, organic way. Which means, hopefully, I will continue to grow even faster in my digital art skills.

    What's in it for you?

    If you enjoy being a patron to my art and seeing my work, then investing in a tool that will help me evolve as an artist will give you more awesome things to ogle! More sexy pin ups! More butts! More trolls! More belves!

    BUT...if you contribute at certain levels, you can get limited cool art perks like sketches, mini-comics, and more! I won't be doing any more commissions for a long while, so this is a great time to get some Talia-made art.

    Can't Donate?

    That's okay! Please help me out by signal boosting on Tumblr, or telling a friend about my art, which they can find on Tumblr or DeviantArt.

    Thanks!

    <3 Talia

story:
Tree of Love

The Tree of Love is an art installation, intended to be a sacred space, a place of gathering, of celebration, of rest. An oasis of calm and human contact in what can be a whirlwind of impressions and high-energy intensity of the Nowhere event. A sanctuary for contemplation. An ‘event space’ for spiritual workshops, weddings, celebrations, or commemorations. A sculpture that can be experienced for its aesthetic beauty, and at the same time is a “canvas of experience” for participants to use in a way they see fit, different from the standard communal structures or barrios.

Trees have had a special function in past and present human societies. They were and are places of worship. Of connectedness to nature. Of shade, that enables group gatherings. Of teaching. Of repose.

The Tree of Love celebrates this archetypical function of trees, by bringing a large tree sculpture, made out of natural “local” Spanish materials, that enables all above functions, and at the same time reflects in its design and execution on the necessity of high budgets, and of using “new” and environmentally less friendly materials.

 

 

What We Need

For construction of the Tree of Love, the following items are part of our budget:

  • Transportation/Logistics:  € 400
  • Construction hardware:  € 300
  • Rope and wire:  € 300
  • Tools and add-ons:  € 200
  • Lighting and cables:  € 300
  • Sarinena pre-build rentals:  € 250
  • Fundraising costs:  € 200
  • Perks:  € 200
  • Buffer:  € 250 

Total budget: € 2400

The Nowhere Art Team is in the process of granting the Tree of Love generous support. At this point, it is not fully clear yet for what amount they can assist us, but a grant request of at least 1200 has been made. We ask your generous help as well, in raising our total budget and getting the Tree of Love out to Nowhere in its ideal form. 

If we don't raise our budget, the tree will be scaled down in size and refinement. In the case we raise more than our crowdfunding effort, the surplus money will go to further enhance the tree, up to a point where we will gift the additional funds to the Nowhere organization, to help fund other artworks.

In any case, there will be a Tree of Love at Nowhere this year!

 

What You Get

We are very grateful for each and every donation, big or small. Your biggest perk will be the knowledge that you have helped to enable meaningful experiences at the Tree of Love.

Depending on your contribution, we have devised the following perks:

  • for a € 5 donation, you get a hug or high-five from as many team members of the Tree of Love as you can find at the moment of collection. All consensual, of course.
  • for a € 10 donation, you get a hug or high-five, and you will receive a special Tree of Love pendant.
  • for a € 25 donation, you get a hug or high-five, receive a pendant, and get a special Tree of Love t-shirt.
  • for a € 100 donation, you get a hug or high-five, receive a pendant, get a t-shirt, and become the owner of a special Tree of Love miniature sculpture.

 

 

A word about temples

The team that brings you the Tree of Love, has brought temples to the Nowhere event in the past. This year, we explicitly do not make a claim for this installation to be a "Burning Man style temple" for the Nowhere event. 

Why? Because past is prologue. We grow. We evolve. 

The Tree of Love is a "sacred space", but does not have pre-described rituals, it does not have the expectation that people come and mourn their deceased beloved, it does not aim for people to "let go".

The Tree of Love is a place for people to share their humanity. To share their souls. To share their love. A place of "worship" in the oldest form: a tree, our sacred ancestors in evolution, that shade us and comfort us on our desert adventures. Some rocks of the Monegros under it, that invite for play, or for ritual, but do not enforce it.

 

Risks & Challenges

The sculpture/structure will be built by a team that has successfully, without safety incidents, created large-scale sculptures and installations at (burn) events previously. Among those installations were the Temples of Dissolution, Ascension, and Reflection, at Nowhere. Also, recently members of the team built a sculpture with the same materials, of comparable dimensions, that was sturdy, safe, and was eventually burned without incidents.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Apart from helping us with a donation, we kindly invite all that want to help out with their time and effort in helping to create the Tree of Love, by reaching out to us. We will need help the coming weeks in preparing the materials. Afterwards, in (pre-)construction and teardown. And we will need help with properly lighting the structure, and with coordinating events and workshops at the Tree. We welcome anyone that feels they have something to contribute, to join us in our journey.

Apart from this physical help, we hope we can rely on your support as well, to help and spread the word via your own network and connections with other participants.

We hope to welcome you all at the Tree of Love at Nowhere this year. We already thank you for your generous support and help. 

<3

story:
OPUS is a both an art piece and a playable instrument. Inspired by the surrealist quality of the playa, it takes the form of an abstracted piano, a continuous surface of keys, with different sound stations to be activated and played by visitors. Keys are linked to LED tubes that extend out of the keyboard, into the air, and collectively outline a spatial canopy of music, immersing visitors and visualizing their orchestrations as light. 

A goal of this project is to make audio-visual composition accessible to everyone, no matter their musical background, and to invite visitors to produce an opus of their own creativity. This piece also celebrates collaboration, by encouraging impromptu ensembles to form, experiment, and compose on an instrument designed for many hands.  



OPUS is brought to you by the makers of Chronosydra and TRACE, both honoraria projects, at Burning Man in previous years.  Collectively, we are designers, engineers, coders, and builders that share a passion for artistic performance and wish to provide that opportunity to the community.  We are excited to offer this new interactive installation to the community of attendees at Burning Man 2019, and beyond!

We need your help to make this project a reality. 

Only with the community's support and contributions can we bring OPUS to life, and every dollar matters.  The $18k we raise during this campaign will cover the costs of electronics, building materials, and transportation from San Francisco to Black Rock City.

MORE ABOUT OPUS

Design and Interactivity 

OPUS is immersive, interactive, and it glows! 

Musical instruments can be intimidating.  A primary goal of OPUS is to lower the barrier to artistic creation and to allow everyone the opportunity to produce creative works.  In pursuit of this goal, we've designed a keyboard you're unlikely to find on another instrument.  The black keys that you might find on a traditional piano have been removed, and the keys have been programmed to ensure "wrong" notes are hard to find and to facilitate harmony between multiple players performing different roles in the ad-hoc ensemble.  Through these reconfigurations, we hope that everyone -- no matter how many music lessons you may have had in the past -- can produce joyful multi-sensory works of art.

To futher encourage collaborative exploration, rather than solo performance, this piece offers multiple operable stations with a wide variety of sound designs. There are ten positions along the continuous key surface where people can interact with the piece: this includes horizontal and vertical spans of keys, and keys that widen into hand and foot pads. Each station will offer the players a unique role in the ensemble, as synths, subs, atmospheric pads, and percussion.

Interacting with each station generate beams of light that chase along a corresponding collection of tubes.  Quick key presses will produce small beads of light while holding a key will fill the tube. As people interact with OPUS, they will generate complementary sound and light, and as more people join in, the layers of sound and the animation of lights will become increasingly complex.  One person might only be able to generate a spark of simulated fire; however, several players could set the piece fully ablaze.  The full range of the audio-visual programming can only be unlocked and discovered through the coordinated efforts of several players.  We will be incorporating a few interaction easter eggs for you to find :)

 

YOU MAKE THE DIFFERENCE

Your contribution will help thousands become audio-visual artists, learn a new instrument, and build shared experiences and connections with friends and strangers alike.  Your donations will help us secure:

  • Building materials (wood, fasteners, tools, lighting frame) = $3,600
  • LEDs, power supplies, controllers, and other electronics = $7,000
  • Keyboards and audio amplification equipment = $4,000
  • Rentals for power & transportation = $3,400

Help show off your support of arts and music with some OPUS swag! Check out the unique campaign perks available through your donations -- including custom soundbyte pendants and LED lanturns -- and see which resonates most with you.

You can also help by sharing OPUS and its campaign with others! If you'd like to connect with our team, please reach out via our OPUS Facebook page or on our OPUS Instagram profile.

See you at Burning Man 2019 -- Thank you for your support!

A very special thank you to Jenny Red [Jenny Red Studio] for filming and editing our campaign video. OPUS installation designed by Kathryn Greenberg, Ahren Alexander, Dave Sumberg & Christopher Crawford.

story:
The Straight Goods

If you know me, you're likely aware I've been making art for quite some time: drawings, cartoons, paintings, murals, posters, doodles across other people's important legal documents, etc. 

One thing I haven't done in decades though-- actual professional development. I graduated from Visual Arts at Western and immediately got distracted by theatre as a living, and art became the sideline. While learning-by-doing has been a swell form of education, at some point I could probably benefit a tad from a super-knowledgeable somebody giving me the what-for. 

So! When I learned well-known illustrator and MAD Magazine contributor Tom Richmond was running a three-day intensive workshop on caricature in his hometown of Eagan, MN this September 15th-17th, I knew I absolutely had to be part of it (see www.tomrichmond.com for why I like this guy).

Of course, the cost of the workshop had to be considered, as well as getting there, staying for four nights, possibly even eating once or twice. Sure, I could give my credit card a workout, but it gets tuckered out pretty easily these days.

Then it occurred to me: every so often, a friend suggests they'd like me to create something,  for themselves or as a gift. Some never get past the "I should get you to do this" mention, while others result in real live commissions. But what if I could consolidate these requests towards a specific direction?

Well, if you've ever considered nudging me to draw that-thing-you-want, here's a great reason to do it. Basically, I'm offering my skills in exchange for your financial support to help me improve them. You get the art, I get the chance to become a better artist. Win-win-win!

What I Need:


The workshop is $500 U.S. ($625 Can). Hotel is 4 nights x $80 U.S. /night + tax ( approx. $435 Can), and the return flight is $635 Can. Additional expenses (airport parking, ground transportation, meals) will be about $300 Can, plus art supplies are another $50 Can. In total, approximately $2000.00. 

What You Get: 

Well... what would you like? 

Being as this is all in service of becoming a better portrait artist, the perks shall be… portraits!

Depending on your contribution to the cause, they range from quick on-the-spot sketches to full-blown paintings. One person or two? Or more? Maybe you want an image of yourself with Katy Perry and Justin Trudeau, together at last? Maybe it's a gift for your Mom. Cartoon, realistic, or something in-between? Pencil, ink, or full-on colour? It can be done! The perks depend on the time, the materials used and the complexity of the request.

I've included several examples of work I've done in the past to fire your imagination, here, in the Image Gallery, as well as with the breakdown of the perks section to the right (...if you'll just take a moment to turn slightly to the right).

 

 

All art commissioned within this campaign will be guaranteed to be completed by the end of June 2018 (next Father’s Day isn’t that far away). However, I intend to complete everything  sooner if possible.  I will generally work on them in the order that supporters contribute, but I reserve the right to prioritize the artwork as best as I can, especially if someone has a deadline for a specific event, say, for a Christmas gift or birthday surprise. 

 

If there’s a project you have in mind that doesn’t appear to follow these guidelines of this campaign, that’s okay, contact me and we’ll see where it might fit in.

Caveat:  all artwork created within this campaign is intended for personal enjoyment only. If you’re looking for a caricature or portrait for business or promotional purposes, please contact me separately to discuss that. Thanks!

 

I love to draw. I like the challenge of capturing likenesses, whether realistically or in cartoon form. The more often I do it, the better I get. I enjoy making people happy when they see something they asked for, a unique piece created especially for them, or for a loved one. Your contribution towards my goal is two-fold. You're not only helping me with getting professional instruction, but also gaining more experience creating your piece. Make me work!

Lastly, if you like my stuff but aren’t necessarily contributing, please feel free to share this with friends! There’s apparently a few billion people out there who haven’t heard of me, at least so I’m told.

The perks depend on the time, the materials used and the complexity of the request.I've included several examples of work I've done in the past to fire your imagination, here, in the Image Gallery, as well as with the breakdown of the perks section to the right (...if you'll just take a moment to turn slightly to the right).  All art commissioned within this campaign will be guaranteed to be completed by the end of June 2018 (next Father’s Day isn’t that far away). However, I intend to complete everything  sooner if possible.  I will generally work on them in the order that supporters contribute, but I reserve the right to prioritize the artwork as best as I can, especially if someone has a deadline for a specific event, say, for a Christmas gift or birthday surprise.  If there’s a project you have in mind that doesn’t appear to follow these guidelines of this campaign, that’s okay, contact me and we’ll see where it might fit in.Caveat:  all artwork created within this campaign is intended for personal enjoyment only. If you’re looking for a caricature or portrait for business or promotional purposes, please contact me separately to discuss that. Thanks! I love to draw. I like the challenge of capturing likenesses, whether realistically or in cartoon form. The more often I do it, the better I get. I enjoy making people happy when they see something they asked for, a unique piece created especially for them, or for a loved one. Your contribution towards my goal is two-fold. You're not only helping me with getting professional instruction, but also gaining more experience creating your piece. Make me work!Lastly, if you like my stuff but aren’t necessarily contributing, please feel free to share this with friends! There’s apparently a few billion people out there who haven’t heard of me, at least so I’m told.

story:
My name is Naomi Takaki. I'm a multi-disciplinary artist from Japan currently living in Berlin. Recently, after years of trying to be accepted by various residencies and collections, I was selected to showcase my work at the London art fair in January.
It is beyond any of my expectations and I can't express how grateful I am to be a part of this wonderful opportunity. So I am asking anyone and everyone for a little bit of support as expenses are not covered and I am without sponsors or any funding. All funds will be used towards travel expenses,transport cost, and necessary art materials for the exhibition.

Artrooms in London 2019 
https://art-rooms.org/application/naomi-takaki/

About the project

Series on the Language of Stones
--------------------------------------------
One day, while hiking in the Alps I began to notice the stones at my feet. The contrast
between the shimmery black granite and the white limestone, their irregular shapes, the
simplicity of its' beauty and the complexity of their origin fascinated me.
Each stone a small part of the enormous mountain range spread out into the distance. I found these remnants of such natural grandeur awe-inspiring and I was filled with new reverence and inspiration.
They are the memories, the thoughts, tiny recollections of the mountains' history; the
plates violently colliding beneath, the reckoning of an ice age, the powerful gracefulness
of it's formation, fully alive. Yet it is just a stone...
But a stone that gives me a vision to express its' spirit, its' fragmented memories and the
impressions I received when I was hiking on that mountain.


What are the funds for?
The Funds will be for an exhibition at Art room in London including transport cost( 21 pics) travel expenses for one week stay in London as well as art materials for new acrylic paintings.

About the project owner
I was born and raised in Japan, where I completed studies in printmaking. During this
time, I developed a deep curiosity for contemporary art and culture in Europe. Five years
ago, this curiosity drew me from Japan to Berlin.
And so through this new experience and new culture, I grew a deep understanding of
myself, expanding my creativity and perspective: untouched and without influence from
my native culture.
My path is guided by this desire to enlighten these overlooked facets and qualities within
my own character and the work itself and to seek and express connections on a higher
level.
“I discovered that I was infatuated with the practice and exploration of reconstructing
new or different aesthetic forms of imperfection. I believe aesthetics are defined by the
response they give to one's imperfections."

Website ＆ Instagram
https://www.naomitakaki.com/ 

https://www.instagram.com/naomitakaki_/?hl=ja

story:
What the sweet bejesus is Artists’ Spread?

Good question! Have you ever seen an artwork and wondered about the person who made it? How much time and effort it took to create? Whether they even earn enough from their art to make ends meet?

Artists’ Spread is a pop-up restaurant with a difference. It is run entirely by practicing artists who hold down other jobs in the hospitality industry, and seeks to create a unique and unexpected dining experience. The artists will not only be running the restaurant but have created exclusive artworks for the event that will be incorporated into the dining service in surprising and fun ways. Artists' Spread seeks to not only open up questions around the sustainability of artistic careers and the financial vulnerability of artists, but to provide potential answers and solutions.

For some fantastic grub and a one-of-a-kind art experience both delicious and thought-provoking, the one-night-only opening on Sunday 12th August at Glasgow’s Project Café is not to be missed.

However, the project needs a little help to get things off the ground!

 

 

Whad’ya need?

There will be 50 tickets available for the one-night-only event with each guest attending being provided with:

  • A 3-course meal made by artists who are also experienced cooks
  • A drink made by artists who are also skilled bar workers
  • Service provided by the artists working Front of House
  • Artwork made by the artists involved in the project

Sounds pretty good, right? Well, the cost we need to charge for this in order for the project to be self-sustaining is a little high, coming in at £45 per ticket! While that’s still a pretty reasonable price, we’d really like to reduce this ticket cost. By backing this project you would be directly contributing to the social impact of this project by helping to subsidise the ticket cost to make the event more affordable for the wider community, and also contributing to paying the artists involved fairly and properly.

The fundamental premise of the project is that each artist involved is paid for their time working a shift in the hospitality role they perform in their ‘day job’, as well as allocated a fee and production costs for creating the artworks involved in the project. As many artists struggle to keep their practice going while juggling other employment and cuts continue to be made across the arts, this part is incredibly important. A recent survey conducted by the Scottish Artists’ Union[1] in 2017 for their membership base of artists revealed that 81% of respondents earn less than £10000 per year from their art practice.  In addition, 73% of their respondents have never received public funding.

Your funding is crucial in making this project a success. If we get the full £1000, we will sell tickets for £25 which is a much more affordable price. The more funding we receive the cheaper the tickets will be, and the higher the production budgets for all artists involved, meaning more ambitious artworks can be incorporated into the service! This is the first time a project like this has been put on in Glasgow and you have the opportunity to make it happen!

 

What’s in it for you?

Given the nature of this project, I would never expect any help for free. So I’ve racked my brains to come up with a list of perks to thank you for your contribution (however great or small):

£1 will get you a personalized thank you message by email from the Artists’ Spread team!

£5 will get your name acknowledged as a backer of the project printed on the menus being used for the one-night-only restaurant opening! Includes a personalised thank you from the Artists’ Spread team!

£10 will get you a limited edition printed copy of the menu for the one-night-only restaurant opening with your name acknowledged as a backer of the project! Also includes a personalised thank you from the Artists’ Spread team!

£30 will get you an artwork made by one of the artists involved in the project, along with a printed copy of the menu with your name acknowledged as a backer of the project! Also includes a personalised thank you from the Artists’ Spread team!

£50 will give you a free ticket to the one-night-only restaurant opening, an artwork made by one of the artists involved in the project along with a printed copy of the menu with your name acknowledged as a backer of the project! Also includes a personalised thank you from the Artists’ Spread team!

£90 gives you two free tickets to the one-night-only restaurant opening for you and a friend/partner to attend. Also includes two artworks made by the artists involved in the project along with two printed copies of the menu with you and your friend’s/partner’s names acknowledged as backers of the project! Also includes personalised thank yous to you and your friend/partner from the Artists’ Spread team!

 

Who’s involved?

Artists’ Spread is a project involving the artists Angeli Bhose, Stuart Noble, Emma Rogers, Robert Thomas James Mills, David Fagan, Eilidh McKay and Ameena Nur, curated by me, David McDiarmid.

 

And who the heck am I and why should you trust me?

In a conscious effort to highlight that the balancing of different types of work has become the norm for artists in contemporary society, I choose to list all of my jobs roles when identifying my profession as an Artist/Curator/Restaurant manager.

With a local focus, my curatorial practice investigates the sustainability and precarity of artists’ practice in Scotland. I seek to work with artists to produce projects that ultimately act as support structures for nurturing the development of emerging/early-career/financially vulnerable artists.

Creative Scotland's Visual Arts Sector Review in 2016[2] revealed that 42% of respondents (consisting of artists and art sector workers) worked in additional jobs outside of the visual arts to supplement their income. A third of these respondents work four days or more per week in their 'other' job.

As a response to this, I launched the Artists' Other Jobs Survey in January 2018. Building upon the initial information received from this survey, I have embarked on the organization of a series of events across Scotland as a means to continue discussions surrounding artists' low pay and needs for time and space, so that we may begin to collectively produce strategies and/or solutions to enable artists to spend more time on producing work and to sustain their practices more efficiently and effectively.

I am interested in suggesting different ways in which to interpret the term ‘artist-run’. With Artists’ Spread, I am testing the notion of an artist-run restaurant becoming a self-sustaining model for supporting the development of artistic practice.

Below is a brief bio/statement listing some of my past projects, but you can find more information about me and images from my past work and projects at: www.davidmcdiarmid.co.uk

David McDiarmid (b. 1990 Paisley, Scotland) lives and works in Glasgow as an Artist/Curator/Restaurant Manager, he graduated with a BA (Hons) in Painting at Gray’s School of Art (2013). As an artist, he has exhibited extensively throughout Scotland. Solo shows include: Megalomania (2014) at the Inverness Museum and Art Gallery and Projection (2015) at Interview Room 11, Edinburgh and group shows including RSA New Contemporaries, Royal Scottish Academy, Edinburgh (2014), Sluice Art Fair, London (2015) and Hidden Door Festival, Edinburgh (2017).

As a curator, he co-founded Visual Artist Unit, a Scottish-based artist collective that aims to support the professional development of emerging and early-career artists. In his current role as Co-Director of Visual Artist Unit he has organised a wide range of public engagement projects involving emerging/early-career artists including the Pillow Talk series (various venues across Scotland) featuring the likes of David Shrigley, Graham Fagen, and Rachel MacLean alongside recent art school graduates, the VAU Members Shows (nomadic group shows of emerging artists’ work held in various venues across Scotland from 2014-2017) and Toaty Wee (2015), an open call exhibition of small-scale works at Crownpoint Studios, Glasgow.

He has also balanced both of these practices by working his way up from a Busser to Assistant General Manager at Mexican restaurant, Topolabamba, Glasgow, since 2014. David is currently studying an MLitt in Curatorial Practice at Glasgow School of Art, due to graduate in 2018.

 

I love the idea but I have no money :(

Not a problem! This is a quick-fire 2-week campaign. I realise that some people might love the sound of this, but need to wait ‘til payday, or simply don’t have the money to hand!

There are loads of other ways you can help:

  • Spread the word about the Artists’ Spread Indiegogo Campaign – share the link on your Facebook, Instagram or Twitter accounts and email/message any friends/acquaintances you think might be interested!
  • Follow the Artists’ Spread Facebook and Instagram pages, and share with your friends/colleagues/acquaintances. This will be a great help in promoting the event for when tickets go on sale!
  • Put me in touch with any press/marketing contacts you might have who would be interested in promoting the event. The project email is artistsotherjobs@gmail.com

 

Notes

[1] Simpson L and Parson E (The Lines Between). Scottish Artists Union Membership Survey: 2017. Scottish Artists Union. 2017. Available from:

http://www.sau.org.uk/news/index.php?i=137

 

[2] Creative Scotland. Creative Scotland Visual Arts Sector Review. Creative Scotland, Edinburgh/Glasgow, Oct 2016.Available from: http://www.creativescotland.com/resources/our-publications/sector-reviews/visual-arts-sector-review

story:
Short Summary

  • Hello lovely people! My name is Rebecka Marie and I´m an artist trying to make it! And I believe I can because I believe in what I do! I´ve been painting since I was 3 years old! The love for life and colours have always been there! 
  • As you all know it´s not always easy to make it as an artist. You need to get up everytime you fall, try again when you fail. It hasn´t always been easy, but I´m very stubborn! And I decided to never give up the gift of painting that God gave me. And now to the big news: I´m invited to exhibit my art at Galerie Thuillier in Paris! The gallery is located in the heart of the Marais near the Place des Vosges and the Picasso Museum in the gallery district of the capital. The gallery gives professional artists and promising amateurs the opportunity to exhibit their artworks in the heart of Paris. 
  • I really want to do this! This is where YOU come in! The participation cost is 150 euro for each artwork and I´m planning to exhibit at least 2 artworks. And I really don´t have that money. There is also other costs like transportation and insurance of the art and other stuff. Please help me make this childhood dream come true! I WILL PERSONALLY THANK EVERY CONTRIBUTOR ON MY FACEBOOK PAGE!
  • This art exhibition will open doors for me and help me reach a wider audience! 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some of you just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please get the word out and make some noise about my campaign! That would be awesome!    ---- Thank You so much !!!! <3

story:
In support of the 2008 theme “The American Dream,” a group of artists and ne’er-do-wells created the Dust City Diner to share the kind of Playa experience we all love so much: that astonishing performance art one stumbles across just once during your Burning Man week but that stays with you forever -- and maybe even makes you see the world and your fellow travelers with a little more love.

 

The Dust City Diner is styled on a ‘40s American diner, complete with a quilted steel backsplash, red leather stools, neon-style sign, and chrome finishes.

 

 

You’ll come upon her when you least expect her out in deep Playa. However, she’s a tricky old thing, and she’s never in the same spot twice….. but you’ll find her if your heart is true! Just wander until you hear the soft sounds of the Ink Spots and the Andrew Sisters and the low murmur of conversation among other night travelers, and behold! There she is, in all her neon glory, a warm oasis in the cold night with an open seat and space at the counter just for you. We’ll serve you a piping hot grilled cheese with a crisp dill pickle, a bottomless cup of coffee -- and waaaayyy too much sass from the waitresses who have clearly been spending too much time in the sun or something.

 

Feeding You! (and Some Artists too...)

In 2010, we were granted permission by the Burning Man organization to arrive early and feed grilled cheese to those starving artists and minions building big art in the desert. Along with feeding every traveler who wanders across our path, this has also become a meaningful part of our performance art mission.

The Dust City Diner’s grilled cheese has even been featured in Saveur!

(feeding the Man crew...)

Helping the Old Lady

We used to raise funds through performances at events throughout the year, but as we’re all exponentially older than the Dust City Diner, we’re turning to this newfangled crowdsourcing thing so we don’t have to drag ourselves to parties at which we have to explain to truculent customers that no, we don’t do lattes with coconut milk, and yes, we did just put out our cheap cigarette in that grilled cheese you waited so long for. We know you’ll still eat it...

 

 

We’re grateful to again have the support of Burning Man.

But we still need to raise $15,000 of your hard earned and graciously donated bucks in order to:

  • Replace the brakes and axles on the trailer (safety first!)
  • Feed hundreds of artists and workers -- the folks who bring you amazing art on the Playa!
  • Transport the Dust City Diner from the Bay to the Playa (and pay for those speeding tickets….)
  • Buy at least 120 pounds of clarified butter (yum!)
  • Buy at least 200 pounds of good ol’ America-first cheese
  • High performance hairnets that cover our beehives. Because you do not want hair of unknown origin with your grilled cheese...
  • Health department bribe. It costs more than you think it would in Nevada, baby

 

You can also help by sharing information about the Dust City Diner and our campaign!  And keep up with the lovely ladies on our Dust City Diner Facebook page or spankin’ new Dust City Diner Instagram account.

The Dust City Diner runs on a lot of love, a little grit, and the support of our community. Thank you!

We’ll serve you a piping hot grilled cheese with a crisp dill pickle, a bottomless cup of coffee -- and waaaayyy too much sass from the waitresses who have clearly been spending too much time in the sun or something. Feeding You! (and Some Artists too...)In 2010, we were granted permission by the Burning Man organization to arrive early and feed grilled cheese to those starving artists and minions building big art in the desert. Along with feeding every traveler who wanders across our path, this has also become a meaningful part of our performance art mission.The Dust City Diner’s grilled cheese has even been featured in Saveur!(feeding the Man crew...)Helping the Old LadyWe used to raise funds through performances at events throughout the year, but as we’re all exponentially older than the Dust City Diner, we’re turning to this newfangled crowdsourcing thing so we don’t have to drag ourselves to parties at which we have to explain to truculent customers that no, we don’t do lattes with coconut milk, and yes, we did just put out our cheap cigarette in that grilled cheese you waited so long for. We know you’ll still eat it...  We’re grateful to again have the support of Burning Man.But we still need to raise $15,000 of your hard earned and graciously donated bucks in order to:
Replace the brakes and axles on the trailer (safety first!)
Feed hundreds of artists and workers -- the folks who bring you amazing art on the Playa!
Transport the Dust City Diner from the Bay to the Playa (and pay for those speeding tickets….)
Buy at least 120 pounds of clarified butter (yum!)
Buy at least 200 pounds of good ol’ America-first cheese
High performance hairnets that cover our beehives. Because you do not want hair of unknown origin with your grilled cheese...
Health department bribe. It costs more than you think it would in Nevada, baby
 You can also help by sharing information about the Dust City Diner and our campaign!  And keep up with the lovely ladies on our Dust City Diner Facebook page or spankin’ new Dust City Diner Instagram account.The Dust City Diner runs on a lot of love, a little grit, and the support of our community. Thank you!

story:
Nach 13 Lichtprojektionen und dauerhaftem Druck auf die Meden verließ der oberste CIA Mann Deutschland. NSA in da House oder United Stasi of America, weltweite Berichterstattung, von ZDF 37° über die Titelstory beim Spiegel (Der Pakt) wurde auf unsere Kampagne bezug genommen.

Um gegen das ausspähen unserer Daten zu demonstrieren, hat Licht- und Aktionskünstler Oliver Bienkowski mit PixelHELPER bereits mehrfach mit provokativen Lichtkunstaktionen auf diesen Missstand aufmerksam gemacht. Zahlreiche Medien berichteten darüber. Hier eine Übersicht unserer Videos. Presseberichte zu diesem Thema finden Sie auf Google News. Wir pflegen diese in den kommenden Tagen hier ein.

 

Um gegen das ausspähen unserer Daten zu demonstrieren, hat Licht- und Aktionskünstler Oliver Bienkowski bereits mehrfach mit provokativen Lichtkunstaktionen auf diesen Missstand aufmerksam gemacht. Zahlreiche Medien berichteten darüber. 

Um auch in Zukunft dafür zu kämpfen und Licht- und Kunstaktionen durchzuführen, starten wir dieses Crowdfunding. 

Wir bitten um eure Unterstützung, damit wir Ungerechtigkeiten nicht länger hinnehmen müssen, sondern gemeinsam dagegen vorgehen und protestieren können! 

Durch das kaufen der einzelnen Perks, könnt ihr nicht nur uns helfen, unsere Aktionen zu realisieren, ihr seid dadurch auch selbst Teil der Aktionen.

Jede unserer Aktionen wird auf Video fest gehalten, für deine Unterstützung wirst du namentlich im Abspann unserer Videos genannt.

Hilf' uns jetzt dabei, etwas zu bewegen und gegen die Ungerechtigkeiten in dieser Welt vorzugehen! 



+++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++

Spendenkonto:IBAN: DE70 8105 3272 0641 0339 40

Bank: Sparkasse Magdeburg

Inhaber: PixelHELPER International SARL

story:
In August I started my 6 months as graduate artist in residence at AirSpace Gallery in Stoke-on-Trent. Time has flown by and I am already working towards the solo show which will mark the end of the residency. The show will be on from the 29th January  - 6th of February 2016 at AirSpace Gallery in Hanley, Stoke-on-Trent. AirSpace is a collaborative, artist led project that brings critical, high quality contemporary art to the region and provides opportunities for a broad range of artists.

Over the last 3 months I have been developed many of the concerns central to my practice, as well as learnt about the rich industrial heritage of Stoke-on-Trent. I have recently begun working with ceramics, trying my hand at working with slabs and slip casting. For my final exhibition at the gallery I am looking at taking all that I have learnt and create a ceramic installation through creating my own moulds and taking slip casts from them.

Further information on how my work and research is progressing can be found at www.emilieatkinson.net and on my residency blog https://www.a-n.co.uk/blogs/airspace-graduate-residency !

I am applying for funding from various sources to make all this happen! If you would like to support this project in return for a piece of my work - please donate!

Loads of Love

Emilie xxx

story:
Hello, I'm Kazuhiko Hachiya. I'm working as an associate professor at Tokyo University of the Arts and also releasing various works as a media artist. For the last 16 years, I have been working on the OpenSky Project, creating and flying a small single-seater jet-powered airplane called M-02J. The motif of it is "Mehve" that many people want to ride like Nausicaa in Japanese comic/animated film "Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind."

 

Our Airplane, M-02J

The OpenSky Project requires to create an airplane what people could actually ride and fly, so from the beginning, I asked a professional to work with. Our airplane has been designing and manufacturing by professional plane production company Aircraft OLYMPOS, year by year, step by step, and the first flight in 2013, then in 2016 a flight in a circuit traffic pattern has been achieved. At first, it was thought that "it's impossible," but we improved the airplane's impeccable creation by step-by-step process and repeated the test flight while helping many people, and reached this by 2017. 

From 2013 to 2018, we conducted some test flights in Japan, and now, we are enthusiastic that we will achieve our much-awaited and the last mission of this project "exhibit and fly our airplane M-02J in the US sky." At this year's opportunity, we are going to:

1) participate in the home of aviation EAA AirVenture OSHKOSH in the US, 
2) set after-talk session in LA, 
3) exhibit at Chino Airport, and 
4) run a test flight at Corona Airport.

In addition to these, so that we could carry out the plans in California, we need an extra budget for airplane transportation, and the venue will be searched and decided from now on.

"Show M-02J the people in the US" is this project's ultimate goal. I want to make this happen, make it real. Please help our grand project!

 

What is EAA AirVenture OSHKOSH?

First of all, please take a look at this video. 


Isn't it amazing? 

I went to the Oshkosh Air Show for the first time as a preliminary inspection in 2017. So, wow, I was overwhelmed by the scale (the venue is enormous, events every day for a week, etc.), types and quantities of aircraft, and the passion and spirit of the people participating in this event. Unlike the ordinary air shows (trade shows style of ones) , the Oshkosh Air Show is based on "civil aviation aircraft." It is the world's largest air show that is still profoundly ingrained the early era of civil aviation aircraft culture which is "make your own and fly," and it is the sacred place where aircraft lovers all over the United States gather!

And, The Oshkosh Air Show will have 600,000 visitors and 10,000 aircraft during the seven days. This air show is not only for plane enthusiasts but also for a wide range of people from aviation workers to researchers, enthusiasts, ordinary people, and families. So, I think to show M-02J in the Oshkosh Air Show is an enormous opportunity to show "the actual flying plane created by the artist.”


The Artist Creates An Airplane

The animation movie "Nausicaa of the Valley of the Wind" was released in Japan in 1984; 35 years ago for now.

 

At that time, I was a high school student, and of course, I went to the theater! I remember I was very moved and brought back the impression home. Well, I did not think that I could make a plane similar to the Mehve 30 years after that …

The anime movie director Hayao Miyazaki has been drafted the Mehve as a "non-flying airplane." Since that, a decade later, I became an artist using technology and started to create works using micro-jet engines. At the beginning of 2000, I thought about if the power output of the jet engine continues to be improved, it would be possible to fly a small, single-seater airplane by about 2010. "Could I really make Mehve seen in a movie when I was a high school student?" After being obsessed with the delusion, I began to make an airplane as an artwork “to make the impossible possible.”

I made some models in 2003, made a glider with professionals to make sure that an ordinary human can drive, trained on an ultralight plane, and made a successful maiden flight in 2013. In 2016, I made traffic flight at an altitude of 300 feet.

It took a long time and a lot of money than I expected for the beginning, but "the closest to Mehve among the airplanes that exist in the world" could be realized. I made it so much that I want to show everyone in the US that our aircraft is flying!

 

OpenSky US Tour Schedule

 Here is the current planning schedule:

July 22 to 28: Exhibit actual airplane and explain the project at "Homebuilder's Hangar" in EAA AirVenture OSHKOSH. We are currently working toward to hold whether the demo flight is possible.


Late July to early August: Test flight at Waupaca Municipal Airport in Wisconsin. (It will be a closed test. We will let only backers know the dates and times.)

After EAA AirVenture OSHKOSH, I would like to ship the airplane to California by land, then I would like to hold lectures, fan meetings, the exhibition of the airplane, and demo flights. 



August 9 and 10: Presentation of the project and EAA AirVenture OSHKOSH 2019 in Los Angeles.


 

AUGUST 9  Event Open 20:30 Anime Jungle LA  
319 East 2nd Street #103, LA, CA, 90012
20:30〜22:00 (Admission 10USD)
Flying to US skies, Möwe from Nausicaä arrives Special Talk Show
Special Guest: Ayako Fujitani

event page 
The backer of "Event Invitation Pack"  or above will be invited free of charge.

AUGUST 10 Program Starts 14:00 The Japan Foundation LA
5700 Wilshire Boulevard, Suite 100, LA, CA 90036
14:00~ (Admission Free)
Make It Real: Flying Out of Miyazaki Animation
--OpenSky US Tour 2019 Summer--
event page
The backer of "Fan Meeting Pack" will be Invited to the fan meeting in LA (after Seminar at Japan Faundation LA)! 

August 15 to 18: Display of the airplane and introduction lecture of the project on the hangar of Chino Airport. (Because it is the private area in the airport, its admission may be by backers or invitation only.) 


the exhibition in Aoyama Tokyo 2018.

 


Hope we could have this kind of big hangar party...!
These depend on how much support can be raised.

Late August: Limited presentation of several flyings at Corona Municipal Airport. (It will be informed the schedule and time with priority to only backers preferentially. It is still undecided whether public release will.)

 

Collaborators and supporters

EAA: Experimental Aircraft Association // Providing exhibit locations at EAA AirVenture OSHKOSH, advice on flights in the US.

 
Walter Bauer, Lee Fischer (individuals) // Advice on flight locations in Wisconsin and assistance with exhibits at the EAA. 

 

KAA Corporation // Advice about the venue at CHINO.
Sky Creation, Inc.(Flight School) // Advice on flight locations near LA.


Kazuaki Yanagida, GM of KAA Corporation, 

Hajime Nakamura, the CEO of SkyCreation.

Mujin-to Production Co.,Ltd., PetWorks Co., Lid. // Project management, etc.


Use of The Rewards

This OpenSky Project is basically operated "without sponsor". Because "a newly designed airplane" is very risky, if we rely on sponsor money, we can be interrupted the project by the pressure to succeed by the deadline and it can lead to an accident.

Your support will go to:

  • Expenses related to this US tour (airplane transportation, travel expenses, accommodation fee, etc.)
  • Display and flight-related expenses
  • Return preparation and shipping cost

 

About The Perks
 

$15 "PDF Brochure Pack":

  • Send sincere thanks and PDF Brochure of the OpenSky Project "OpenSky 2013-2018".
     

$50  "Movie Credit Pack" 

  • List your name on the credit of the project document movie.
  • Download the movie, longer version. (of course your name on the credit!)

And,

  • Send sincere thanks and PDF Brochure of the OpenSky Project "OpenSky 2013-2018".
     


$70 "Event Invitation Pack" 

  • Invite you to the lecture presentation in LA (probably August 8 to 10)  and the exhibition in Chino Airport (probably August 15 to 18)!
    * Transportation expenses to the venue will not be included.
    * Includes a companion with you. For more companions, a consultation is necessary.
  • Keep inform you frequently update to tell how the OpenSky US Tour goes in the US. 
    And,
  • Send sincere thanks and PDF Brochure of the OpenSky Project "OpenSky 2013-2018".
  • List your name on the credit of the project document movie.
  • Download the movie, longer version. (of course your name on the credit!)
     


$120 "Fan Meeting Pack" 

  • Invite you to the project briefing session and fan meeting in LA (August 10)! 
  • Present a Kazuhiko signed PRINTED Brochure "OpenSky 2013-2018" to the backer who came to the fan meeting. (For applicants: Write your name.)

And,

  • Invite you to the lecture presentation in LA (probably August 8 to 10)  and the exhibition in Chino Airport (probably August 15 to 18) !
    * Transportation expenses to the venue will not be included.
  • Keep inform you frequently update to tell how the OpenSky US Tour goes in the US. 
  • Send sincere thanks and PDF Brochure of the OpenSky Project "OpenSky 2013-2018".
  • List your name on the credit of the project document movie.
  • Download the movie, longer version. (of course your name on the credit!)
    * Includes a companion with you. For more companions, a consultation is necessary.
     


$250  "Hangar Tour Pack" 

  • Special hangar tour guided by Kazuhiko Hachiya! Join me and our staffs and crews' deep and fun gathering at the hangar in Chino. Currently scheduled day: August 17 (Sat).
    * Transportations are not included.
    * Meal fee will be included.

And,

  • Invite you to the project briefing session and fan meeting in LA (probably on August 8 to 10)! 
  • Present a Kazuhiko signed PRINTED Brochure "OpenSky 2013-2018" to the backer who came to the fan meeting . (For applicants: Write your name.)
  • Invite you to the lecture presentation in LA (probably August 8~10)  and the exhibition in Chino Airport (probably August 15 to 18)!
    * Transportation expenses to the venue will not be included.
  • Keep inform you frequently update to tell how the OpenSky US Tour goes in the US. 
  • Send sincere thanks and PDF Brochure of the OpenSky Project "OpenSky 2013-2018".
  • List your name on the credit of the project document movie.
  • Download the movie, longer version. (of course your name on the credit!)
    * Includes a companion with you. For more companions, a consultation is necessary.
     


$800  "Art Work Pack" 

From the 5 photos taken at the US tour, you can select one of your favorite photos and we frame it for you for delivery. The photo is 10 X 12 inch, Digital C Print. Each photo limited released only  10edition. The frame is: W337 × H387 × D14 mm. It will be printed and shipped from Japan after the US tour finished.
* Shipping expense will not be included.

 

OpenSky US Tour Approximate Budget

I have developed an action plan to put the US tour into practice last year. And at the beginning of the year, I calculated the approximate budget. The estimated total cost of the project is approximately 9 million yen (about $82K).

The significant portion of the cost is a transportation fee of the aircraft (round trip to Japan and domestic transportation in the US), travel expenses, and accommodation expenses.

The funds collected by Indiegogo are to be used for transportation of the airplane to California, travel and accommodation of the staff in California, costs for lectures and exhibitions in LA and Chino, flight test-related expenses, video and photo production costs, etc. I would like to share this project with many people in Japan and the US and make it a rewarding one for each of you...!

<OpenSky US Tour Event Related Budget in California (USD)>

  • Transportation Fee: from Wisconsin to California $10,350
  • Transportation Fee: from Chino Airport to Corona Airport $1,200
  • Air Travel Expenses of The Staff x2: from ATW to LAX $520
  • Accommodation of The Staff (25 days of 8/6 to 8/31) $4,500
  • Lecture-Related Expenses in LA (inc. preparation) $800
  • Exhibition-Related Expenses in Chino (inc. preparation) $1,000
  • Fuel and Insurance Fee of The Airplane  $900
  • Renting Hangars $2,960
  • Video Production Fee $1,500
  • Photo Shooting Fee $1,000
  • Kickstarter's Reward Handling Cost $1,000

Total 25,730 USD


Crowdfunding and Its Management Members

Kazuhiko Hachiya, a person in charge of the project, will be responsible for the contents and the whole the crowdfunding, but Kickstarter's updating and communication with YOU will be mainly conducted by Gamme Takiguchi, the collaborator of the project. 
 


It's me in 2006! At that time, the airplane didn't have an engine, so we had to pull it with strong rubber rope to make it float in the air. Still, I remember the excitement when the airplane I pulled was flying in the sky, with Mt. Fuji in the clear sky. Again, fly M-02J, this time in the US sky!!!  (Gamme Takiguchi )
 

 

Risks & Challenges


Currently, our airplane is in transit by ship. We are considering that there is a risk of delays in customs clearance in the US customs inspection, etc., but it is assumed that the possibility of not being in time for the exhibition is low because there is enough transportation schedule to offset the risk. Also, there is a possibility that an accident or damage may occur during container (M-02J is in it) transportation, but we think that it is unlikely to happen.

About flight testing, our airplane belongs to the Ultralight category in the US Aviation Act, that means in principle it can be flown in the US sky as a "Federal Aviation Regulation Part 103-Ultralight Vehicles" without FAA (Federal Aviation Administration) permission. To make it sure, we are asking the FAA about it while getting the cooperation of EAA.

In any case, flight tests should only be performed in a safe environment and suitable weather, with utmost care to avoid accidents.
 

At last...

Thank you for reading through to the end. I would like to get your help, make the US tour a success, and let more people see M-02J...!!!

 


Reference: OpenSky web article (in English)

  • M-02J Spec. http://www.petworks.co.jp/opensky/
  • Popular Science http://pops.ci/SJDX31
  • Mainichi News http://mainichi.jp/english/articles/20160805/p2...
  • popular mechanics http://www.popularmechanics.com/flight/a22207/t...
  • YouTube 15 COOL VEHICLES AND PERSONAL TRANSPORT MACHINES https://youtu.be/NpQpm85CXIU
