Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute, but would still like to help, please feel free to circulate this campaign among anyone who would be interesed.

story:
Click HERE for more episodes of the OUTsider "Telethon"

Thanks for visiting our OUTsider Indiegogo page!

Coming February 18-22, 2015, OUTsider is a multi-arts queer festival and conference based in Austin, TX that celebrates the bold originality and creative nonconformity of the LGBTQI and Ally communities through the presentation of provocative, overlooked and out-of-the-box film, theater, dance, music, writing, performance art, visual art and scholarship. Through its annual festival and conference, OUTsider will join together queer artists, audiences and scholars from around the globe to exchange ideas, ignite conversations, transcend boundaries and experience new pleasures through artistic discovery.


OUTsider breaks the traditional one-medium festival model through a mixed-up multi-arts experience that bridges disciplines in order to activate the full power and brilliance of LGBTQIA creation and community.

OUTsider rejects the common separation of artistic practice and appreciation through an intertwined festival and conference that encourages meaningful, galvanizing interactions between artists, scholars and the general public.

OUTsider believes in the power of new forms of art and community, and stands in solidarity with all outsiders everywhere.

Support our bold mission by donating today!

With love and gratitude,

The OUTsider Team


Our Track Record

OUTsider is a new festival, but we already have a number of successful events under our glitter belts and combat boots, including MayDayGayDay, a mixed-up night of springtime frolics that featured artists turned upside down and inside OUT, performing in totally new mediums for the very first time (filmmakers danced, punk rockers painted, installation artists sang, and so on down the joyously jumbled line).

This event was well-attended and highly-praised by folks of all stripes and predilections, and gave audiences a palpable sense of our cross-disciplinary ambitions, as well as a little taste of the artistic mischief that we have in store.



Our Team

OUTsider boasts a rock star team who bring a wealth of festival expertise and creative accomplishment to the OUTsider buffet.

Our Board of Directors includes:

Curran Nault (PhD, Former Artistic Director of the Austin Gay and Lesbian International Film Festival and the Austin Asian American Film Festival)

Scott Dinger (Founder of the Austin Gay and Lesbian International Film Festival)

Bobette Mathis (Festival Specialist)

Beth Schindler (Queerbomb Founder)

Annie Bush (Filmmaker, Former Educator)

Mirna Hariz (Entertainment Lawyer)

PJ Raval (Award-Winning Filmmaker, University of Texas Professor)

Paul Soileau (Award-Winning Performance Artist)

Our Advisory Board includes:

Eugene Alvarez (Company Manager, Ballet Austin)

Ron Berry (Founder/Artistic Director, Fusebox)

Nao Bustamante (Performance Artist & Professor, Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute)

Del Ray Cross (Poet & Editor, Shampoo Poetry)

Ann Cvetkovich (Professor of Women’s & Gender Studies/English, University of Texas at Austin)

Madge Darlington (Founder & Artistic Director, Rude Mechs Theater Collective)

Will Davis (Theater Director & Writer)

Heyd Fontenot (Visual Artist & Director, Central Trak)

Ernesto Foronda (Filmmaker & Programmer, Sundance Film Festival)

Silas Howard (Musician & Filmmaker)

Daniel Alexander Jones (Interdisciplinary Theatre Artist & Professor, Fordham University)

Jonesy (Multi-media Artist)

Peter Knegt (Senior Editor, Indiewire)

Marne Lucas (Visual Artist)

Sandra Martinez (Entrepreneur & Community Organizer)

Travis Matthews (Filmmaker)

Chale Nafus (Founder/Director of Programming, Austin Film Society)

Gary Newsom (Physician & Philanthropist)

Hoang Tan Nguyen (Experimental Artist  & Professor, Bryn Mawr)

Masashi Niwano (Festival Director, CAAMFest)

Gretchen Phillips (Musician)

Andee Scott (Choreographer, Dancer & Professor, University of South Florida)


What We Need & What You Get

$35,000 is the minimum we need to bring OUTsider  to  exquisite fruition.

This money will be used to:

o  Secure Venues

We will be taking over Manor Road in Austin, TX and transforming a uniquely-Austin street into a carnivalesque atmosphere of queer art and adventure! We already have several venues on board, including The Salvage Vanguard Theater, The Vortex, in.gredients, Mi Madre's, School House Pub and Windmill Bicycles as well as two satellite venues—The Contemporary Austin and Cheer Up Charlie’s. To guarantee these spaces and to collectively shape them into the spectacular queer wonderland of our imagining, we will need substantial funds.

o  Facilitate Artist Attendance

OUTsider is intended to be a space of active participation and exchange between artists, academics and the general public. Hosting programmed artists and academics present at the festival is, therefore, imperative to the excitement and vitality of the event. Travel expenses are costly, however, and the more money we raise, the more amazing artists we will be able to bring to OUTsider.

o Pay for Operations Costs

This includes everything from building performance stages to tenting to obtaining city permits to promotional costs in order to get the word out . . . you name it!

In return for your donation, we offer a number of fun and fabulous rewards, based on the amount of your contribution. These include:

o One-time-only perks, like a shout out on the Reverie & Randee Show, a 30-second sketch of historical OUTsiders from acclaimed artists Heyd Fontenot and Jonsey, or an original jingle written for you by famous musician Gretchen Phillips!

o  Severely discounted badges to the first annual OUTsider Festival, so you can enjoy this queer art extravaganza first-hand!

o OUTsider memberships up to the Platinum-level. These memberships come with a set of exclusive VIP benefits, such as access to restricted parties and events. See our website for more info on becoming a high-profile OUTsider  member through a substantial donation.

Risks & Challenges

Starting a new festival is always difficult. But, this is especially true of a festival like OUTsider, which marches to the beat of its own tambourine. Building an unprecedented festival from scratch, for which there is no precise mold, requires a considerable amount of courage and creative thinking, and an even greater amount of financial support.

As this is a new festival and a new concept, we realize that we are asking folks to take a leap of faith in supporting us. But, this is a leap of faith that will yield extraordinary returns. By lending us your support, you will provide the solid foundation for a bold new chapter in the evolution of queer art and community!


FAQs

Where did the idea for OUTsider come from?

OUTsider is the brainchild of a community of queer artists and seasoned festival organizers with a daringly original vision: Unsatisfied with a status quo that keeps (queer) art forms and audiences separate, and that offers limited arenas for audience interaction and engagement, the OUTsider team has envisioned a festival and conference that is decidedly multi-arts and defiantly out-of-the-box.

What do you mean by “multi-arts”?

Multi-arts means not only bringing together LGBTQI and ally artists of every stripe from around the globe, but creating a space in which art forms and audience members can actively intermingle and intertwine—a fun, inclusive space in which participants are encouraged to venture beyond their artistic comfort zones, whether collaborating with artists in other fields during the festival, or delving into freshly discovered artistic mediums as attendees.

Such a space will lead to uncommon artworks, captivating conversations, new types of community united across differences, and a magical “queer” experience that will provide inspiration and sustenance to artists, audiences and academics as they continue to impassion the world with their creations.

4. What do you mean by “OUTsider”?

Outsider is the overlooked, the undervalued, the marginalized, the oddball, the misfit. Outsider exists in tension with the banal and challenges the status quo. OUTsider (the festival) embraces the multiple meanings of the term “outsider,” and seeks to build upon notions of queer outsiderness to make connections to other forms of marginalization, including those related to race, ethnicity, class, gender, ability, size, nationality and generation.

4. Who is welcome at OUTsider?

If you are an art buff, if you support the LGBTQI and Ally communities, or if you simply appreciate wild new ideas, you are already part of the OUTsider community and we hope to see you at the festival. Welcome!


Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to help us financially, we still need your help! Please help us spread the word about our Indiegogo campaign by using the Indiegogo share tools to notify your friends and make some fierce noise about our campaign.


WATCH THE NEXT EPISODES OF THE REVERIE AND RANDEE SHOW!

story:
I am in need of a place to create new ideas without the limit of familiarity or the pressures of work, Residencia Sao Joao is just that. I am excited that I now have the opportunity to leave one artist community, Bushwick, Brooklyn and join another more international condensed artist collective and to collaborate with artists from different locales all over the world. I'm looking to broaden my idea of what is seen through the eyes of lands foreign to me. I think through interacting with artists in a new cultural environment I will form a more enriched perspective and vision.

 During the residency I intend to explore alternative printing methods. Using photography, relief printing, stamping, transfer and other methods that will be developed in practice, I seek to develop a new language for 3 Dot Zine.

I seek to finish a zine while in Brazil. I will start the process of that zine with the Launch of Issue #2 that will take place in August. Upon returning I will submit the follow up to Issue #2 that will be informed by my learnings while in Brazil. 

What Your Contribution Supports!

  • Residency cost $400
  • Supplies & Shipping Costs $400 
  • Thanks to a gracious friend my plane ticket has been taken care of. I'm not able to update the amount for the campaign to show this change. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    You reading this campaign is help alone, but there are other ways to contribute.  

    • Help me get the word out! Share the campaign in a status or email. 
    • Help me pack (hehe)
    • Give any advice you have for international traveling
    • Remember to use Indiegogo share tools where possible

    I am excited for this opportunity and am thankful for your support! There is nothing like the help of friends. I thank you in advance for your contribution!

story:
I dont know if you are aware but obesity is killing our families BUT we can save our own family!! 

The Art of Capoeira Transforming the Life of Son and Mother.

We are excited to include you in this wonderful opportunity to support my son, Michael Perdomo and I, Sol Perdomo in traveling to Brazil to participate in the Power of Capoeira. Different towns from Brazil are coming together to celebrate annual Capoeira events in which Capoeiristas will be competing for ranks. From August 17th through the 27th, the group which we are part of Abada Capoeira NYC; will be going to Brazil on a Delegation that will give us the opportunity to share the language classes, baking classes, capoeira, sustainable arts and crafts, and cultural celebrations.

This will be my family’s first time visiting Brazil after becoming part of the big family of Abada Capoeira. Some of my family members where suffering obesity and my oldest son of three, Michael was 85 pounds overweight at the age of 12. I was working as a home attendant and I did not have a lot of time to help my son to lose weight. One day I chose to make my family’s health a priority. My son’s doctor recommended capoeira and I enrolled my son; after which I decided to join my son in his capoeira efforts. Additionally, his other two younger brothers who were overweight joined the class. Due to my family’s struggle with finances I decided to do a course on pastries and today I divide my time between baking, home attendant and bringing my son to every capoeira class. Thanks to the Art of Capoeira the total sum of my family’s weight loss is over 200 pounds!  

This year my son Michael won a ticket to travel to Brazil and I will be joining him. I feel it would be a great exchange between me and other Brazilian mothers about my struggle to raise my family. I plan on giving baking classes to the women in some of the favelas in Rio de Janeiro. Favelas are communities that have been neglected, exploited and systemically ignored in the media for years. Our goal is to provide the resources for communities to powerfully take charge of their own life.

  

What We Need 1 Plane Ticket : $ 1500 

Food and accommodation for 10 days: $ 500 *2= $1000

Bakery Mixer: $320 *2= $640

Bakery Products: $260    Total = $ 3,400  With this amount,  we can definitely make this vision a reality, and we can not just give my family an opportunity to travel but a group of Mothers that live in Favela an opportunity to start their own business. However, we hope to raise more than our goal, in which case we would use the money for the program that Abada Capoeira offer in our neighborhood. 

What We Have

We have 1 ticket to Brazil, we have $600 dollars to re-new our passport, and a lot of energy to make cake to raise money.   

LETS MAKE THIS HAPPEN!

 1. Donate some money 

2. Tell a friend to tell a friend (Use the share tool... E-mail, Blog about it, Facebook, Tweet it all day) 

3.If you have any connections that would be helpful, please let us know.  We seek alliances with parents, teachers, youth groups,  Obesity Prevention  groups, journalists, and most importantly the youth themselves to spread the message about the importance of a Abada Capoeira as a door for a power path.

story:
L’exposition Chimères présente trente-six photographies extraites d’une série de reportages autour des Arts de la Scène, réalisés par Mara De Sario depuis 2009.

Autour de son travail de vagabondage scénique Mara nous dévoile des histoires qui vont au-delà de la simple commande photographique. Nourrie par la liberté que lui procure son travail, elle capte des sentiments impalpables, presque subliminaux avec un regard de photographe affûté, sensible et subjectif. Ses images sont des sentiments, des rencontres, des moments privilégiés avec des artistes de tous bords qui exultent, rêvent ... Chaque cliché raconte des histoires d’hommes et de femmes, transcendés, métamorphosés par leur performance ou dans l’abandon de soi ; l’expression de leurs corps nous dévoile des personnages à la fois poétiques, étranges et subliminaux.

Aujourd’hui, Mara décide d’accrocher cette histoire sur les murs. L’envie de partager avec le public cette aventure scénique et vagabonde. Parce que la création d’une œuvre ne peut exister que si elle est partagée auprès du grand public. Pour un artiste c’est une nouvelle mise à nu, à la fois effrayante et excitante !

  • Le Projet :

La volonté de Mara est de proposer une exposition à la fois itinérante et évolutive dans le temps, afin que ces photographies puissent générer des rencontres : avec les acteurs culturels, avec les artistes, avec le public, mais aussi, et surtout, entre ces publics.

Le projet de Mara est de faire voyager son travail dans plusieurs lieux, tout en poursuivant son travail de photographe autour des arts de la scène. Chaque rencontre donnera naissance à de nouvelles histoires. Des nouvelles photographies s’ajouteront aux Chimères, comme pour leurs rendre une suite naturelle … Une Exposition itinérante et évolutive dont la première série sera dévoilée en septembre 2013.

 Lire le dossier de Partenariat Chimères 

  • Vous Coproducteur :

Parce qu’en dehors de la difficulté de rassembler les fonds nécessaires pour mettre réellement en valeur une série de photographies, Mara aime l’idée que chaque personne sensible à son travail participera, à sa hauteur, à la naissance d’une exposition, qui voyagera à son tour avec une part de chacun ...

La Compagnie du plat pays ! a créé un fond de création en 2009 afin de soutenir financièrement la réalisation des projets « Artistes Associés ». En tant qu’association d’artistes, de production des Arts et Arts de la scène non-subventionnée, le financement d’un projet artistique passe par l’autoproduction et sa réalisation par l’aide de nombreux partenaires. Nous souhaitons le dire haut et fort : ce projet sera lui aussi COLLABORATIF ! car en participant financièrement à cette exposition, vous devenez directement et pour n’importe quel apport (comme dans les coopératives), un coproducteur exécutif potentiel (potentiel car vous n’êtes pas obligé d’utiliser vos super pouvoirs). 

Ainsi, votre premier super pouvoir sera de choisir une des photographies qui sera votre coup de cœur ou qui vous turlupine, vous questionne à tel point qu’elle vous empêche de dormir. Les photographies sélectionnée feront l’objet d’une exposition coup de foudre en 2015.

Votre deuxième super pouvoir sera de commenter l’une des photographies de l’exposition que nous enverrons à tous les coproducteurs. Vous nous donnerez vos sentiments, votre coup de cœur et vos histoires.

Votre troisième super pouvoir sera de diffuser l’exposition autour de vous car vous obtiendrez, selon vos contributions, des photographies.

Associez-vous à ce projet en l’accueillant, en le soutenant financièrement, en relayant l'information pour faire vivre et tourner cette exposition le plus largement possible.

  • À quoi servira notre collecte de fonds ?

La réalisation du projet Chimères coûte bien plus que 10.000 euros, (en général un projet artistique à petit budget tourne autour de 25 000 euros). Si vos participations couvrent 2.500€, nous serons plus que comblé !

Notre objectif 2.500€ moins les frais 175€ de service Indiegogo = 2.325€ Ce montant n'est qu'une base (indispensable) pour mener à bien la réalisation de l’exposition.

  • L'exposition comprenant l’impression de 36 photographies (De Formats variés : Tirage 40 x 60 / 50 x 75 / 80 x 120). Le tout imprimé sur papier FineArt écologique, contrecollé sur dibond = 1.680€
  • Une sélection de photographies en cartes postales = 350€
  • Petit matériel d’exposition (Accrochage, éclairage, etc.) = 300€
  • Organisation de la réception du vernissage de septembre 2013 = 200€

Si l’objectif est dépassé, l’argent sera plus que bienvenu pour les autres frais, non comptabilisés tels que : Frais de promotion & production / Frais d’accueil & frais généraux (déplacement, assurance, administation, téléphone, etc…) / Rémunération du travail de l’équipe : Artiste & Production / Aide pour nos prochains projets. /.

Si le fait de contribuer par paypal ou par carte de crédit ne vous convient pas, vous pouvez également verser votre don sur le compte de Asbl Compagnie du Plat pays, avec votre nom et la communication : « Don - Chimères - Votre nom et adresse e-mail. » Vos contreparties vous seront offertes. (Mais n'apparaîtron pas sur ce site.) 

  • Banque Triodos : BE13 5230 8024 4539  /  BIC : TRIOBEBB 
  • Asbl Compagnie du Plat pays 
  • 203, rue d’Onnezies – 7380 Baisieux - Belgique 
  • Mail : info@cieduplatpays.be

La Compagnie du Plat pays ! vous remercie de votre engagement culturel.

Générique :

  • Un projet de Mara De Sario
  • Une production *Artistes Associés* Compagnie du Plat pays !
  • Chargé de production : Sébastien Domogalla
  • Les partenaires du projet : (Distribution en cours.)
  • *Centre Culturel de Dour (1er Exposition du 21 septembre au 03 novembre 2013.)
  • *Centre Culturel de Mouscron (2em Exposition du 27 février au 23 mars 2014.)

Présentation de l’artiste : Mara De Sario – Photographe.

Originaire des Hauts Pays, Mara dés son plus jeune âge est attiré par l’image et dévore la bibliothèque familiale. À 16 ans, elle décide de prendre des cours du soir afin d’apprendre les techniques photographiques, avant de poursuivre sa formation à l’Institut des hautes Etudes des Communications Sociales (IHECS Bruxelles) et à l’Ecole de Recherche Graphique (ERG Bruxelles.) dont elle sort diplômée. Attirée par les arts de la scène et ces petits moments de la vie, Mara développe au travers de son parcours pluridisciplinaire une approche documentaire, artistique et narrative de la photographie.

Depuis 2004, Mara couvre plusieurs événements culturels dont entre autres : « Festival européen des écoles de cirque de Honnelles, Festival du Court Métrage (Bruxelles), BE Film Festival (Bruxelles), ProsVia (Mons), Festival International du Film d’Amour (Mons), Festival International du Film Francophone (Namur), Festival Ciné32 – Indépendance(s) et Création, Auch (France). Depuis 2009, Mara est « Artistes Associés de la Compagnie du Plat pays ! Asbl ». Elle poursuit sa collaboration avec plusieurs troupes de cirques, de théâtre, de musique dont « L’Acteur et l’écrit de Fréderic Dussene », le « cirque Farrago », le groupe de musique « Moon Hop » (Bordeaux) et « Antoine Hénaut » (Belgique) pour l’album « 36.000 ». En 2013, entre divers spectacles, et la préparation de l’exposition « Chimères » Mara couvre le Tribunal Russell pour la Palestine en présence de Roger Waters.

La structure de production en quelques mots : 

L’ASBL Compagnie du Plat pays !  « Association d’artistes, de production artistique des Arts et Arts de la scène ».  Elle se consacre depuis 2005, à accompagner des artistes, auteurs, interprètes dans la réalisation de leurs projets, avec expertise, engagement et humour. Elle est née d’une envie de rassembler, de mêler les arts en les sortant de leur cadre ordinaire et d’échanger avec tous les milieux artistiques comme le cirque, la danse, le théâtre, l’audiovisuel, la musique, les arts plastiques et l’artisanat. En prenant à cœur l’engagement de l’artiste et sa position au sein de la société, la compagnie présente des pratiques, des styles artistiques variés en faisant des choix avec une nette préférence pour les thèmes sociaux, elle contribue à sa façon à la recherche d’une conscience, d’un dialogue, d’une identité culturelle. Elle s’est forgé une reconnaissance auprès des publics et programmateurs en traversant les frontières de la Belgique, se produisant notamment en France, en Suisse, en Espagne, en Hollande et au Canada.

Le projet de l’association se fonde sur une dynamique de recherche de synergies et de mutualisation des moyens au profit du travail artistique.De tout temps, la réalisation de créations artistiques a nécessité talent, inspiration, travail et une bonne dose de rêves, de risques, de folies et de passions. Il y a tout un chemin parcouru entre la naissance d’une idée et l’aboutissement d’une œuvre quelle que soit sa forme finale

Plus d’infos sur : www.cieduplatpays.be
story_txt:
L’exposition Chimères présente trente-six photographies extraites d’une série de reportages autour des Arts de la Scène, réalisés par Mara De Sario depuis 2009.
Autour de son travail de vagabondage scénique Mara nous dévoile des histoires qui vont au-delà de la simple commande photographique. Nourrie par la liberté que lui procure son travail, elle capte des sentiments impalpables, presque subliminaux avec un regard de photographe affûté, sensible et subjectif. Ses images sont des sentiments, des rencontres, des moments privilégiés avec des artistes de tous bords qui exultent, rêvent ... Chaque cliché raconte des histoires d’hommes et de femmes, transcendés, métamorphosés par leur performance ou dans l’abandon de soi ; l’expression de leurs corps nous dévoile des personnages à la fois poétiques, étranges et subliminaux.
Aujourd’hui, Mara décide d’accrocher cette histoire sur les murs. L’envie de partager avec le public cette aventure scénique et vagabonde. Parce que la création d’une œuvre ne peut exister que si elle est partagée auprès du grand public. Pour un artiste c’est une nouvelle mise à nu, à la fois effrayante et excitante !


Le Projet :

La volonté de Mara est de proposer une exposition à la fois itinérante et évolutive dans le temps, afin que ces photographies puissent générer des rencontres : avec les acteurs culturels, avec les artistes, avec le public, mais aussi, et surtout, entre ces publics.

Le projet de Mara est de faire voyager son travail dans plusieurs lieux, tout en poursuivant son travail de photographe autour des arts de la scène. Chaque rencontre donnera naissance à de nouvelles histoires. Des nouvelles photographies s’ajouteront aux Chimères, comme pour leurs rendre une suite naturelle … Une Exposition itinérante et évolutive dont la première série sera dévoilée en septembre 2013.
 Lire le dossier de Partenariat Chimères 


Vous Coproducteur :

Parce qu’en dehors de la difficulté de rassembler les fonds nécessaires pour mettre réellement en valeur une série de photographies, Mara aime l’idée que chaque personne sensible à son travail participera, à sa hauteur, à la naissance d’une exposition, qui voyagera à son tour avec une part de chacun ...
La Compagnie du plat pays ! a créé un fond de création en 2009 afin de soutenir financièrement la réalisation des projets « Artistes Associés ». En tant qu’association d’artistes, de production des Arts et Arts de la scène non-subventionnée, le financement d’un projet artistique passe par l’autoproduction et sa réalisation par l’aide de nombreux partenaires. Nous souhaitons le dire haut et fort : ce projet sera lui aussi COLLABORATIF ! car en participant financièrement à cette exposition, vous devenez directement et pour n’importe quel apport (comme dans les coopératives), un coproducteur exécutif potentiel (potentiel car vous n’êtes pas obligé d’utiliser vos super pouvoirs). 
Ainsi, votre premier super pouvoir sera de choisir une des photographies qui sera votre coup de cœur ou qui vous turlupine, vous questionne à tel point qu’elle vous empêche de dormir. Les photographies sélectionnée feront l’objet d’une exposition coup de foudre en 2015.
Votre deuxième super pouvoir sera de commenter l’une des photographies de l’exposition que nous enverrons à tous les coproducteurs. Vous nous donnerez vos sentiments, votre coup de cœur et vos histoires.
Votre troisième super pouvoir sera de diffuser l’exposition autour de vous car vous obtiendrez, selon vos contributions, des photographies.
Associez-vous à ce projet en l’accueillant, en le soutenant financièrement, en relayant l'information pour faire vivre et tourner cette exposition le plus largement possible.


À quoi servira notre collecte de fonds ?

La réalisation du projet Chimères coûte bien plus que 10.000 euros, (en général un projet artistique à petit budget tourne autour de 25 000 euros). Si vos participations couvrent 2.500€, nous serons plus que comblé !
Notre objectif 2.500€ moins les frais 175€ de service Indiegogo = 2.325€ Ce montant n'est qu'une base (indispensable) pour mener à bien la réalisation de l’exposition.

L'exposition comprenant l’impression de 36 photographies (De Formats variés : Tirage 40 x 60 / 50 x 75 / 80 x 120). Le tout imprimé sur papier FineArt écologique, contrecollé sur dibond = 1.680€

Une sélection de photographies en cartes postales = 350€

Petit matériel d’exposition (Accrochage, éclairage, etc.) = 300€

Organisation de la réception du vernissage de septembre 2013 = 200€

Si l’objectif est dépassé, l’argent sera plus que bienvenu pour les autres frais, non comptabilisés tels que : Frais de promotion & production / Frais d’accueil & frais généraux (déplacement, assurance, administation, téléphone, etc…) / Rémunération du travail de l’équipe : Artiste & Production / Aide pour nos prochains projets. /.
Si le fait de contribuer par paypal ou par carte de crédit ne vous convient pas, vous pouvez également verser votre don sur le compte de Asbl Compagnie du Plat pays, avec votre nom et la communication : « Don - Chimères - Votre nom et adresse e-mail. » Vos contreparties vous seront offertes. (Mais n'apparaîtron pas sur ce site.) 

Banque Triodos : BE13 5230 8024 4539  /  BIC : TRIOBEBB 
Asbl Compagnie du Plat pays 

203, rue d’Onnezies – 7380 Baisieux - Belgique 
Mail : info@cieduplatpays.be

story:
Short Summary

My name is Yanai and I am an Art student at Miami Dade College in Miami, Fl. I work and study full time and still have managed to keep my GPA at 3.83. I was recently accepted into my college's Study Abroad Program. From all destinations I picked Florence to take Art History and Drawing because it is the city of the fine arts by excellence, it is rich in history and as an art student, living and studying there for a few months will be an experience hard to equal. It will challenge my creativity, improve my drawing skills and develop my artistic abilities, and significantly increase my knowledge about art. I will be studying at Lorenzo de' Medici Institute: http://www.lorenzodemedici.org/

What I Need & What You Get

My goal is to raise $10,000 to take full advantage of this opportunity. Besides my classes, I will start a project to document my trip. I will be making sketches, drawings, and photographs of my daily experiences and there is where you come in. Your contribution will be entirely used to make this project a reality. I need to purchase art materials, a portable computer. I also need to cover the expenses incurred in traveling for my research, and the shipping costs of sending your reward.

Your rewards:

You will have the chance to own pieces of the FIRST EDITION OF THE FIRST COLLECTION I ever made. Of course I have made other drawings but they are mostly class assignments or practices with the purpose of teaching me certain techniques. In this trip I will do my very own creative art project and you will have some of the artwork!!!!

The Impact

I am a low income student studying in a public college. My current earnings and Financial Aid are not enough to cover all my educational expenses nor my extra curricular activities including studying abroad, volunteer work or materials for my projects. Therefore, your support will have a significant impact in the achievement of my success.

Studying abroad will not only enrich my artistic portfolio, it would also build more solid roots for my future career. I have been seriously thinking of Art History as a minor and visiting Florence will be crucial for me to make the final decision.

After the summer term, I will be ready to transfer to the upper division to complete my education. The major in Fine Arts requires a portfolio review in which the school evaluates the students' talent and skills. It is crucial for me to build a professional and consistent portfolio that impress the jurors. The drawings I need to build the portfolio will be made in this trip. It will include the best drawings of my project!!

My project is NOT one of those that can't be done if the full amount is not raised. If I don't get the full amount I need, your contribution won't be spent in anything but the project and in the development of my artistic skills. I'll still use the amount raised to buy art materials, but maybe I won't be able to make as many drawings as I want to. I'll be limited to draw until the materials are exhusted. I won't be able to travel to the outskirts of Florence to meet the authentic Italians either, as it is my desire. I believe I can make more interesting and powerful drawings of the people in the little towns than from people in the city. Traveling is essential to stimulate artists creativity.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't help me with money, don't feel bad yet!! YOU STILL CAN HELP!!! Spread the voice, send it to your friends, post it on facebook, twitter, and other social networks. I am very grateful for any kind of support.

Thank you. Gracias. Grazie.

FAQs

  • How can I support the project?

Just click one of the pink bottoms on the right hand side of the project's page: "Claim this Perk" 

  • How do I pay? Is it save?

IndieGoGo offers the option of paying through paypal. If you don't feel confortable paying with your CC or Paypal, contact me to make other arrangements.

  • When am I getting my reward?

Most of them will be delivered within the month of my return to the United States. I'll come back on July 31, so you should be receiving your perk before Aug 31.

  • How can you be contacted?
Visit my facebook page http://www.facebook.com/YanaiNassar

story:
In September of 2011, through our children’s teachers, we learned that the Flint Community Schools eliminated the art education program and budget for all elementary levels schools.  As concerned citizens and parents, my husband and I decided to volunteer to teach art at Eisenhower Elementary, with the principal’s permission.  The program we created is completely voluntary and the teachers are under no obligation to invite us into their classrooms, but every teacher in the building consistently welcomes us into their rooms with complete enthusiasm.  Since the beginning of the school year we have utilized teacher input to develop a program that both the students enjoy and that works with their existing curriculum. 

We encourage students to use art as a coping mechanism as well as a learning tool.  Our projects focus on fine motor skill development through scissor and controlled brush use.  We have also made it a point to include a variety of tools including compasses, rulers, and protractors that the students will need an understanding of as they progress in grade level.  We have also hosted several art based events in the school including our Art in Real Life event in January 2012 where we partnered with nine local artists of different mediums, including the Dean of Fine Arts from Mott Community College, who volunteered their time to show students their work and the tools they use to create it.  This event was broadcast on WNEM evening news. 

One of the sixth grade classes was given an amazing opportunity to work with Flint Comix.  The students, as a group, wrote a complete comic story for Flint Comix’s The Spark character that was drawn and inked by Brian Hackney.  The students discussed sequential art and watched the comic development process from penciling, to inking, to computer touches, and then finally published in the January 2012 issue with their names as authors.  We have also collaborated with Mott Community College, The Creative Alliance, Pages Bookstore, and were honored to host a performance by the University of Michigan’s Dance for Schools Program. 

Unfortunately, the majority of our supplies currently come from our family income, limiting what projects we are able to do with the students.  We are reaching out to the community to help us raise funds for supplies for our soon to be 700 students for the 2012-2013 school year.  All donations will go towards keeping art in the elementary schools in Flint, MI through supplies like colored pencils, glue, molding clay, paint, brushes, canvases, etc.

story:
MANGO PEELER RUNS ISLAND TO ISLAND

Canadian-Filipino artist, teacher, and marathon runner MANGO PEELER (Jepoy Garcia) embarks on a journey to his roots in the Philippines. During his artist residency he will bring together arts and athletics with the local youth and surfers on a Secret Island, and bring the journey back home to Canada.

Pre-selected as the first international artist for this NOMADIC ARTIST-IN-RESIDENCE PROGRAM IN THE PHILIPPINES by The Unifiedfield.


From my Jungle Program to my Space Travel Program, I teach kids that the world is round and colourful. They always remind me that travel keeps us young and our imaginations fresh.

For 3 years I have been part of the Visiting Artist Program at Children's art studio and have been creating exciting work with children from ages 3-7 years old. The funds will go to the studio so Lynn Jackson (Director) can continue her  positive and innovative programming for youth.

*** 10% of the funds raised I will donate to Children's Art Studio at Artscape Wychwood Barns in Toronto, Canada. ***

 


Bamboo Hut Studio, Photo Courtesy of The Unifiedfield.

BENEFITS OF RESIDENCY & MOTIVATION

Back in 2008 after winning an award for Best Mixed Media at the Toronto Outdoor Art Exhibition, I embarked on a mission to my homeland in search of my roots. That trip was the first time I have visited as a practicing artist and it has influenced the trajectory of my work until now. Recently being invited to exhibit at the Art Gallery of Ontario, my artistic practice is reaching a new level and I feel the need re-invigorate this inspiration I felt with this residency. I am very interested in the cultural and artistic exchange with the local communities in the Philippines and bringing back the journey and knowledge to my students here in Canada.  I also feel the combination of collaborative art making and athletics is an integral part of the future of art education. This residency will allow us the opportunity to expand and unify our international communities. I feel that as a Filipino raised abroad, my perspective is unique for this type of exchange. 

 

Photo by Vuk Dragojevic

BIOGRAPHY

I am a Filipino-Canadian artist and work in a diverse range of media including collage, screen printing, installation, fashion, food, workshops, the internet, and performative athletics. My process involves the collecting, sorting and patterning of found ephemera. Known for my large scale installations and happenings, I'm interested in bringing people together through colour and energy. I have exhibited extensively in Canada and had solo exhibitions in Tokyo and Kyoto Japan where I explored my interest in healing power methods and mystics. I recently exhibited in The Art Gallery of Ontario’s Massive Party. With the theme of ‘Gold’, I created an extravagant Filipino-Baroque jungle featuring glittering costumes, and signature ‘Psych Bike Caravan’. I am a self-taught artist also known for my collaborative teaching methods and experimental residencies. I was the founder of Halo Halo Village  (2009-2012), an exploratory impulse studio specializing in screen printing and experimental workshops. I continue to work extensively with students of all age groups at Seneca College, Sheridan College, Ontario College of Art & Design, The Art Gallery Of Ontario, Artscape, and I am also featured in The Royal Ontario Museum.

I am also a marathon runner and culinary artist. I use performative running groups, long distance races and Hot Pot Workshops to bring people together to celebrate health. Internationally known as Mango Peeler, my art, fashion and video have also been attracting commissions and collaborations from celebrities such as Drake, October’s Very Own, Josephine Foster, R.Kelly, and Diplo.

 

 

 

 


What we need for the residency & what you will get:

1. Secret Sandscape

Inspired by my favourite book 'Woman in The Dunes' by Kobo Abe, I will create work with sand while on the Secret Island and e-mail you a photograph during my residency.

 

2. Secret Island Map

You will be mailed a screenprinted map of the co-ordinates of the Secret Island in the Philippines where I will be working with the local youth and surfers. The map will be mailed out during my residency. Your contribution will also go towards art supplies during the residency and workshops.

 

3. Mango Marathon Poster

On May 5th 2013 I ran the Toronto Goodlife Marathon (42.195 KM- The last 5K I ran with a palm tree!). You will receive a hand printed poster of my bib tag and runners high inspired images. The poster value of $42.20 is a dollar for every kilometer I ran. Your purchase will also go towards my travel costs Island to Island.


4. Daily Video

A short daily video documenting the 50 day residency will be made each day. The video will be dedicated to you and your name will appear somewhere in the video. The compilation of videos will be uploaded to my channel and you can share the journey with me. Your contribution will also be going towards a Go Pro and camera equipment.

 
 
5. Mail Art

I will be making 50 pieces of mail art while on the Secret Island for every day I am in the Philippines. The mail art could include collages, drawings, writing, photographs, found objects, sand, or a message in a bottle. The mail art will be sent out during the residency and you will receive it randomly. Your contribution will be going towards my residency fees and my host family on the island.

 

6. CATCH & r e l e a s e T-Shirt

This hand printed T-Shirt is inspired by fly fishing for rainbow trout with my father on the Grand River in Canada. I will be learning how the islanders catch their fish on the Secret Island as it is their main source of food and livelihood. Your purchase will also go towards the T-Shirt printing workshops on the Island.

The shirt will be shipped to you in September. S / M / L / XL 100% cotton.

 
7. WARRIOR*REGALIA T-SHIRT

This hand printed T-Shirt is inspired by 'Traditional Philippines Music of Mindanao' on Folkways Records, and the warrior spirit of Indigenous people of the Philippines.

Limited varied editions of 50. The shirt will be shipped to you in September. S / M / L / XL 100% cotton.

 

 
8. MANGO PEELER POSTER PACK

You will receive a tube full of hand made posters. Some posters will be pulled during my residency and some in my studio in Toronto. You will receive the poster pack in September 2013. Your purchase will also go towards the screen printing supplies and  workshops on the Island.

 
9. PSYCH KITES

As a part of my residency, I will be creating 'Psych Kites' with the youth in the one school on the Island. Your patronage will help with the materials and creation of the kites. Your name will be written on the kite and it will fly in the sky in your honour.

A video will be made and the link will be emailed to you. Your contribution will also go towards a documentary that will be filmed during my residency.

The Psych Kites will be made in the same spirit as my signature Psych Bikes. Psych Bikes that evoke memories of colourful Jeepneys and the Ati-Atihan Festival.

Photo by Eleni Alpous

 

 10. Banks

Since high school I have been creating 'Banks' filled with my collages, observations, collected detritus, and obsessions. I call these books/journals 'Banks' as I make deposits and save memories or I cash them and take the images for other projects. You will receive an original Bank that I make in the Philippines filled with daily peelings from my residency. Each of the 10 Banks will be dedicated to the sponsoring patron and the collection will be shown in Toronto in September 2013. 

 

 
11. Toronto Island 2-Day Workshop

A 2 day workshop on Toronto Island will complete the Island to Island exchange. The workshop will include field recordings, silk screening 101, collaborative book/bank making, hot pot meals and running exercises. Your contribution will go towards studio space, materials, food, and travel to and from Toronto Island.

Funds will also be going towards my mentorship programming upon arrival in Toronto. I will also be continuing my mentorship work with Clutch, an arts program for Filipina Women, hosted by KPC. I have worked extensively with Kapisanan Philippine Centre for Arts & Culture which is a Filipino-Canadian community arts organization that has a space in downtown Toronto. Kapisanan has also agreed to support any exchange via internet or exhibition assistance upon return. 

 Photo by Vuk Dragojevic

 

12. Custom Hand Made Surf Board

During my residency I will be taking workshops with a master surfboard maker. The custom surfboards will be made from the native wood on the Island. Every morning during my residency I will be creating, painting and silkscreening the surfboards. I will use the board as a canvas and it will be ridden on the waves of the Pacific Ocean. Your patronage will be going towards the materials and creation of the surfboards, the workshop fee, shipping costs, and an exhibition in Toronto in September.


Photos of surfboards courtesy of The Unifiedfield. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Many of you are my close friends and have seen my work grow over the years. I understand if you can not make a monetary contribution, but you can help share my journey and spread the word! To all my family, friends, followers, students and patrons that helped make this happen, THANK YOU. All my best thoughts and thanks for helping my vision come a reality.

A special thanks to Marta and Ivan my residency hosts at The Unifiedfield. 

SALAMATS!


 

Testimonials

‘What struck me most about Jepoy and his work was the deep and genuine committment to the visual practice he’s completely invested in observing, exploring and making. He has a beautiful faciity for drawing and composition and uses this to consider his environment in ways that are both moving and provoking. His work is fresh, beautiful and often fun but it is also extremely smart and thoughtful.’ Nina Leo, TOAE Juror

‘Jepoy is ready to be your homeboy. He's down for whatever, always hustlin' but ready to party. Jepoy is a collage artist, working with the physical and cultural detritus of late-capitalist urban life. He's gonna take what he can get and make it better, for you and for me. This is the dream of Canada, and Jepoy here to tell the story JUST SO YOU DON'T FORGET IT.’ Zeesy Powers, Multi-Disciplinary Artist and Contemporary.

‘Your magic really was the perfect remedy. Our play was so energizing and invigorating. What a divine dose of FRESH you gave the class!! I don't know how to thank you for such a profound change you made in me.’ Patricia Molina, OCAD Sculpture Student.

 

FOLLOW ME ISLAND TO ISLAND

WWW.MANGOPEELER.CA

FACEBOOK PAGE

TUMBLR

TWITTER 

INSTAGRAM 

VIMEO
story_txt:
MANGO PEELER RUNS ISLAND TO ISLAND
Canadian-Filipino artist, teacher, and marathon runner MANGO PEELER (Jepoy Garcia) embarks on a journey to his roots in the Philippines. During his artist residency he will bring together arts and athletics with the local youth and surfers on a Secret Island, and bring the journey back home to Canada.
Pre-selected as the first international artist for this NOMADIC ARTIST-IN-RESIDENCE PROGRAM IN THE PHILIPPINES by The Unifiedfield.

From my Jungle Program to my Space Travel Program, I teach kids that the world is round and colourful. They always remind me that travel keeps us young and our imaginations fresh.
For 3 years I have been part of the Visiting Artist Program at Children's art studio and have been creating exciting work with children from ages 3-7 years old. The funds will go to the studio so Lynn Jackson (Director) can continue her  positive and innovative programming for youth.
*** 10% of the funds raised I will donate to Children's Art Studio at Artscape Wychwood Barns in Toronto, Canada. ***
 

Bamboo Hut Studio, Photo Courtesy of The Unifiedfield.
BENEFITS OF RESIDENCY & MOTIVATIONBack in 2008 after winning an award for Best Mixed Media at the Toronto Outdoor Art Exhibition, I embarked on a mission to my homeland in search of my roots. That trip was the first time I have visited as a practicing artist and it has influenced the trajectory of my work until now. Recently being invited to exhibit at the Art Gallery of Ontario, my artistic practice is reaching a new level and I feel the need re-invigorate this inspiration I felt with this residency. I am very interested in the cultural and artistic exchange with the local communities in the Philippines and bringing back the journey and knowledge to my students here in Canada.  I also feel the combination of collaborative art making and athletics is an integral part of the future of art education. This residency will allow us the opportunity to expand and unify our international communities. I feel that as a Filipino raised abroad, my perspective is unique for this type of exchange. 
 

Photo by Vuk DragojevicBIOGRAPHY
I am a Filipino-Canadian artist and work in a diverse range of media including collage, screen printing, installation, fashion, food, workshops, the internet, and performative athletics. My process involves the collecting, sorting and patterning of found ephemera. Known for my large scale installations and happenings, I'm interested in bringing people together through colour and energy. I have exhibited extensively in Canada and had solo exhibitions in Tokyo and Kyoto Japan where I explored my interest in healing power methods and mystics. I recently exhibited in The Art Gallery of Ontario’s Massive Party. With the theme of ‘Gold’, I created an extravagant Filipino-Baroque jungle featuring glittering costumes, and signature ‘Psych Bike Caravan’. I am a self-taught artist also known for my collaborative teaching methods and experimental residencies. I was the founder of Halo Halo Village  (2009-2012), an exploratory impulse studio specializing in screen printing and experimental workshops. I continue to work extensively with students of all age groups at Seneca College, Sheridan College, Ontario College of Art & Design, The Art Gallery Of Ontario, Artscape, and I am also featured in The Royal Ontario Museum.
I am also a marathon runner and culinary artist. I use performative running groups, long distance races and Hot Pot Workshops to bring people together to celebrate health. Internationally known as Mango Peeler, my art, fashion and video have also been attracting commissions and collaborations from celebrities such as Drake, October’s Very Own, Josephine Foster, R.Kelly, and Diplo.

story:
Our Story

My show will consist of 60 or so fine art portraits that I've made of famous Americans. They measure 13" X 19" and will matte out nicely to 16X20 (www.availablelightphoto.com). Also I will unveil new images of figure models styled and posed as Greco-Roman statuary. Some will be photographed in studio and some in garden settings.

Also, I'll have selections of images made over 40 years that I know people from this area will be sentimental about. They will vary in size from 13X19 to 5'X15'.


The Impact

Besides showing my latest portraits I'll be exhibiting an entirely new line of work. The head shot and family portrait premiums will be shared as a fund raiser for LeMoyne Center for the Visual Arts.


What We Need & What You Get

I'm asking $7500.00 to cover great expenses for ink, paper, matting, framing, printing, publicity, payment for models, videographer, hair stylist, costume designer/builder, jeweler, posing consultant, reception, and more. What you get is listed in the perks section.


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help spread the word about my show. Please "share" my posts on Facebook and the IndieGoGo site.

Word of mouth and personal emails would be great.

story:
Our Story

On the 4th of July weekend, 2011, Xingularity first rose from the ground and arched up towards the sky.

It all started as a small sculpture called the Gateless Gate, and a crazy idea that such a thing could be built on a large enough scale to walk through. It was designed in Adobe Illustrator and the pieces cut out with a CNC. Last year, when the 2011 Burning Man theme, "Rites of Passage", was announced, that word "Passage" was a catalyst towards that vision. Robert Bell (creator of Zonotopia) was the other catalyst, as his mind-blowing 2010 playa installation made it all suddenly seem possible.


From Vibrata: "I've been working with a friend who uses a CNC cutter for making commercial signs and such. It was a steep learning curve for me but I loved the resulting sculptures. The inspiration to create something really big and interactive hovered over my head until May, when the call for art proposals for the False Profit Priceless campout was sent out. It was like being shot out of a cannon."


Vibrata and I have created large scale art pieces together at Burning Man before. Our first was the Wind Oracle, a mixed media kinetic installation in 2003, which went back to the playa as well as Decompression 2005. In 2006, I assisted her in creating the Rose Window, the crowning piece of the Connexus Cathedral project. We've also contributed art to previous Priceless campouts; last year with "Past, Present, Future Perfect".


The Priceless campout is held in Belden, California, in a layout that includes a huge dance area with a wooded trail about 100 yards long leading to a small beach. Xingularity was proposed as a passageway that people would walk through to go between the main dance area and the beach. It would create a transition point, and lend a momentousness to the entering and exiting.


Production was swift, from the moment of beginning the design, to finding a new CNC connection in Robert Bell (creator of Zonotopia), to cutting the shapes, painting and transporting to Belden. In the midst of it there were redesigns, a 1/3 scale model was hatched, and a freak rainstorm nearly derailed the final preparations. 


Once in Belden, the pieces were sorted, the volunteers were briefed, and assembly took 4 1/2 hours. Not bad, considering none of us had ever done anything like it before!



...And it was quite spectacular. It was more than a way to get from one area to another, it was a place to stop a talk, a place to dance. Lighting gave the piece an otherworldliness that we couldn't have predicted. The response was overwhelmingly and enthusiastically positive!


We learned a lot in the process. The uneven ground made it challenging to line up the pieces properly. Some of the pieces were damaged during assembly, some by people who thought it was for climbing. We knew that in order to build it on the playa, we would need new lights. The ones we had were gorgeous, but old and unreliable, not to mention heavy on power usage. We also knew that with a bit more money, we could add more pieces and make the structure larger.


It also needed a new name. Originally it was titled, "Priceless Passage". Building it on the playa seemed to warrant a name that doesn't include "Priceless". Vibrata researched a little into ideas around wormholes, those beguiling cosmic entities proposed by physicists as shortcuts through vast areas of spacetime. Tripping through various theories of black holes and singularities, she came upon the term, ring singularity, which refers to a point with infinite density that has a radius, like a ring - unlike a singularity which has virtually no spacial dimensions at all. This lead to "ringularity". Then, because the piece is a passageway, it became Xingularity, from X-ing, or crossing.

The Impact


Bringing Xingularity to the playa means bringing it home to the place it was conceived.

For Priceless, the piece was developed to the maximum potential our bootstrapped-budget would allow. Because the design is modular, adding more pieces will add to the scale and impact of the piece and give it a new symmetry. We're in the process of creating one additional arch, bringing the total to five and expanding it another 4 feet.


Wood may be versatile and strong, but it's not indestructible. The desert dust, wind and sun are cryptonite to Xingularity and it needs protection. So we have painting and varnishing in the works, which will also add depth to the piece by accentuating the shapes and bringing out the natural beauty of the woodgrain.


New low-voltage LED lighting will replace the power-hungry halogens. We'll need additional lights to take into account the expanded size.


We've kept the costs as low as possible, but these expenses are critical. Your donations can help Xingularity grow to its full potential!


What We Need & What You Get

Your donations will pay for some 3/4" plywood made of sustainably harvested pine, sold by a locally owned small lumber company. No Home Depot! Rob Bell will get paid for his indispensable roll as fabricator. Our new LEDs will be paid for. We'll get some suitably durable all-weather varnish and primer.


Hopefully you'll come out to Black Rock City and enjoy Xingularity for yourself! Whether or not you do, you can proudly sport a Xingularity Button, wear the Xingularity design on a custom shirt or decorate something you love with a high-quality vinyl decal. Or get a piece of Vibrata's artwork for yourself in the form of a collectible trading card!


If you're so inclined, the mini Xingularity scale model could really use a home as well! 


Images of all the perks are posted on our Facebook Page..... Go see them, and LIKE us!

Other Ways You Can Help

We would appreciate your cash. But if that's not possible, please help spread the word!

Other Ways You Can Help

story:
Our Story

Patricide is a bi-annual publication featuring work relating to the history and practice of surrealism in art and life. Three editions have been published to date with interest and quality growing with each publication. Issue 4 is a book with an accompanying CD that features work from around the world. Previous editions of Patricide have been sold at a low price in order to ensure wide distribution but this means that the editor has made a financial loss on each issue. We hope that by effectively asking subscribers to pre-order issue 4 via this campaign, we will ensure that Patricide continues to be viable, dynamic and thought-provoking.


The Impact

Previous editions of Patricide have been distributed internationally and sold in the book shops of world-class galleries such as The Tate Modern and ICA in London, The Tate Liverpool and Cornerhouse in Manchester to name but a few. Supporting the publication of issue 4 will ensure the continued publication of Patricide and support the work of surrealist artists and ideas around the world.


What We Need & What You Get

In order to print copies of the next edition of Patricide we need to raise at least £800 and to professionally replicate copies of the accompanying CD with printed covers and labels we need £400. If we raise additional money through this campaign we will then produce more interesting packaging options which will be available in the first limited edition of 200.


Anyone who donates money towards the publication of Patricide will receive perks which could include a copy of this very limited edition book and CD delivered to your home (check the 'perks' section for details). Past editions are now sold out and have become rare, collectible items in their own right. It is quite possible that this new edition will be an investment and will substantially grow in value.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please pass on the word about this using Facebook, e-mail and other sharing tools. If you'd rather pay by UK cheque or currency - e-mail me and I'll let you know the postal address. editor@patricide.co.uk
story_txt:
Our Story
Patricide is a bi-annual publication featuring work relating to the history and practice of surrealism in art and life. Three editions have been published to date with interest and quality growing with each publication. Issue 4 is a book with an accompanying CD that features work from around the world. Previous editions of Patricide have been sold at a low price in order to ensure wide distribution but this means that the editor has made a financial loss on each issue. We hope that by effectively asking subscribers to pre-order issue 4 via this campaign, we will ensure that Patricide continues to be viable, dynamic and thought-provoking.


The Impact
Previous editions of Patricide have been distributed internationally and sold in the book shops of world-class galleries such as The Tate Modern and ICA in London, The Tate Liverpool and Cornerhouse in Manchester to name but a few. Supporting the publication of issue 4 will ensure the continued publication of Patricide and support the work of surrealist artists and ideas around the world.


What We Need & What You Get
In order to print copies of the next edition of Patricide we need to raise at least £800 and to professionally replicate copies of the accompanying CD with printed covers and labels we need £400. If we raise additional money through this campaign we will then produce more interesting packaging options which will be available in the first limited edition of 200.

Anyone who donates money towards the publication of Patricide will receive perks which could include a copy of this very limited edition book and CD delivered to your home (check the 'perks' section for details). Past editions are now sold out and have become rare, collectible items in their own right. It is quite possible that this new edition will be an investment and will substantially grow in value.

Other Ways You Can Help
Please pass on the word about this using Facebook, e-mail and other sharing tools. If you'd rather pay by UK cheque or currency - e-mail me and I'll let you know the postal address. editor@patricide.co.uk

story:
What Are We Even Doing?

Hello and thank you for checking out our fundraising campaign! Our names are Caelen, Maureen, Naomi, Patrick, and Siobhán. We are upper-year students at Concordia University studying Acting for the Theatre. All of us share an immense passion for music and theatre that has led us to collaborating on Carner and Gregor's Island Song, a contemporary musical theatre piece that has become the centrepiece of our independent study.

Why The Heck Would You Teach Yourself?! No Prof?! 

As upper-year students at Concordia, this independent study serves as an opportunity to incorporate musical theatre, a theatrical genre incredibly important to us that is hugely under-represented in our curriculum, into our learning process as students. The focus of this independent study is to develop a refined and practical understanding of musical theatre performance by building on and applying the skills that we have already begun developing at Concordia. Throughout the semester we have been working on the majority of the songs featured in this musical that we will perform in an outcome that will be open to the general public on April 16th (https://www.facebook.com/events/131161567566785...). 

Where Is My $$ Going?

As emerging artists, we feel an enormous responsibility to respect the time and efforts of the artists involved in our project. The process of creating a musical theatre performance is one that is highly collaborative and requires the talents of artists from a variety of disciplines. With this fundraising campaign, we are hoping to earn enough to pay off the rights of the show, fairly compensate our accompanists as well as our vocal coaches, and any of the artists who have invested their time in helping further our project. 

IndieGoGo's minimum fundraising limit is $500 but our goal is raise $400. If we exceed our goal, the excess funds will go towards paying a live band for our performance outcome, costumes and set design, and more sessions with a vocal coach/vocal director.

story:
Hello all!

We are curators, artists, and writers from the MFA programme at Goldsmiths College, and we are working together on a project for the Lewisham ArtHouse. For the past few weeks, we’ve been meeting to discuss what we as a group can do with this space, and we’ve come up with a solution that is collaborative, unsual, dynamic, and a host of other adjectives!

The project is called Kill The Lollipop, which is taken from the drawing game known as 'kill lust lollipop'. It references the communal activity of 'drawing' together, with undetermined outcomes and consequences. We will be installing work over a timetabled exhibition which involves both performance and multimedia installations of all sorts. The exhibition will be in a perpetually state of flux, as artists are asked to create site-specific work which addresses the space as it 'grows'.

Each artist will be given a space on a dedicated day of the exhibition to install work. On the first day of the exhibition (May 7th) the first time-tabled artists will begin to install their work and by the end of the two weeks, all of the participating artists will occupy the space. The last day of the installation (May 20th)will be the end of the exhibition, and will be the culmination of the project. Additionally, performances will be scheduled on various days throughout the two- week event.  A catalogue project will be running alongside this exhibition and will be available at the venue.

We are all very excited about this project because of all its possibilities, but also because it is in a great venue! The Lewisham ArtHouse is in our neighborhood, and is a fantastic community resource. We are thrilled that we are lucky enough to have this space at our disposal, especially since it is in our own backyard.

We need the funding to offset some of the general costs that accompany a show, such as installation tools, promotional materials (catalogues, cards) and the actual space. We are all planning on contributing as well, but any help would be much appreciated. If we manage to raise all the money, it will really allow us to focus more on the project and its potential.

We are all first year students, and this project is an inaugural step for us in terms of working together as a group and across disciplines.

Thanks so much!

story:
A diverse, beautiful place bursting with history and emotion.

A circle of friends loving, and living on an Aegean island.

This is Amorgos, and this is us.

For the past three years talented artists from all over Greece have showcased their creative work, honoring us and our guests with their presence, and bringing life to the island.Our goal for the 4th year of the festival is to encourage more artists to participate. 

All performances take place next to ancient monuments, surrounded by landscapes of rare natural beauty without any complex stage settings.

No one involved in the organization of Asterismos (the Constellation), or any artists, is profiting financially in any way. Everything in this festival is created and offered out of love for the arts and the island.

However,we do need to have a small budget in order to cover the cost of transportation to and within the island, as well as for the accomodations offered to the artists we are hosting.

To this date, these costs were carried solely by a small circle of friends and the help of a few islanders, without any sponsorship or advertising support.

In order to continue the growth of our small, yet unique, festival we would appreciate your support.

Let's Make It Happen!

Ευχαριστούμε! (Thank you!)

story:
Hi!
DEATH CAT has been serious about their music, art & shows here in L.A. for about 2 years.
prior to L.A., the band existed with a different line up in the midwest with past unreliable members.  Now we're in full motion and not stopping.  We love to play music & truly appreciate everyone in our lives who have made our experiences possible.

-ToM Cat

vocals/guitar: ToM Cat
accordion: Spirit Sanctus
drums: Harry Cloud
bass: Ryan Skaggs
synth:demodog-1138
 

We've been working at this tour since January!

We're taking 2 of our own vehicles which get aprox 25mpg.
we're traveling over 6,600 miles.

Being a not so well known under the underground band, there is no guarantee at the venues we play that we will make money.  Merch cost money to make.
We may not have places to stay and need to get motels along the way.


We're Leaving from Los Angeles and looping around through the South to East Coast to the midwest and through Colorado back to L.A.
July 8 PRESCOTT AZ - Gurley Street Coffee

July 9 ALBQ NM - Burt's Tiki Lounge

July 10 Drive Day/middle of Nowhere TX

July 11 AUSTIN TX - Kick Butt Coffee

July 12 HOUSTON TX - White Swan Live

July 13 NOLA - Siberia

July 14 MACON GA - Fresh Produce Records

July 16 BALTIMORE - Positive Force fundraiser

July 17 NYC - Electric Bowery

July 18 NYC - Grand Victory

July 19 CAMBRIDGE MA - Out Of The Blue Too Art Gallery

July 20 PHILLY/PITTSBURG PA

July 21 TOLEDO OH - house show

July 22 DETROIT MI

July 23 HAMTRAMCK MI - The New Dodge

July 24 YPSILANTI MI - house show

July 25 CHICAGO IL - The Mutiny

July 26 CHICAGO IL - Jurassic Park

July 27 LINCOLN NE

July 28 DENVER CO - Rhinoceropolis

July 29 DENVER CO - Lion's Lair

July 30 SANTA FE NM -

July 31 TEMPE AZ - Tempe Tavern

story:
The Talk Shop will be a temporary, experimental cultural center open in Midtown Kansas City for one year.  It will be a vehicle for dialogue by hosting public events at which people will gather to discuss topics that matter in Kansas City, like education, transit or food issues.  


We will have eight six-week programming themes.  These themes will inform scheduled events as well as a certain number of programs that will be planned in response to ideas or issues that arise. The format of the events themselves will be varied, including exhibitions, hosted conversations, meals, or other types of gatherings that we come up with along the way. Overall, we hope to cultivate healthy conversation surrounding public issues in Kansas City by making them interesting, accessible, and enjoyable. The Talk Shop will involve individuals from the Kansas City community and beyond in an effort to both strengthen and diversify our own cultural landscape.


Our choice of venue informs the entire aesthetic of the project.  We intend to design and implement an inviting, collaborative space for individuals from all walks of life.  For this reason, we find it key to be located on Main Street; foot traffic, accessibility and centralization are all key to the format of the project.  We want this project to create a participatory audience that is as diverse as possible.


We see this as an opportunity for cultural exploration. By choosing the main venue as a midtown storefront– a public, accessible, unintimidating environment (as opposed to an art space) –will be able to draw a more diverse crowd. They may not represent typical audiences at art events, and because of this they are valuable contributors and participants within the community.

story:
Chamber of Crafts ist eine Internet Plattform wo Handwerkskünstler aus Rumänien ihre Kunst und Produkte vorstellen können.

Chamber of Crafts ist das geistige Kind von Silvia Stroe, eine gebürtige Rumänin die in Deutschland lebt. Seitdem sie ihre Heimat verlassen hat, haben ihr die Traditionen die man in Rumänien so oft hat gefehlt. Als Silvia noch gehört hat, dass die rumänische Handwerkskünste langsam aussterben, müsste sie was dagegen tun. Sie hat vor zwei Welten, Rumänien und Deutschland, zusammen zu bringen.

So entstand Chamber of Crafts: aus dem Wunsch, Handwerkskünste die vom Aussterben bedroht sind bekannt zu machen und dadurch am Leben zu halten. Silvia kämpft für die Erhaltung von Kulturen und traditionellen Handwerken, für das was sie Kultur-fairen Konsum nennt.

In einer modernen, schnelllebigen und industrialisierten Welt gibt es immer mehr Leute die sich nach Traditionen sehnen und ihre Wurzeln suchen. Chamber of Crafts bietet eine Alternative zu industriellen Produkten für Menschen die mehr Individualität und Produkte mit Tradition in ihrem Leben haben möchten. 

Zur Zeit bietet Chamber of Crafts Keramikobjekten mit hohem Bedeutungsgehalt, bemalt nach jahrhundertealten Maltechniken mit mythischen Motiven, die das spirituelle Leben des Volkes über zwei Jahrtausende erzählen.

 

Was Wir Brauchen & Was Du Bekommst

Damit wir vorankommen, brauchen wir 2000€. Das Geld wird für folgende Dinge gebraucht:

  • Reisefinanzierung zu den abgelegenen Dörfern; Reisedokumentierung
  • Professionelle Fotos von den Produkten als Komponente und Erfolgsfaktor im E-Business
  • Finanzierung des ersten Imports
Wir haben einzigartige Perks für euch vorbereitet: von handbemalten Keramikteller, individualisiert mit euren Namen, bis auf einer geführten Tour im Dacia durch Rumänien zu den Künstlerateliers!

Sei Dabei!

  • Suche Dir einen Perk aus!
  • Sag allen über das Projekt weiter!
  • 'Like' uns auf Facebook und teile unsere Geschichte weiter!

story:
Dear Friends & Family;

 As many of you know, this year I am attending Paul Mitchell the school Charlotte. It's a really great school and it opens up many doors of opportunity. The way they teach is similar to that of Harvard, including the multiple intelligences. I really like the environment and the curriculum, and I am doing really well there! The school is broken down essentially into 3 parts; CORE, a 5 week course on the basics of hair styling and cutting and culture that PM strives to achieve; Prodige, another 5 week course focusing on hands on work with the mannequin and more textbook work; and then finally we move on to the clinic floor and we have clients!! So far, I have completed the first 5 weeks and graduated CORE. This is very exciting for me because I have gotten 100% on all my textbook tests, 100% in attendance, and a 90% on my practical exam (so I've got just enough room to improve before I go to state board to get certified)

Anyways, the reason I wanted to share all this with you is because by October 1st I hope to raise 1500 dollars to go towards my education. As I said, PM offers many opportunities for it's students, and one of them is a 3 day education conference in Las Vegas called Caper. At this three day conference, it will be jam packed with education from platform artists (people who are really good at what they do) including speakers like Jean-Paul DeJoria, the co-owner of Paul Mitchell and also Patron tequila, a very successful business man. So needless to say, this three day conference will be VERY educational for everything to hair design techniques to business and financial advice. You can find a video preview for this event here: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2XqOl5TJ_3Y

So, what does the 1500 dollars go towards? Well, basically, I raise the money, and I bring it to school on the morning of October 1st and I hand it to our receptionist. Then, I am given my Caper ticket, along with $1500 dollars of Paul Mitchell tools and product to sell so I can afford the flight, dinner, and any other expenses I may encounter on those days in Vegas. 

I would really appreciate it if you could donate to my cause, any amount would be appreciated. Like I said, I've been doing really well, and I hope to do just as well once I graduate (Probably around May). This conference looks GREAT on resumes and can help me get my foot into the door I'm hoping to get into (fashion photography). If you would like to donate, you can do so here

Thanks so much, 

Crystal Boland

story:
Houston Art Showcase is a non profit for artists, by artists and artists know what artists need. We need your help making Houston’s art scene more vibrant and more sustainable.

Houston is the third largest city in the U.S. – with a diverse population, strong economic climate and a huge population of working artists. Yet the city has not gained the recognition it deserves in the visual arts.

We have a solution that could help Houston’s art scene rival Chicago, New York and L.A.

The arts could be heavily supported through regular competitions. In this atmosphere, artists would create better art and develop more innovative techniques. The competitive events would also bring more people out to see art.

We recently established Houston Art Showcase a non-profit organization (501c3)– with the mission of providing more opportunities for artists by hosting more art competitions annually. Each competition will recognize winners in various categories. The work will be judged by multiple established artists from around the world. These artists will also critique the work and evaluate the artist’s technique.

Houston Art Showcase is also committed to helping emerging and established artists gain recognition, web presence and social media success. Each artist who participates in events will have work posted online. There will also be a gallery of past winners.
 
A portion of the proceeds from each art competition or live art auction will go to a distinct charity every year.

Your help is needed to fund the competitions and the prizes to be awarded. The funding will also be used to create a free video interview each month, which will feature a different artist. For four art competitions for one year, we estimate a minimum of $25,000 in donations, which would include $3,000 for prizes per competition and the fees for contractors who will help set up and manage the shows, as well as the cost to create the videos.

We have several incentives for those who would like to help:


$15 Houston is art Bumper Sticker (Measures 3x5)

$10 Houston is Art Bracelet

$25 Houston is Art t-shirt

$50 Signed and numbered print of Artist Ambassador: Lindy Chambers

Title: "Who we are" more info on houstonisart.com

story_txt:
Houston Art Showcase is a non profit for artists, by artists and artists know what artists need. We need
your help making Houston’s art scene more vibrant and more sustainable.
Houston
is the third largest city in the U.S. – with a diverse population, strong
economic climate and a huge population of working artists. Yet the city has not
gained the recognition it deserves in the visual arts. 
We have
a solution that could help Houston’s art scene rival Chicago, New York and L.A.

The arts
could be heavily supported through regular competitions. In this atmosphere,
artists would create better art and develop more innovative techniques. The
competitive events would also bring more people out to see art.
We recently established Houston Art Showcase a non-profit organization (501c3)– with the mission of providing more opportunities for artists by hosting more art competitions annually. Each competition will recognize winners in various categories. The work will be judged by multiple established artists from around the world. These artists will also critique the work and evaluate the artist’s technique.
Houston Art Showcase is also committed to helping emerging and
established artists gain recognition, web presence and social media success.
Each artist who participates in events will have work posted online. There will
also be a gallery of past winners.
 
A portion of the proceeds from each art competition or live art auction will go
to a distinct charity every year. 
Your help is needed to fund the competitions and the prizes
to be awarded. The funding will also be used to create a free video interview
each month, which will feature a different artist. For four art competitions
for one year, we estimate a minimum of $25,000 in donations, which would include $3,000 for
prizes per competition and the fees for contractors who will help set up and
manage the shows, as well as the cost to create the videos. 
We have several incentives for those who would like to help:$15 Houston is art Bumper Sticker (Measures 3x5)$10 Houston is Art Bracelet$25 Houston is Art t-shirt$50 Signed and numbered print of Artist Ambassador: Lindy ChambersTitle: "Who we are" more info on houstonisart.com$50 Signed and numbered print of Artist Ambassador: Chandana ParastavuTitle: "Magnolias" more info on original available in houstonisart.com
