story:
THE DIRECTORS

Yasmina Hilal

Born and raised in Lebanon, Yasmina Hilal is a Visual Arts Major with a concentration in Experimental Film and a Minor in Photography. She is in her final year attending Emerson College in Boston. She aims to raise awareness on Social Injustice through different mediums of art. 

"Symptoms is a means of therapy. It has helped me learn ways to manage my symptoms PTSD, which have often taken form in my dreams. My aim with this project is to activate the audience into a dreamlike state through movement, form, texture, and body language." 

Ned Stasio


Originally from the Bay Area in California, Ned Stasio majors in Visual Arts, with an emphasis in Digital Media. They are finishing up their final year at Emerson college. They hope to explore the capacities of media as a tool of discourse.

"Symptoms is, to me, an article of my own experiences learning to navigate PTSD. hold a profound interest in the influences of memes on culture, and have taken great interest in current discourse which utilizes them as a tool of catharsis. By compositing multiple forms of imagery together into a unified work, I hope to explore the aesthetics and healing capacities of memetic structure and function."

THE PRODUCER

Liza Wagner

Liza, a Washington State native, is also finishing up her senior year as a Visual Arts major at Emerson College. She has spent most of her time at Emerson producing student films.

"Ned and Yasmina have brought their own talent and personal history to Symptoms. Helping them bring their vision to fruition, I think, has been cathartic for all of us. It is tough to make something beautiful out of something painful. It's even tougher to do this and broadcast it to the public. The entire process has been incredibly rewarding and I can't wait to see our project's final form."

 

BEHIND THE SCENES

Our principal photography wrapped in October.
Cinematographer; Darren Samuels

 

 


EXHIBITION

Even though we finished all our principal photography, Symptoms is far from wrapped! For our exhibition, we will be constructing a 7" wooden fixture to display the film within. We have teamed up with a constructionist to bring Symptoms to life through a large scale art piece. Here is a rough drawing of what the vision is. 

RAISING FUNDS

We are raising money to cover our budget! This includes crafty to feed our cast and crew, transportation for PD and actors, on screen production design, and most importantly - our grand art installation! That's a lot of wood and a lot of tools; it all ends up relatively fast.

story:
Hello, my name is Connie Herberg and I am an artist (primarily a painter)I living near Shepherd, MT.  I live in a rural area where I have a view of the sunrise and sunset each day.  I am nestled among grain fields and pastures, with commanding views of several mountain ranges, rimrocks and a creek that gurgles through the coulee below the house.  I have always felt part of the landscape and that remains an overarching theme in my work. You can see my work and read more at www.connieherbergfineart.com

I have earned a B.A. in Fine Art with an emphasis on drawing and sculpture.  I believe in the fundamental value of the arts to enhance learning, as a core to our daily needs (who designed your toaster?), and I believe it elevates societal values (make art not war).

I am asking you to help me build an art studio.  It is my dream to have a proper studio working space that not only allows room to work on large paintings, but also provides an adequate space for framing and storage, along with room for an instruction / workshop area.  We have acreage to build an additional garage building on our property and, If you help me raise enough money, I can add a studio onto that building and solve my workspace problems.

My current studio consists of a converted bedroom in my home which only  allows painting space for small projects, this computes to roughly a 6x6 floor area where I can stand to paint and an 7’ ceiling that prohibits my easel extension, thereby limiting my workable canvas sizes.  I share the rest of the overall space with my office, supply storage and a working table for my landscape design projects.  It is more than a bit cramped.  I have had to rent outside space on occasion to complete larger projects.  This is an expense I would rather put into my own property.

My initial need is $40,000.  This phase one will pay for my portion of additional building materials, that will have to be added on to the main building for the framing, concrete, windows and door, electrical, plumbing, and heating.  Basically this will erect the outside shell.  This space will be nothing extravagant, just practical working space where I can hold classes, host small workshops and  individual students. 

“A true artist is not one who is inspired, but one who inspires others”  Salvador Dali

Phase two will finish the project after the shell is erected, I will have approximately another $35,000 need to sheet rock and paint, add trim and light fixtures, flooring, cabinets, countertops and a work table.  This will make a solid workable space with no frills.  My husband and I will supply as much of the labor as we reasonably can.  This includes some of the work needed to erect interior walls, sheetrock, paint, trim and whatever else we can manage.  I will put that into a separate campaign unless the need is met here.

I work daily with dedication in my current studio and am fully committed to my chosen career.  I am equally adept at the business and marketing end of art as well as the framing, matting, stretcher building, packing and multitude of other responsibilities that go along with this career.   To put it in a nutshell, I’m the whole dog and pony show.  

This additional space will not only allow me more elbow room, but provide the possibility of added revenue through workshops, classes and students.  An artist’s life is not a steady paycheck.  The sale of artwork is sporadic at best and more often than not, the available unsold inventory is ten times the annual revenue.  Teaching allows a steadier income stream with lower overhead and fills in the income gaps.  

I have only 30 days to raise this phase of revenue, so I’m asking for your immediate consideration,

Donate today and you will receive a really great perk (remember to supply your mailing address if you wish to receive your perk):

Perks range from a thank you, note cards, book, original small paintings framed and unframed, to a large “Montana Trilogy” triptych (each panel 3.5’w x 6.5’ h) + personal thank you + signed book + original design note cards.

If I don’t reach my goal on phase one of this project, the money raised will still go toward the building of the studio, as far as it will reach.  I hope you will find that I am not asking for something for nothing.  I wasn’t raised to take without repayment.  I think you will find that the perks are substantial. 

Please share this campaign on your Facebook or Twitter account using the Indiegogo share tools.  Remember, www.connieherbergfineart.com for more information and to view my artwork.  Thanks for your time and consideration.  I will keep you posted on the progress on Indieigogo and through my Facebook page.

story:
Welcome to the BLOOM 2016 Calendar IndieGoGo page!

The BLOOM 2015 Calendar was met with beautiful success! Thank you so much to those who contributed last year. If you missed out, here's your chance to help fund the project and reserve your calendar at the same time!

The calendar itself features: 

  • 12 fully illustrated calendar pages (Jan 2016-Dec 2016). This year, I've worked to incorporate my evolving art style, making each month more detailed and more vibrant, yet keeping the same clean simplicity that made BLOOM 2015 so dang cute. 
  • A super awesome fully illustrated cover/info page with a lovingly/painstakingly hand bound spine
  • 365 bursts of positivity and inspiration with quotes to get you through the week and year. 
  • Calendars measure 7.25 in x 5.25 in closed and 7.25 in x 10.5 in open.


WHY TO SUPPORT THE CAMPAIGN:

Last year, I ran a limited print of 50 copies (based on the response I got on the IndieGoGo page). Yet after the print ran out, there were still many requests for more! By supporting the campaign, not only do you reserve your copy of the calendar, but receive thank you gifts for pre-order! Backers will receive their calendars before they will be available to be sold to the public. Please note that after all of the backers have had their perks delivered, whatever calendars are left will be available for sale to the general public. This is why you should reserve your copy NOW!

You can still reserve a copy through the IndieGoGo page AFTER I have met my fundraising goal - but you have to do it before the campaign is over! After all of the orders are placed I will use that to determine the final order quantity and round up a couple for those who didn't order online! So do it! Back the page! Thanks!

WHO I AM:

I'm Mary, the illustrator for the BLOOM 2016 Calendar. I've been illustrating and creating work for over year (professionally) and I have been thinking really hard about the best way to share some of my artwork with friends and family! It finally occurred to me that others might be interested, too! 

For more of my work, check out maryvertulfo.com!

This calendar not only represents me as an artist, but BLOOM is the first and ONLY product I have available to the open market. I have put blood, sweat, tears and plenty of sparkles and rainbows into this calendar so I really hope you all enjoy it!


Check out last year's Calendar here! http://www.maryvertulfo.com/bloom-florals/

story:
International Artist Residency

Hello, my name is Michael H Thomas, and I'm an Artist based out of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania. I want you to imagine an opportunity for yourself, where you are chosen to attend a residency where you are allowed to do what you love and do best freely for two weeks. The only draw back is that the residency requires you to pay their fees to attend. Missing this opportunity that could grow your career only because you do not have the funds, would be very upsetting. Now you see what my issue is. If the campaign is successful, I will be able to create art and grow as an artist! Not only will I grow as an artist, but it will also help open other opportunities later on when it is seen that I have attended an International Residency on my resume. With that considered, any contribution would greatly help me and my career as an artist.

This campaign will require $5000 dollars to be successful. The residency requires me to provide $2200 for their fees. Beyond their fees, I will not be able to take my personal art supplies to France with me. Art supplies are very expensive and will add up fast. For example, oil paint could add up to $500, assuming the price is comparable to what it is in the United States. Additionally, I will need to buy supplies to create my painting surfaces, brushes, a pallet, and other tools.  

Now, I know what you are thinking; is this campaign safe? Honestly, I can say this is the safest campaign on Indiegogo! I am a seasoned artist who has been creating art for more than 15 years. Also, while I am in France, I will be posting videos and photos of all my paintings on all of my social media so you can literally see what this campaign is benefiting. As added comfort, I have my Bachelor's and Master's in Fine Arts. The time spent with this residency will be valuable to me because it will allow me to expand my knowledge and experience in the arts. This opportunity is not just something I want, but something I absolutely need. 

Want some Perks?? I promise for the first ten contributors who donate $100 or more, I will create a drawing that will be displayed on my Instagram page with you tagged in it!  Also, while I am in France, I will be posting videos of myself painting and posting everything I am doing. 

Overall, I do want to reiterate how important this residency is to me. This opportunity is everything I have been trying to achieve for the last 5 years. It is an opportunity that will open many doors for me later in my career. Please help me take this once in a life time opportunity!

Thanks!

story:
Short Summary

In September 2010 I started this epic journey over land to India I left with about 3000kr (about 400 Euroes) in the bank, but with friends, instruments, pens and paper, we made it through 22 countries, by music, art and living on minimum budgets and not the least, by the help of hundreds of amazing people along the way. The goal; Living and Learning.

Now I am at the end of my trip and those 3000kr in the bank is finally basically gone and I am ready to ask for one last big hand from you!
This trip has been an incredible learning process, it has shown us nature, life and humanity at it's highest and it's lowest. I have seen more and learned more than I thought I would. My idea is now to go home and write a book and make an art exhibition, to share with all, and for myself to understand all I've seen and learned so far. The journey of life is not over, but for the moment. I am ready to go home!

What I Need & What You Get

For 300$ I will be able to afford a flight ticket to Istanbul, Turkey and can then hitchhike my way from there in a few days to Denmark.

For 400$ I will be able to purchase a flight ticket all the way to Copenhagen.

For 600$ I will be able to fly home and survive without bigger problems the last weeks in India (right now I am selling stickers to pay for my food)

For 700$ I will be able to fly home, survive in India and have a little bit to fall on when I come to Denmark without any income or a place to live.

For 1000$ I will be able to do the above and also have some breathing space to live my dream of writing a book and make an exhibition about my journey! In this way I will be able to give more back!

 

What I can give you in direct thanks for your help, is my art, as has helped me survive so far and that I hope I will be able to live of in the future as well.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

You will helpe me a lot by spreading the word and share my campain with friends and family or people you think might be interested!
Also if you have any ideas of free spaces to stay and write and do artwork, either in Denmark or England or anywhere in the World really, it would be a lot of help to me!
 
Thank you so much, your help is moslty appreciated!

story:
Udate:  7/27/2015

We are so grateful to our funders for helping us reach $70K.  Thank you!  
~ Dreamers Guild


Update: 6/18/2015

Our campaign is now "InDemand" which means we can continue to accept your gracious donations even though our deadline has passed. For a short time, we will continue to offer our popular perks with each new donation. Get them while you can!

Please see our website www.templeofpromise.org/donate for more ways to help us bring the Temple of Promise to the playa this year and warm thanks to all of you who have helped us thus far.


Update: 6/17/2015

We are deeply grateful to each of you who donated to the Temple of Promise and helped us reach our goal for this campaign! We're also grateful that many of you are continuing to give - every additional dollar is just as helpful. Our Burning Man grant covered 25% of our total budget and this IndieGoGo campaign covered another good chunk of what we need. Thank you for making this happen! 

There are lots of exciting ways we're planning to raise our remaining funds. In July, we're working on a dance party in L.A. and San Francisco. We're also trying to reach donors with much deeper pockets who may be able to sponsor entire portions of our project, such as the creation of our trees which will cost around $17,500 each, for example. Someone could also purchase the trees outright and place them outside their business or home as they will survive the ritual fire and will be a memorable art piece for years to come. So keep an eye out for our upcoming campaign for The Grove.

Your efforts here helped us complete and surpass this particular goal. Without your help here, we'd have a significant gap that would be even more difficult to fill. Thank you, deeply, for each dollar you gave and if you continue to give here past our deadline, IndieGoGo will continue to send us the funds. We can't wait to welcome you to the Temple of Promise on playa this year <3.


Update: 6/14/2015

Yesterday one of the trees from the Temple grove made a guest appearance at the DISTRIKT REVEL Station party.  

We've pulled together this video of how the trees are being constructed by Artist Kevin Byall.  



UPDATE 6/10/2015

A few weeks ago, Temple of Promise artist Jazz Tigan was invited to speak at the Desert Arts Preview in San Francisco. His story makes a powerful connection between the Temples of Burning Man and events surrounding the aftermath of 9/11. With this, we are reminded of what a special place it is that we're creating, this Temple of Promise.

Please have a listen for yourself.



UPDATE 6/4/2015

The build site is buzzing with activity.  Check out our progress! 


The Temple

A tradition at Burning Man since 2000, the Temple serves as Black Rock City's spiritual nexus – a  contemplative space of reflection, solace, celebration, bereavement, communion, and release. This year we need your support to make the Temple of Promise a reality.


Temple of Promise begins with an immense skyward-reaching spire, clad entirely in shimmering copper. As you move deeper into the gently curving structure you pass beneath a progression of delicate archways which gradually descend to a decidedly human scale. When you pass through the final archway you emerge into an encircled grove of sculpted trees.

 


In the beginning, the trees stand empty and exposed. Visitors will leave messages of remembrance on lengths of cloth, tying them to the branches. In this way, as the days pass, the trees will come into full bloom and take on the shape of weeping willows.

The Temple lives for only one week. In this brief moment it serves as a spiritual vessel, receiving everything that is brought to it. On the last night, every memento, every joyous moment, and every tear is released when the Temple is burned to ash.


What We Need

The Burning Man Project provides the initial seed funds for the Temple through an honorarium grant, but most of the funding comes from the generosity of the community. The cost of building, transporting, and burning such a large structure is considerable and this campaign represents only a fraction of what is required.

Architectural Drawings of the Temple arches   


Please join us in building this temple together. Volunteer through our website, TempleofPromise.org. Reach out to us on Facebook and share your stories. Join 
us on the island of Alameda, California  to help us build this sanctuary, the
Temple of Promise.

Most of all, please consider making a donation to the Temple of Promise.  

- The Dreamers Guild




The Dreamers Guild is a collective of (mostly) San Francisco Bay Area artists, builders, caretakers and dreamers who have come together to create the Temple of Promise for Burning Man 2015.  You can reach us by email at donations@templeofpromise.org.

Woodshop and Ilo prototyping the arches

Dan Swain (Architectural Lead), Jason "Woodshop" DeCook (Build Lead), and Todd Evans (Project Manager) standing under the first of many arches to be constructed at the build site in Alameda, California.

Jazz Tigan (Promise Artist) is a designer, inventor and entrepreneur. 
This is his first large-scale art project for Burning Man.
UPDATE:  Some photos from our recent build day featuring our amazing volunteers.



The Dreamers Guild would like to thank The Burning Man Project for their support of the Temple of Promise.

story:
What is SPRED?

Spred is an intermittent print and online art zine. It is a submission  based zine and each issue will follow a different theme. We encourage a variety of people to submit their art work and we encourage not just 'artists' to submit, but anyone who feels inspired to create. We accept any kind of artwork that can be displayed on a page. This includes, but is not limited to: drawings, paintings, collage, doodles, design, poetry, short stories, illustration, photography, sculpture, jewelry and glass. Although our zine is based in Philadelphia, we encouraged people to submit from all over the U.S. and plan to distribute the zine in different cities. The launch of our first zine will culminate with a zine launch party and art show at Nice Things Handmade, a local handmade art boutique and gallery.

Spred is created by Naima Merella and Tina Mukherjee, two artists who met in college. We initially decided to create this zine after noticing how little artwork people created after they graduated from school and real life hit. However, after we began to work on the zine it blossomed into so much more.


Motivation to Create & Building Community 

Spred was created to motivate people to create art for fun! Spred is a platform where this artwork can live and be viewed by a variety of people, hopefully inspiring more people to create art and support the arts. Allowing more people to understand the importance of expressing themselves creatively and witnessing all the positive effects of personal expression. We feel this is so needed in a country where generally artists and creating art is not very valued. 

Spred was also created as a way to build a community of people who enjoy art with people who enjoy creating art. In addition to offering our print and online zine Spred will host events such as art shows, art parties and critiques.



FREEdom 

We want Spred to be a free zine, this way money will not be an obstacle for anyone submitting artwork or anyone who wants to look at the zine. This gives people more incentive to create artwork and to look at the artwork in the zine. Ultimatley allowing our contributors to get more exposure and hopefully to inspire that many more people to create art. 

In order to print a CMYK color zine we need to raise $2,200. This will allow us to print 500 copies of a 40 page mini zine. Our dream goal is to raise $2,500 so that we can print 1000 copies of a 40 page zine. 

If we don't reach our goal we will be forced to find a cheaper printer or even print the zine in black and white, which would take away from most of the amazing artwork we received. Any extra money will go toward promo materials for the zine and art show.

PERKS!

$5 - Digital download of the zine 

$10 - Digital download and Spred sticker 

$20 - A copy of Spred zine and sticker mailed to your home, as well as digital download 

$35 - 2 copies of Spred zine and sticker,mailed to your home, as well as, a digital download 

$50 - A copy of Spred zine and a print of an image from the zine, mailed to your home

$75 - A copy of Spred zine and two prints from images in the zine, mailed to your home

$100 - A copy of Spred zine and a framed print of an image from the zine, mailed to your home

$200 - A copy of Spred zine and 2 framed prints of images from the zine, mailed to your home

$500 - A copy of Spred zine and an original artwork by Naima or Tina

$1,000 - A copy of Spred zine and a custom artwork by Naima or Tina

**All Contributors who donate $100 or more will receive a special thank you in Spred zine.  


Risks & Challenges

Our biggest risk right now is not raising enough money to print the zine and having to cancel the zine and art show. Another big challenge for us was finding an affordable printing company that would also produce a good quality zine. We did not want to compromise quality for the cost of printing because as artists we know presentation is so important and can completely change the way a viewer sees and interprets a work of art. As this is our first zine it has been a lot of trial and error a long with a ton of hard work. 
We are confident in the support that we will receive from friends, family and our art community, as well as, the support of those patron saints of the arts.  


Other Ways You Can Help

MAKE MORE ART! Encourage others to make more art and submit to our zine. In the end this zine is really about encouraging people to express themselves creatively and having a safe space for people to exhibit what they create. As artists we understand the profound effects of creating and sharing artwork. For us creative expression is a necessary and essential part of being alive. We hope to help others cultivate this passion in their lives. 


Upcoming zine cover

Here are some of the artworks submitted by our wonderful contributors!

- Cory Espinosa

- Hannah Shimabukuro

- Miguel Co

story:
EN 

(versione in italiano sotto)

What

Raw to the Surface is the last step through my Master experience. With it I want to place myself in the contemporary photography discourse suggesting a new approach and escaping from the bidimentional and digital displays to connect my pictures to the viewer in a more intimate, shaking way. 

Social media as Instagram taught us to look at images as a sort of flow on the screen, now Snapchat and Instagram Stories are increasing this disconnection between visual material and personal involvement, making the time we devote to an image decrease to less than a second.

Raw to the Surface wants to invert this tendency, re-starting from the body, allowing time, but letting the power to the viewer. 

The project will involve various works devoted to the exploration  of the limit between inside and outside of the body, including a series of interactive and tactile pictures that the visitor will be able to touch and even modify during a one-night-performance and opening that will take place at 71a Gallery, Shoreditch, on the 1st December. The exhibition will then be open during the weekend to experience the work and see the changes caused by previous visitors. 

The project is enriched by collaborations with artists and designers who share the interest for skin, embodiment and new display modes, including: Mark Goldby, who will be part of the exhibition with a collaborative project created ad hoc, Fiona Faumuina, Abi Skinner, Manuela Menzi, Paula Q. Yu.

 

Why support?

I believe in the importance of physicality, of experiencing things on one’s skin. In a time where the sense of touch is more and more connected to a screen and the consciousness of one’s body pass through a phone camera I feel the urge to provoke the viewer through an interactive experience to get lost inside the body, challenging the perception and view of the female body as flesh and skin. 

During my MA I have experimented with new materials and new displays to create a different discourse about photography and fashion. Unfortunately, most of the times many good ideas had to be reviewed and resized because of a small budget.

I feel that this time it's important to push this project forward and give it the chance to become something bigger. I feel that many people would love to finally be able to touch a picture or an artwork in a gallery space, to interact with the objects they see and experience a new way to rapport to photography. It's a new approach, that in my opinion deserves to come to life. If you feel the same, if you are tired of pictures on a screen and digital bodies without wrinkles, folds or imperfections, please support Raw to the Surface!

 

How

My team and I are working for free to produce the final pictures, as I usually create a fashion editorial as well as my personal pictures on each session, to offer them a publication on a magazine and new pictures for their portfolios as a compensation for their time and help. 

Nonetheless, the production of the final pictures require tests and experimental printing processes, to find the best materials and display methods to fit the idea. 

Moreover as the project is thought as interactive I am planning to host a three days exhibition at the Gallery 71A in Shoreditch, between the 1st and the 3rd December, with an opening night-performance in which the visitors will be able to see and interact with the works.

The money raised thanks to your contributions will help me covering the expenses of testing, printing and exhibiting my work.

Of the £2000:

£750 will cover the venue hire,

£350 will cover the promotion and the realisation of the opening night (flyers, posters, staffing for the night at the bar, security, video-maker to film the interaction with the works) , 

£500 will cover the tests and printing,

£300 will cover the production of a final catalogue including the pictures of all the works realised for the exhibition, stills of the opening night and of the results of the interaction of the public with the works,

£100 will cover the Indiegogo costs.

If you are starting to figure how Raw to the Surface could look and you are curious to see the final result you can support the project with as much as you wish! Every donation matters!  Have a look at the perks available that include prints, portrait sessions, personalised darkroom prints and much more! 

Reaching the goal would be really important to give to this project its best chance and look, but even in case the goal is not reached all the funds collected will be used for the realisation of the prints and the exhibition, reviewing the budget and eventually trimming down the copies of the final catalogue and the opening night expenses. 

 

Afraid?

Thinking about an exhibition while the work to be exhibited is still in production is a big challenge. It requires a lot of steady nerves and good organisation skills. I believe I have these features, and even if the time is not much most of the work is already done and the more I'm experimenting on the display options, the more I can't wait to have this project exhibited in a space. All my works are always thought as exhibited but rarely I have the chance to produce an entire body of work knowing the space where it will be and being able to imagine how the whole thing will look like. 

The interactive choice requires as well a good amount of courage. I am giving my pictures in the hands of the viewers, presenting months of hard work and giving the chance to destroy it. I am basically undressing together with my pictures, and I really hope that you all will be able to be part of this experience and get something home from it.   

 

Other Ways You Can Help

I know that not everybody can afford to support an art project and I am well aware that there are many, many important causes and difficult situations around the world that require economic support.

If you don't feel to donate money for this project please help it grow anyway by supporting and sharing the event on social media and word of mouth (here the Facebook event)! Talk to each other and come to the opening night to have a look and meet me and all the people involved!

 

IT

 

Cos'è?

Raw to the Surface è l'ultimo passo che mi porta alla conclusione del Master. Con questo progetto desidero posizionare il mio lavoro all'interno del panorama della fotografia contemporanea, cercando di suggerire un approccio differente, che si discosti dalla bidimensionalità e dal digitale ed attraverso il quale lo spettatore possa interagire in maniera più intima. 

Social Media come Instagram ci hanno insegnato a guardare le immagini seguendo un flusso che scorre sullo schermo. Ora Snapchat ed Instagram Stories stanno incrementando sempre più la distanza tra materiale visivo e fruitore, facendo precipitare il tempo che dedichiamo ad un'immagine a meno di un secondo. 

Raw to the Surface vuole invertire questa tendenza, ripartendo dalla fisicità del corpo, concedendo più tempo, ma mantenendo il controllo nelle mani dello spettatore.

Il progetto comprenderà vari lavori volti all'esplorazione del limite tra interno ed esterno del corpo, compresa una serie  di stampe tattili che il pubblico potrà manipolare durante la serata di apertura - performance il 1º Dicembre, alla 71A Gallery. 

La mostra rimarrà poi aperta fino al 3 Dicembre per permettere di scoprire come le foto sono state modificate durante la serata. 

Il progetto è inoltre arricchito da collaborazioni con artisti e designer che condividono l'interesse per la pelle, la fisicità del corpo e la ricerca su nuovi metodi di esposizione. Tra questi Mark Goldby, presente all'interno della mostra con un lavoro realizzato a quattro mani; Fiona Faumuina, Abi Skinner, Manuela Menzi, Paula Q. Yu.

 

Perché sostenere il progetto?

Credo sia importante riscoprire la materialità del corpo umano, e con essa la capacità di sperimentare sulla propria pelle. In un tempo in cui il tatto è per lo più legato ad uno schermo ed in cui la coscienza di sé passa attraverso la camera di uno smartphone credo sia necessario provocare lo spettatore attraverso un'esperienza interattiva che metta in discussione la percezione del corpo, per scuoterlo e farlo perdere nei meandri di pelle, carne e rughe.

Durante il master ho sperimentato diversi materiali e forme espositive per cercare di smuovere l'idea di fotografia, moda e fotografia di moda. Sfortunatamente, molte volte buone idee sono state accantonate o ridimensionate a causa di un budget ristretto.

Credo sia arrivato il momento di spingere questo progetto al massimo per dargli la possibilità di diventare qualcosa di davvero grande. Scommetto che molte persone non vedono l'ora di poter finalmente toccare un oggetto in mostra, che normalmente è visto e vissuto con un certo timore reverenziale. Si tratta di un approccio diverso, che vuole mettere in discussione l'approccio tattile che si ha con le foto sullo schermo, trasportandolo in un contesto analogico. La prossima volta che siete su un social network fermatevi per un secondo e cercate di ricordare la penultima immagine passata a schermo. È molto difficile, perché non si guarda più niente, lo sguardo scorre e non si fissa. Il tatto può aiutare a concentrarsi nuovamente su quello che si ha sotto gli occhi e sotto le mani. 
Supportando Raw to the Surface  aiuterete a dar vita ad un'esperienza interattiva, che porta in mostra corpi veri, con pelle, rughe e lentiggini, che parlano dell'essere umano, da toccare, manipolare e ricordare. 

 

Come 

Tutte le persone coinvolte nel progetto stanno lavorando gratis alla produzione delle fotografie finali. Sto cercando di offrire sempre la produzione di un editoriale moda in parallelo ai miei scatti personali, in modo da dare al team una pubblicazione o nuove foto per il loro portfolio come ricompensa per il loro tempo ed aiuto.

Ciò nonostante la produzione delle immagini finali richiede test pratici e svariati esperimenti di stampa per trovare i materiali più adatti e le modalità di esposizione migliori. Inoltre, essendo il progetto pensato come interattivo, sto organizzando una mostra dal 1º al 3 Dicembre alla 71A Gallery con una serata di apertura-performance il 1º Dicembre durante la quale gli spettatori avranno la possibilità di vedere, toccare e manipolare le foto esposte. 

I fondi raccolti attraverso questa campagna mi permetteranno di coprire le spese dei test di stampa, delle stampe finali, della galleria, della opening night e di un catalogo finale che raccolga gli scatti in mostra e la documentazione della serata interattiva.

Dei £2000:

£750 andranno a coprire i costi della galleria;

£350 copriranno la promozione e realizzazione della serata di apertura (volantini, poster, staff per la serata, sicurezza, video-maker per filmare l'interazione con le opere);

£500 saranno destinati a test e stampe finali;

£300 alla produzione del catalogo finale;

£100 copriranno le spese della piattaforma Indiegogo

Se state cominciando ad immaginare come Raw to the Surface potrebbe essere e siete curiosi di vedere il risultato finale potete supportare il progetto con quanto volete. È inoltre possibile fare un'offerta per uno dei "perk", ossia piccoli ringraziamenti materiali che posso offrire in cambio della vostra generosità. Tra questi stampe, ritratti fotografici ad hoc, stampe personalizzate in camera oscura e molto altro!

Raggiungere l'obiettivo di £2000 sarebbe davvero importante per dare a questo progetto la migliore chance possibile ma nel caso l'obiettivo non venga raggiunto tutti i fondi saranno comunque utilizzati per la creazione della mostra, revisionando il budget ed eventualmente tagliando sulle copie del catalogo finale e sulle spese per la serata di performance.

 

Paura?

Pensare ad una mostra mentre i lavori da esporre sono ancora in fase di lavorazione non è cosa da poco. Richiede nervi saldi ed un grande spirito organizzativo, dote che fortunatamente ritengo di avere. Anche se il tempo è poco gran parte del lavoro è terminato e più faccio esperimenti per le stampe finali più non sto nella pelle di vedere il tutto nello spazio espositivo. 

Tutti i miei lavori sono pensati nello spazio, ma raramente ho la possibilità di produrre un lavoro importante e ramificato immaginandolo direttamente all'interno di uno spazio preciso. Questo è un grande vantaggio, che mi permette di lavorare direttamente in vista dell'esperienza in galleria. 

La scelta della mostra interattiva richiede altrettanti nervi saldi e coraggio. Sto dando le mie fotografie nelle mani dello spettatore, presentando mesi e mesi di lavoro e dando la possibilità di distruggerne completamente il risultato. Diciamo che in qualche misura mi spoglio insieme alle mie foto, e spero davvero che tutti i presenti tornino a casa arricchiti da questa esperienza inusuale. 

 

Altri modi per supportare il progetto

So che non tutti hanno la possibilità di supportare un progetto d'arte e sono ben consapevole della presenza di numerose altre cause in giro per il mondo, più serie e più importanti, che vale la pena di supportare economicamente. 

Se non ve la sentite di donare per questo progetto per favore aiutate a diffondere la voce condividendo l'evento Facebook e la mostra su altri social media e al bar davanti ad una birra. Grazie a tutti coloro che parteciperanno dall'Italia e spero di poter raccogliere tanto materiale da poter mostrare a chi non potrà essere presente alla performance. Per tutti gli altri: ci vediamo il 1º Dicembre alla 71A Gallery!
story_txt:
EN 
(versione in italiano sotto)
What
Raw to the Surface is the last step through my Master experience. With it I want to place myself in the contemporary photography discourse suggesting a new approach and escaping from the bidimentional and digital displays to connect my pictures to the viewer in a more intimate, shaking way. 
Social media as Instagram taught us to look at images as a sort of flow on the screen, now Snapchat and Instagram Stories are increasing this disconnection between visual material and personal involvement, making the time we devote to an image decrease to less than a second.
Raw to the Surface wants to invert this tendency, re-starting from the body, allowing time, but letting the power to the viewer. 
The project will involve various works devoted to the exploration  of the limit between inside and outside of the body, including a series of interactive and tactile pictures that the visitor will be able to touch and even modify during a one-night-performance and opening that will take place at 71a Gallery, Shoreditch, on the 1st December. The exhibition will then be open during the weekend to experience the work and see the changes caused by previous visitors. 
The project is enriched by collaborations with artists and designers who share the interest for skin, embodiment and new display modes, including: Mark Goldby, who will be part of the exhibition with a collaborative project created ad hoc, Fiona Faumuina, Abi Skinner, Manuela Menzi, Paula Q. Yu.
 

Why support?
I believe in the importance of physicality, of experiencing things on one’s skin. In a time where the sense of touch is more and more connected to a screen and the consciousness of one’s body pass through a phone camera I feel the urge to provoke the viewer through an interactive experience to get lost inside the body, challenging the perception and view of the female body as flesh and skin. 
During my MA I have experimented with new materials and new displays to create a different discourse about photography and fashion. Unfortunately, most of the times many good ideas had to be reviewed and resized because of a small budget.
I feel that this time it's important to push this project forward and give it the chance to become something bigger. I feel that many people would love to finally be able to touch a picture or an artwork in a gallery space, to interact with the objects they see and experience a new way to rapport to photography. It's a new approach, that in my opinion deserves to come to life. If you feel the same, if you are tired of pictures on a screen and digital bodies without wrinkles, folds or imperfections, please support Raw to the Surface!
 
How
My team and I are working for free to produce the final pictures, as I usually create a fashion editorial as well as my personal pictures on each session, to offer them a publication on a magazine and new pictures for their portfolios as a compensation for their time and help. 
Nonetheless, the production of the final pictures require tests and experimental printing processes, to find the best materials and display methods to fit the idea. 
Moreover as the project is thought as interactive I am planning to host a three days exhibition at the Gallery 71A in Shoreditch, between the 1st and the 3rd December, with an opening night-performance in which the visitors will be able to see and interact with the works.
The money raised thanks to your contributions will help me covering the expenses of testing, printing and exhibiting my work.
Of the £2000:
£750 will cover the venue hire,
£350 will cover the promotion and the realisation of the opening night (flyers, posters, staffing for the night at the bar, security, video-maker to film the interaction with the works) , 
£500 will cover the tests and printing,
£300 will cover the production of a final catalogue including the pictures of all the works realised for the exhibition, stills of the opening night and of the results of the interaction of the public with the works,
£100 will cover the Indiegogo costs.
If you are starting to figure how Raw to the Surface could look and you are curious to see the final result you can support the project with as much as you wish! Every donation matters!  Have a look at the perks available that include prints, portrait sessions, personalised darkroom prints and much more! 
Reaching the goal would be really important to give to this project its best chance and look, but even in case the goal is not reached all the funds collected will be used for the realisation of the prints and the exhibition, reviewing the budget and eventually trimming down the copies of the final catalogue and the opening night expenses. 
 
Afraid?
Thinking about an exhibition while the work to be exhibited is still in production is a big challenge. It requires a lot of steady nerves and good organisation skills. I believe I have these features, and even if the time is not much most of the work is already done and the more I'm experimenting on the display options, the more I can't wait to have this project exhibited in a space. All my works are always thought as exhibited but rarely I have the chance to produce an entire body of work knowing the space where it will be and being able to imagine how the whole thing will look like. 
The interactive choice requires as well a good amount of courage. I am giving my pictures in the hands of the viewers, presenting months of hard work and giving the chance to destroy it. I am basically undressing together with my pictures, and I really hope that you all will be able to be part of this experience and get something home from it.   
 

Other Ways You Can Help
I know that not everybody can afford to support an art project and I am well aware that there are many, many important causes and difficult situations around the world that require economic support.
If you don't feel to donate money for this project please help it grow anyway by supporting and sharing the event on social media and word of mouth (here the Facebook event)! Talk to each other and come to the opening night to have a look and meet me and all the people involved!

 
IT
 
Cos'è?
Raw to the Surface è l'ultimo passo che mi porta alla conclusione del Master. Con questo progetto desidero posizionare il mio lavoro all'interno del panorama della fotografia contemporanea, cercando di suggerire un approccio differente, che si discosti dalla bidimensionalità e dal digitale ed attraverso il quale lo spettatore possa interagire in maniera più intima. 
Social Media come Instagram ci hanno insegnato a guardare le immagini seguendo un flusso che scorre sullo schermo. Ora Snapchat ed Instagram Stories stanno incrementando sempre più la distanza tra materiale visivo e fruitore, facendo precipitare il tempo che dedichiamo ad un'immagine a meno di un secondo. 
Raw to the Surface vuole invertire questa tendenza, ripartendo dalla fisicità del corpo, concedendo più tempo, ma mantenendo il controllo nelle mani dello spettatore.
Il progetto comprenderà vari lavori volti all'esplorazione del limite tra interno ed esterno del corpo, compresa una serie  di stampe tattili che il pubblico potrà manipolare durante la serata di apertura - performance il 1º Dicembre, alla 71A Gallery. 
La mostra rimarrà poi aperta fino al 3 Dicembre per permettere di scoprire come le foto sono state modificate durante la serata. 
Il progetto è inoltre arricchito da collaborazioni con artisti e designer che condividono l'interesse per la pelle, la fisicità del corpo e la ricerca su nuovi metodi di esposizione. Tra questi Mark Goldby, presente all'interno della mostra con un lavoro realizzato a quattro mani; Fiona Faumuina, Abi Skinner, Manuela Menzi, Paula Q. Yu.
 
Perché sostenere il progetto?
Credo sia importante riscoprire la materialità del corpo umano, e con essa la capacità di sperimentare sulla propria pelle. In un tempo in cui il tatto è per lo più legato ad uno schermo ed in cui la coscienza di sé passa attraverso la camera di uno smartphone credo sia necessario provocare lo spettatore attraverso un'esperienza interattiva che metta in discussione la percezione del corpo, per scuoterlo e farlo perdere nei meandri di pelle, carne e rughe.
Durante il master ho sperimentato diversi materiali e forme espositive per cercare di smuovere l'idea di fotografia, moda e fotografia di moda. Sfortunatamente, molte volte buone idee sono state accantonate o ridimensionate a causa di un budget ristretto.
Credo sia arrivato il momento di spingere questo progetto al massimo per dargli la possibilità di diventare qualcosa di davvero grande. Scommetto che molte persone non vedono l'ora di poter finalmente toccare un oggetto in mostra, che normalmente è visto e vissuto con un certo timore reverenziale. Si tratta di un approccio diverso, che vuole mettere in discussione l'approccio tattile che si ha con le foto sullo schermo, trasportandolo in un contesto analogico. La prossima volta che siete su un social network fermatevi per un secondo e cercate di ricordare la penultima immagine passata a schermo. È molto difficile, perché non si guarda più niente, lo sguardo scorre e non si fissa. Il tatto può aiutare a concentrarsi nuovamente su quello che si ha sotto gli occhi e sotto le mani. Supportando Raw to the Surface  aiuterete a dar vita ad un'esperienza interattiva, che porta in mostra corpi veri, con pelle, rughe e lentiggini, che parlano dell'essere umano, da toccare, manipolare e ricordare. 
 
Come 
Tutte le persone coinvolte nel progetto stanno lavorando gratis alla produzione delle fotografie finali. Sto cercando di offrire sempre la produzione di un editoriale moda in parallelo ai miei scatti personali, in modo da dare al team una pubblicazione o nuove foto per il loro portfolio come ricompensa per il loro tempo ed aiuto.
Ciò nonostante la produzione delle immagini finali richiede test pratici e svariati esperimenti di stampa per trovare i materiali più adatti e le modalità di esposizione migliori. Inoltre, essendo il progetto pensato come interattivo, sto organizzando una mostra dal 1º al 3 Dicembre alla 71A Gallery con una serata di apertura-performance il 1º Dicembre durante la quale gli spettatori avranno la possibilità di vedere, toccare e manipolare le foto esposte. 
I fondi raccolti attraverso questa campagna mi permetteranno di coprire le spese dei test di stampa, delle stampe finali, della galleria, della opening night e di un catalogo finale che raccolga gli scatti in mostra e la documentazione della serata interattiva.
Dei £2000:
£750 andranno a coprire i costi della galleria;
£350 copriranno la promozione e realizzazione della serata di apertura (volantini, poster, staff per la serata, sicurezza, video-maker per filmare l'interazione con le opere);
£500 saranno destinati a test e stampe finali;
£300 alla produzione del catalogo finale;
£100 copriranno le spese della piattaforma Indiegogo
Se state cominciando ad immaginare come Raw to the Surface potrebbe essere e siete curiosi di vedere il risultato finale potete supportare il progetto con quanto volete. È inoltre possibile fare un'offerta per uno dei "perk", ossia piccoli ringraziamenti materiali che posso offrire in cambio della vostra generosità. Tra questi stampe, ritratti fotografici ad hoc, stampe personalizzate in camera oscura e molto altro!
Raggiungere l'obiettivo di £2000 sarebbe davvero importante per dare a questo progetto la migliore chance possibile ma nel caso l'obiettivo non venga raggiunto tutti i fondi saranno comunque utilizzati per la creazione della mostra, revisionando il budget ed eventualmente tagliando sulle copie del catalogo finale e sulle spese per la serata di performance.
 
Paura?
Pensare ad una mostra mentre i lavori da esporre sono ancora in fase di lavorazione non è cosa da poco. Richiede nervi saldi ed un grande spirito organizzativo, dote che fortunatamente ritengo di avere. Anche se il tempo è poco gran parte del lavoro è terminato e più faccio esperimenti per le stampe finali più non sto nella pelle di vedere il tutto nello spazio espositivo. 
Tutti i miei lavori sono pensati nello spazio, ma raramente ho la possibilità di produrre un lavoro importante e ramificato immaginandolo direttamente all'interno di uno spazio preciso. Questo è un grande vantaggio, che mi permette di lavorare direttamente in vista dell'esperienza in galleria. 
La scelta della mostra interattiva richiede altrettanti nervi saldi e coraggio. Sto dando le mie fotografie nelle mani dello spettatore, presentando mesi e mesi di lavoro e dando la possibilità di distruggerne completamente il risultato. Diciamo che in qualche misura mi spoglio insieme alle mie foto, e spero davvero che tutti i presenti tornino a casa arricchiti da questa esperienza inusuale. 
 
Altri modi per supportare il progetto
So che non tutti hanno la possibilità di supportare un progetto d'arte e sono ben consapevole della presenza di numerose altre cause in giro per il mondo, più serie e più importanti, che vale la pena di supportare economicamente. 
Se non ve la sentite di donare per questo progetto per favore aiutate a diffondere la voce condividendo l'evento Facebook e la mostra su altri social media e al bar davanti ad una birra. Grazie a tutti coloro che parteciperanno dall'Italia e spero di poter raccogliere tanto materiale da poter mostrare a chi non potrà essere presente alla performance. Per tutti gli altri: ci vediamo il 1º Dicembre alla 71A Gallery!

story:
The theme of the VR @ BM art exhibition will be based on the ‘Turing Test’ made famous by Alan Turing in the 1950’s. The purpose of the Turing Test was to determine whether a machine or computer could exhibit intelligence behavior equivalent to or indistinguishable from a human. We will use various VR installations to conduct a tongue and cheek Turing Test at Burning Man. Essentially having fun with the futuristic concept that artificial intelligent beings might, and one day will be present in our everyday experiences and without some form of advanced test, we might not be able to identify them.

 

Did AI infiltrate Burning Man?

 

You may be asking yourself, How does this all work? Well, the exhibition will be set up in three pieces.

 

  • The first segment will be the AI assessment stations, where users will interact with various VR installations which (theoretically) would only work with real humans and not AI’s. Basically all uses will be determined to be an AI so that we can send them into the next segment called Robo Rehab stations.

 

  • The second segment will be the treatment station and will include various VR installations which will help to re-humanize users by showcasing VR impact videos and other VR installations designed to generate empathy (an emotion that separates man from AI or machine).  

 

  • All of this will be hosted in tandem and concurrently with the third segment which is a live, social, VR rave with visuals projected onto the roof of the dome (sun shade). IDEATE VR volunteers will wear doctor’s scrubs and white lab coats to further the theme of mad scientists conducting a Turing Test.

 

You might NOW be asking yourself, how much have you already raised because there's no way that all of this will be possible with only $5,000 dollars.

 

Guess what, your right!

 

The VR @ BM project has already been gifted over $60,000 dollars in equipment and technology (wait I thought gifting only happens at Burning Man. Nope, the VR @ BM project lives the 10 principles both on and off playa). We've also gifted almost $50,000 dollars in expenses related to supporting this experience.

 

All of these numbers are large, but the gap remaining is small. Please help us close the gap and make the VR @ BM project an out of this world success!!!!

story:
Who we are:

C.A.S. is a high-quality bag company located in Hudson, Massachusetts.  Each bag is designed, developed,  and sewn by Cara DesJardins and a small team of leather crafts people.  Each bag is made of full-grain leather and 100 percent linen.  

We only use the highest-quality materials in our handbag construction. Being a natural material, leather often presents minor marks and variations inherent to the hide. While mass-produced or high-end bags try to eliminate those imperfections, we see them as part of the unique character of the material. We believe it is possible to make bags that are beautiful without supporting the wastefulness of the handbag industry.

 

Cara DesJardins

Owner/Designer

Established in 2013, C.A.S. Handmade Inc. is the creation of Cara DesJardins. A native Rhode Islander, Cara was exposed to sewing and textile design at an early age. From this seed there sprouted a unique line of stylish bags, totes, clutches, home textiles and clothes.

Cara graduated from the University of Rhode Island with a degree in textile engineering and earned over ten years experience designing and creating at several textile companies. She took her passion to the next level, combining her love for fabrics, color, and craftsmanship, and developed a line of custom handbags and pillows made from all-natural, hand-painted linen and leather. The natural linen complements the earth mineral pigments she uses to paint her bags. Cara creates a very natural, simplistic style that she strives to maintain in each of her bag styles. 

 Our Pitch:

We did it! Four years in, hundreds of thousands of stitches, thousands of leather hides, four locations later and a dedicated team bringing Cara's designs to life. We are proud to be at the next level. Our studio store now supports over 35 artists, each unique product made with love and precision. Here's where you come in, we need your help to break through to the next level. We want to continue the momentum by purchasing new die cutting tools, equipment, hire and train new artists, and bring in additional American made products from around the region.

You will be supporting a sustainable eco-friendly company. Each bag is designed, developed and sewn by Cara DesJardins and a small team of sewers and leather craftspeople. All leather products are made from full-grain sustainable leather and 100% linen. We believe it is possible to make bags that are beautiful without supporting the wastefulness of mass produced products.

Thank you for your support! If you have any questions about our products and practices or design process or even about becoming a bigger part of C.A.S. Handmade. Please reach out. We love to hear from you.

Thanks - Cara & Jason

 

Our Risk Factor:

Each Pledge will be filled in 30 days. Our only risk factor is production scheduling. Depending on how many pledges we get,  your bag could take a little longer then 30 days. We will fill each pledge in order of the date pledged. We thank you for all your help!!

story:
It's time! As mentioned prior I'm going to make an art book with you guys! And it's easy as hell to participate.

 

HOW THIS WORKS...

The legnth of the book depends on how many art pieces are pledged for here in the fundraiser. You pick the size you want, I make and ship you the original art while placing a scan and a small spooky story next to it in the book.

 

ART SIZE OPTIONS...

The art is available in three sizes; 3x3, 4x4, and 6x6. Each is priced accordingly.

 

BOOK DISTRIBUTION OPTIONS...

By making this a fundraiser I can distribute the book in three full colored formats. Digitally, which all backers will receive for free or can be pledged for independently, as well as a softcover or hardcover print release which can also be pledged for.

 

WHY $500...


Because it's the minimum indiegogo would let me choose. I wanted to select $100 but that was not an option. If we make $500 great, I can print more books, if not you all still get your art and this book still gets made!

story:
What Happened?!?

We were ROBBED!!  On 12/01/12 we set out on our move from California to our new home in Texas and stopped along the way in Tucson Arizona with our Budget Truck parked safely (at least we thought so) 30 feet away from the hotel entrance.  We woke up the next day and looked out the window only to discover a pile of broken glass where our whole lifes worth of belongings had once been parked.  We were lucky enough to get our car back out of the ordeal which contained my computer with all the magazine files and important info!  So with a few pair of chonies, a couple shirts, and our 2 black cats we pressed on to Texas.  (Sadly our leopard gecko Edgar Allen Poe didn't make it through the move)

All of our magazine company's merch was stolen.  All the issues, all our shirts, our buttons, wristbands, everything.  We also lost all of our start up clothing company's merchandise.  This moving truck cost us $1,500 and in a blink vanished along with thousands of dollars of our belongings along with our items that can not be replaced.  (The truck rental ended up putting me at a negative balance in the bank after they double charged me for the trailer we used to tow the car).  We are the definition of an independent magazine.  All of this product had been purchased through friends donations, an inheritance check from my grandfathers death, loans, etc. (my Grandfather believed in my companies and loaned me the money to get them started in the first place)  My girlfriend also lost her whole make up kit that it had taken over 2 years to put together.  She has put all of her schooling and expertise into our Gore Noir photoshoots.  Any special effects artists will know how much these kits can cost to put together.

What We Need & What You Get

In order to replace what we lost and to help us get the ball rolling on our 7th issue which is in the works as we speak anything will help.  The more we raise the better we will be able to hit the ground running and not miss a beat.  I have big plans for this magazine and they all involve helping out the underground horror community.  We are for the artists, the models, the musicians, the photographers, and everyone in between that is striving to make the horror genre great.  We love spotlighting all these people that are overlooked by the larger magazines.  We have our niche and it's that "culture" in horror culture.  We are the tattooed blood loving freaks that like to just plain CREATE.  I like to get involved in the community and not just "review" it.

 

The Impact

Every little bit helps.  Donate a few bucks.  Share the compaign on your Facebook.  Tweet it.  Like it.  Whatever you can do for us is greatly appreciated.  Not only will this help out the magazine but it wil also help me get back on my feet.  All my clothes, furniture, family photos, keepsakes, etc. were stolen along with that truck.  My Grandfathers pocket knife that was passed on to me after he passed was locked away in that truck.  Thankfully I had it's image tattooed on me.  It'll be with me forever as will his strength and determination.  We will continue on.  Not only will we continue on but with your help we will prosper in 2013.  My life long dream to create a successful magazine WILL be realized. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Get the word out and help us show the world that these thieves can't break us!
 
Share on Facbeook!
Share on Twitter!
Share on your blog!
Any and all social media that you can get the word out on will help!
 
www.gorenoir.com
www.facebook.com/gorenoir
 
Blog posts about our cause:
http://www.thehomicidalhomemaker.com/gore-noir-magazine-replacement-fund/
http://theprojectsofmichaelpugh.wordpress.com/
http://www.gorenoir.blogspot.com/2012/12/its-all-gone.html
story_txt:
What Happened?!?
We were ROBBED!!  On 12/01/12 we set out on our move from California to our new home in Texas and stopped along the way in Tucson Arizona with our Budget Truck parked safely (at least we thought so) 30 feet away from the hotel entrance.  We woke up the next day and looked out the window only to discover a pile of broken glass where our whole lifes worth of belongings had once been parked.  We were lucky enough to get our car back out of the ordeal which contained my computer with all the magazine files and important info!  So with a few pair of chonies, a couple shirts, and our 2 black cats we pressed on to Texas.  (Sadly our leopard gecko Edgar Allen Poe didn't make it through the move)

All of our magazine company's merch was stolen.  All the issues, all our shirts, our buttons, wristbands, everything.  We also lost all of our start up clothing company's merchandise.  This moving truck cost us $1,500 and in a blink vanished along with thousands of dollars of our belongings along with our items that can not be replaced.  (The truck rental ended up putting me at a negative balance in the bank after they double charged me for the trailer we used to tow the car).  We are the definition of an independent magazine.  All of this product had been purchased through friends donations, an inheritance check from my grandfathers death, loans, etc. (my Grandfather believed in my companies and loaned me the money to get them started in the first place)  My girlfriend also lost her whole make up kit that it had taken over 2 years to put together.  She has put all of her schooling and expertise into our Gore Noir photoshoots.  Any special effects artists will know how much these kits can cost to put together.



What We Need & What You Get
In order to replace what we lost and to help us get the ball rolling on our 7th issue which is in the works as we speak anything will help.  The more we raise the better we will be able to hit the ground running and not miss a beat.  I have big plans for this magazine and they all involve helping out the underground horror community.  We are for the artists, the models, the musicians, the photographers, and everyone in between that is striving to make the horror genre great.  We love spotlighting all these people that are overlooked by the larger magazines.  We have our niche and it's that "culture" in horror culture.  We are the tattooed blood loving freaks that like to just plain CREATE.  I like to get involved in the community and not just "review" it.
 



The Impact
Every little bit helps.  Donate a few bucks.  Share the compaign on your Facebook.  Tweet it.  Like it.  Whatever you can do for us is greatly appreciated.  Not only will this help out the magazine but it wil also help me get back on my feet.  All my clothes, furniture, family photos, keepsakes, etc. were stolen along with that truck.  My Grandfathers pocket knife that was passed on to me after he passed was locked away in that truck.  Thankfully I had it's image tattooed on me.  It'll be with me forever as will his strength and determination.  We will continue on.  Not only will we continue on but with your help we will prosper in 2013.  My life long dream to create a successful magazine WILL be realized. 



Other Ways You Can Help
Get the word out and help us show the world that these thieves can't break us!
 
Share on Facbeook!
Share on Twitter!
Share on your blog!
Any and all social media that you can get the word out on will help!
 
www.gorenoir.com
www.facebook.com/gorenoir
 
Blog posts about our cause:
http://www.thehomicidalhomemaker.com/gore-noir-magazine-replacement-fund/
http://theprojectsofmichaelpugh.wordpress.com/
http://www.gorenoir.blogspot.com/2012/12/its-all-gone.html

story:
A book promoting and helping to preserve Tibetan culture by teaching the Tibetan language through relevant art

Share on Facebook

“The need for manuals of [Tibetan] language instruction has … become all the more urgent” — བོད་ཀྱི་སྤྱི་སྐད་སློབ་དེབ། Manual of Standard Tibetan

“The Tibetan people will remain alive as distinct from other nationals as long as the Tibetan language exists.”  — Samdhong Rinpoche

 

བཀྲ་ཤིས་བདེ་ལེགས་ Tashi Delek! I am a linguist and an artist working to promote Tibetan culture by making the language more accessible to a wider range of people. When a language lives, a culture lives.

 

Language, Tibetan in particular, is not inherently difficult to learn, but the way one learns and the tools one uses are important to how one succeeds.

This book is in response to my own journey learning the language and the resources that I have come across. There is a need for more manuals of language instruction and the manuals need to present the information in an easily understood way.

I am working on a new book teaching the Tibetan language that presents the language through the medium of art that makes understanding flow more easily.

In this small way, I am working to promote and preserve the Tibetan culture. For I am deeply grateful for Tibet and all that its people have given to humanity.  

This fundraising campaign will cover all of supplies needed to complete the book and to print the book itself. I have already completed much of the outlines and sketches for the pages, and then the process of painting and computer editing comes, for which I need more paint, canvases, and computer power to complete.

Most importantly, the cost to print the book! I intend for the book to be printed on recycled paper in Dharamsala by a Tibetan printer.

Please read on for a more detailed look at the book, why I am writing it, and why it is unique.

My name is Jason and I have for most of my life been fascinated by the study of language. I have to varying degrees studied more languages than I can count on my fingers and toes, but no language has thus far on my journey captivated me as the Tibetan language has. It is my intention with this work to make it simpler and more expedient to learn this precious gem.

By making it simpler and easier for a greater amount of people to learn, the Tibetan language is encouraged to grow. The more people that can read and speak the language, the more the culture and its wisdom live. The more a language lives, the more a culture lives.

The modern Indian mystic Acharya Rajneesh said, "Nowhere has such concentrated effort been made to discover man's being." The Dalai Lama has also expressed concern over the declining use of the language. This is why I feel that the Tibetan language matters, as the indispensible key to its cultural wisdom, and why it thus is important for there to be more accessible learning resources for a wide range of demographics. And that is what I am creating.

I intend to accomplish this in three ways: powerful use of art, color, pattern and sacred geometrical design (mandalas) and composition for the physical layout of each page, thus making the information more readily absorbed; secondly, I will assume no prior linguistic knowledge and yet the book will remain comprehensive and authoritive on pronunciation, phonology, and so on.

Lastly, the book will be unique in that you will start reading Tibetan from the very first page. In fact, I am sure that you already speak a lot more Tibetan than you might believe! You probably know words like Lama, Rinpoche,  Pema or the mantra Om Mani Padme Hum, and this book will show you how to begin directly reading, speaking and writing these words in the Tibetan (u-chen) script.

I have a unique vision and style of presentation that synthesizes and presents information in a way that can greatly aid others on their paths herewith.

Most importantly, I see this through the use of art--moving beyond black on white text in forgettable square data tables. I can see that others, as I have, could learn much more easily if this information is encoded into color and form.

What I Need and What You Receive

I am asking for money to fund the time intensive process of writing, painting, designing, editing, and producing the book. Based off of my sketches and outlines thus far, a great amount of the pages will be hand designed and painted, then digitized and completed on the computer. There will be at least thirty unique paintings I will do for the book focusing on Tibetan letters, mantras, and vocabulary.

All of the donations generated here will fund the cost of materials--such as paints, brushes, canvases--and the cost to print the book.

Please look to the right of the page for an overview of all that you receive for your donations.

The Impact

By supporting this work, you are directly supporting the preservation of an incredibly powerful culture. This will be an amazingly unique book and tool, and I am sincerely excited about its potential to help people study the Tibetan language and to promote the language overall, showing the world its importance.

Other Ways You Can Help

I also need help by sharing this campaign. Please share it with anyone you know who has an interest in promoting and the preserving Tibetan language or culture. Even if you already speak Tibetan, or even if you don't have an interest in the language, I encourage you to donate and share the message of this project with others.

Thank you. I am deeply grateful to you for your help in allowing me to serve humanity in this way. May you all be free from suffering and the causes of suffering.

ཨོཾ་མ་ཎི་པ་དྨེ་ཧཱུྃ

story:
GonzoFest 2014, curated by Hunter's longtime friend and fellow poet Ron Whitehead, is the culmination of 20 years of brainstorming, planning, and plotting ways to secure the rememberance of one of Louisville's greatest unsung heroes, Hunter S. Thompson, with a "Hunter's Gonzoville" Hometown Hero banner to be displayed on a prominent downtown building in the spring of 2014. 

We're coming to you for donations to help us financially with the massive undertaking of this festival and celebration of Hunters life. Some of our biggest financial burdens are the costs of hanging/printing the banner, booking the talent, renting some of the venues, and securing critical infrastructure for the outdoor portion of the festival. 

GonzoFest 2014 will feature live music from national, regional and local bands and musicians of differing styles including bluegrass, folk, acoustic, and rock. Poets and writers will read their Gonzo and Hunter S. Thompson inspired work as well as Hunter’s work. 

In addition to music, live art, and spoken word, GonzoFest 2014 will host the US premiere screening of “For No Good Reason” a documentary on Ralph Steadman’s life narrated by Johnny Depp. It will also feature an Art & Literary Contest focusing on Gonzo journalism and art, parade through downtown Louisville and celebrity appearances. We hear rumors the famed RED SHARK will motor to Louisville for the festivities too!

All of this entertainment and remembrance of Hunter’s work/life will be held at various venues such as the Ali Center, Carmichaels Bookstores, The New Vintage, The Monkey Wrench, Haymarket Whiskey Bar, Open Gallery, The Mag Bar, and more TBA the week of March 31st through April 5th with more details on lineups, locations,and more TBA.

This is a chance for HUNTERS FANS EVERYWHERE to be part of GONZO HISTORY! Buy the ticket and take the ride!

Take a moment to look through the rewards to the right and make a contribution or just give what you can. Take a look at our instagram, twitter, facebook, and other websites, and share, like, and help us spread the word. 

Additional Perks and breaking news will be announced in the coming weeks, keep checking back for more updates. 

www.facebook.com/GonzofestLouisville

www.instagram.com/gonzofest

#GonzoFest

Keep Louisville Gonzo.

story:
Who we are

We are Emily Blaser and Kristen McLaren, and we are raising funds for our Senior Thesis Exhibition, Lepidopteric Dichotomy, which will be at the Locust Factory in the heart of the Crossroad district on May 2nd.  We are collaborating to create an experimental, process based art show where we focus on materiality, production, and decay, using natural fibers, wool and silk, moths, and video projection.  In order to see our full vision come to life, we need your help!

What we need

This campaign will fund our space, technology, fiber materials, installation supplies, and the purchase and care of moths.  

If you help us reach our goal some of the rewards will be handmade paper products, small pieces from the exhibition, as well as a private tour of the final exhibition with the artists. 

Any amount that we receive from this campaign will help us reach our goal!

Stay updated on our progress through our blog 

Be sure to check out our exhibition May 2nd, located at the Locust Factory, 504 East 18th St. Kansas City, MO 64108!

story:
Short Summary

Hi, my name is Shane. I am a dancer and choreographer. I recently left my job working for the Batsheva Ensemble based in Tel Aviv, Israel. I received a BFA in choreography from UC Irvine in 2011 and due to my busy performance schedule with Batsheva my outlet to make work was limited. 

Naturally, I have a lot of pent up choreographic ideas and I'm grateful to now have the opportunity to actualize some of them. Nature 2 is my vessel. This campaign is designed to provide support for all aspects of building a choreographic work. From the research to the making of the piece to the first performance in Santa Barbara, California.

Nature 2 is a project I devised to merge my biggest passions: Dance and Nature. As an adult my love for nature has continued to grow. I hike, read essays and daydream about it constantly. This obsession fills me with so much joy I considered divorcing my first love, dance, and spending all my efforts in becoming a National Park Ranger or something like that. I used to ask myself, what could be better than that!?  It took a while but I realized that such a divorce probably wouldn’t bring me the utopian mountain man happiness I was dreaming of. But maybe combining these interests could? Hence Nature 2!

The project will be aided by my partner and collaborator Ayelet Nadav. Together we will conduct extensive research in the field. We will visit over 15 National Parks during the winter of 2016 collecting material. We will document our experiences with writing, film, and photography. The goal is to collect a hefty load of material and thoughts to bring with us to the studio. When we’ve finished the outdoor portion of the process we will move inside to create and design a thoughtful piece of choreography. 

Nature 2 is an experiment. Can a piece be made for a theatrical setting that involves as much thought provoking detail and empathy about nature as the writings of John Muir, Edward Abbey, Gary Snyder, Jack Kerouac, and Apsley Cherry- Garrard? What will a nature essay using performance look like? And who will make it if I don't?


What We Need & What You Get

This campaign is designed to help fund Nature 2 in all stages of its development. Below is a description of how the money will be spread across the three main stages of the process.

RESEARCH & FIELDWORK

  • Camera: an upgrade to my personal camera equipment is needed. I utilize photography and video a lot in my works. For the last few years I’ve been able to manage with the camera on my phone and an old flip camera (remember those). This piece deserves better!

THE MAKING OF

  • Rehearsal space rental: I’d like to secure at least 20hrs of studio rehearsal time where the piece will be developed into a performance.

PERFORMANCE

  • Theatrical space rental: I would like to premier Nature 2 at Santa Barbara’s Center Stage Theater. This allowance will help rent the theater itself and pay the technical staff for our limited in theater rehearsal time. This venue is the perfect intimate space for Nature 2  and luckily the rates are reasonable .

  • PR stipend: The performance will need PR. We want as many people to come see this evening as possible. This stipend will pay for flyers and ads in local papers

  • Performer payment: This money will go to Ayelet as a symbolic payment for her work in this project. I believe in paying artists a living wage for their work, and I wish I had the means to do that now. That said, because of the nature of this project and my relationship with Ayelet I think a symbolic stipend will be sufficient. 


If you decide to donate there are a few modest perks you can receive as a thank you for your donation. 
$15 gets you a postcard from a National Park sent to you from the road.
$30 gets you a 2 min. video sent to your email from the road or the rehearsal process.
$75 gets you an hour long interview. In person or video chat, whatever is most convenient.

The Impact

There are many communities I want to engage with Nature 2. 

I want to bring a refreshing look on what dance can be to Santa Barbara. I want to show that dance can be used as tool for discourse about a different topics other than dance itself. Too often dance is made for dancers these days. I want to show nature enthusiasts and activists that dance and performance can provide a scaffolding for their (our) cause. If this project gets funded I foresee it helping facilitate more performances of this piece in the future. At the very least, I plan to show this work as much as possible to my communties here in the US and in Israel.  It will provide a foundation I can use to obtain grant money for Nature 2 and for future projects. I have many plans…. ;)

More Info

If you're interested in what my work looks like please visit the gallery section of this campign or my website at shane.scopatz.com.
