story:
YOU'RE INVITED!

Be a

AMBASSADOR


Imagine what we can accomplish if everyone who views this invitation donates $10 and got a friend or family member to give $10 using #give2get10 on social media.

Yes! That would go far. 

PLUS, if/when you give and get $10 as a part of this fundraising initiative you get the opportunity to win 2 VIP SEATS to see 

TORREBLANCA / ULALUME & CARLO NICOLAU in concert at Lincoln Center.


Join us! This is how it works:


STEP 1. Give $10 (OR whatever amount your heart desires and budget allows!).
STEP 2. Choose your favorite social media platform and post that you have just donated to Mexico Now's Indiegogo Campaign. Tag a friend/family member and invite them to also give $10. You can find us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter.
STEP 3. Use hashtags #fundmxnow and#give2get10. 

Examples you can use:

Twitter 
I donated $10 to the @MexicoNowFest #give2get10 goal. I invite [tag/mention your friend] to #fundmxnow w/ $10: http://bit.ly/fundmxnow15


Facebook and Instagram
I donated $10 to the CELEBRATE MEXICO NOW FESTIVAL #give2get10 goal on Indiegogo. I invite [tag/mention your friend] to #fundmxnow w/ $10: http://bit.ly/fundmxnow15

Date: Thu, OCT 29th
Time: 7:30 pm
Place: David Rubenstein Atrium, Lincoln Center in New York City.

● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ●


Queridos amigos / Dear friends,

WE DID IT!

Together, for the fourth consecutive year, we have run a successful crowdfunding campaign (happy dance!).

This is proof that solidifies the fact that CELEBRATE MEXICO NOW is an independent festival created by YOU, our backers.

It's not just that we can't do it without you, we do it FOR YOU. Every donation, big and small, makes it possible.

Thank you to all our donors for making it happen!
The Celebrate Mexico Now Team


● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ● ●


WE CAN DO THIS TOGETHER!


For 12 years, Celebrate México Now Festival has been New York City's 1st— and only —annual festival of contemporary Mexican art and culture. We have been a platform for over 300 talented visual artists, musicians, dancers, authors, chefs and filmmakers to showcase their work in over 50 cultural organizations in the grand city of New York. We are also very proud to have presented renowned performances and many World Premieres.

This year Celebrate México Now will once again showcase contemporary Mexican culture and the arts in major venues across New York City. 

We invite you to join us for outstanding events including photo exhibits, film screenings, concerts, culinary programs, panels, and performances.

Funding for the arts is very scarce and even more so for international projects. Although we have been able to secure backing from our longtime supporters and partner venues, we still need additional funding to bring this festival to you.


OUR IMPACT

For over a decade, Celebrate México Now has highlighted the creativity, ingenuity, heritage, and heart that contemporary Mexican artists bring to every arts discipline and creative industry. Venturing into to the cutting edge of contemporary expression, Celebrate México Now  will bring New Yorkers an exclusive glimpse into how today’s Mexican artists reflect on and reshape Mexican identity in an evolving global context. The Festival’s multi-disciplinary nature yields a comprehensive cultural picture of the passions and concerns that make today’s Mexico so complex and fascinating.

Celebrate México Now Festival has successfully completed Indiegogo campaigns in past years to secure the support needed to continue this citywide cultural festival. 

Help us reach our goal in 2015! Check out the awesome perks we're offering and give now.


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please tell your family and friends about this campaign and Celebrate México Now. Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Instagram to stay up to date on everything happening behind the scenes too!  

Use hashtag #fundmxnow to be in the loop of all things Celebrate Mexico Now Festival's Annual Fundraising Campaign 2015 in social media.


START HERE!

CLICK TO TWEET: Support Celebrate Mexico Now Festival 2015 on Indiegogo! DONATE NOW: http://ctt.ec/vWXEi+ via @MexicoNowFest #fundmxnow #supportart 

OR

Share our campaign on social media:
http://bit.ly/fundmxnow15

story:
"Cubicles are where dreams go to die." - S. Allahverdi

I graduated from college with a Major in Debt & a Minor in Getting By...

My first job out of college was in a large corporation, as a graphic designer. It was the first job I would have where I would be working in a cubicle. Someone took me up to the floor that I would be on, and I saw the mass of cubicles I reconized from "Office Space". My cubicle was down the isle where all of the rest of the Art Department worked. A sadness dreared over me as I passed each one, all with one common denominator. Unlike cubicles in say a software company, where maybe middle aged woman & men display their the family life in cheap photo frames from Target, that they that had worked hard to support, as a reminder why they were there in the first place; the artists that occupied these cubicles had quite the opposite: All their cubicles were lined with all sorts of art; from traditional to modern, to graphics, to ads they enjoyed, to personal pieces they had made sometime when they did not exist there. They weren't reminders of why they were suffering through it. They were unfulfilled dreams, that they were not currently pursing. It disturbed me on a deep level. I carried feelings of remorse for them, as I walked down a fabricated corridor to what seemed would be my open grave . I didn't want to be in a place for 8 hours of my day where I stared at a life I wish I had. I knew I wouldn't work hard there, afterall, at the end of the day if I shipped a few extra units, I wouldn't see a dime - Where was my motivation? I quit that afternoon.

"NINE to FIVES are the world's most subtle tragedies"- S.Allahverdi

 Maybe this story sounds familiar, because it is you, or maybe you know someone who is this person.

Either way - supporting Art2Art, will help people in those situations with more personal asspirations than just getting by.

You can't afford an advertising, marketing, and graphic design team to produce the quality of work that exists in the industry. Art2Art will change that.

THIS MONEY IS OUR STARTUP FUND, IT WILL HELP MARKET US AND GET TO THE RIGHT PEOPLE, AND IS ENOUGH TO START LAUNCHING THEIR DREAMS & OURS.

*We aren't doing this to make a million dollars. We are doing it because we want to be a part of peoples' success with projects we care about.*
 

Who are we, you ask?

We all have backgrounds in art. From traditional to graphic design. Also advertising & marketing.  We have our bases coverd. ;)

story:
More about "The Waste Land" Performance

At 401 Richmond in Toronto, artist Jessica Bebenek translated T.S. Eliot's canonical long poem "The Waste Land" into a knitted tapestry as a part of Nuit Blanche's Independent Artist's program. She knit the 500-line poem over 12 hours, using a pattern she created by translating the stressed and unstressed beats of each line of poetry into lines of knit and purl stitches.

Eliot’s poem uses intentionally obscure language and references and was written to be understood only by his fellow male Modernists. What happens when Eliot’s coded language is translated into the coded language of a knitting pattern? By performing the hidden labour of knitting as a feat of endurance, Bebenek critiques the artificial divide between ‘fine arts’ & ‘crafts’ and the systemic devaluation of ‘women’s work’.

~~~

One day you'll be able to buy the knitting pattern as a book (I hope!), but for now, please check out some of the books, knitted tapestries, and services I'm offering to the right.

 

About Jess

Hi! I'm Jess, a poet and transdisciplinary artist who splits her time between Montreal and Toronto. I was a poet in the Toronto literary community for years before moving to Montreal to complete my MA in English & Creative Writing. I've primarily written and published lyric poetry, but these days I'm fascinated by textile arts and the rich lineage of women & folks reinventing the genre. My performance at Nuit Blanche even inspired me to work more in creating installation art!

I've edited poetry, short stories, and everything in between in more than eight university workshops, as well as a full novel. I've curated a reading series, run a small press publishing experimental poetry and other works. I've taught undergraduate classes and independent workshops, and continue to work as a programming coordinator at Concordia's Centre for Expanded Poetics, where I organized the Occult Poetics Symposium.

 

So, like, weren't you just knitting?

What cost so much??

While I was as thrifty as possible, the cost of organizing a performance of this size adds up. Here's a breakdown of where the money went:

  • Supplies: $470.90
  • Travel: $200.57
  • Accommodation: $392.11
  • Food (& so much coffee): 284.71

I sought funding beforehand, but unfortunately I was barred from applying for student funding (because I'm in my third year of a two-year program) and from government funding (because I'm a student and I'll be writing about this performance in my thesis.)

Luckily, the amazing folks at Wave Books and Véhicule Press stepped in to generously donate a selection of books, available here for you to purchase, with the funds going directly to recouping the cost of my performance!

Hardcover Subscription 2007 from Wave Books

The series includes signed and numbered cloth-bound volumes:

  • Sorry, Tree by Eileen Myles
  • Rise Up by Matthew Rohrer
  • Citzen Of  by Christian Hawkey
  • No Real Light by Joe Wenderoth
  • Awe by Dorothea Lasky
  • The Scented Fox by Laynie Browne (softcover)

New Releases & Classics from Vehicule Press

  • Stranger by Nyla Matuk
  • Siren by Kateri Lanthier
  • Table Manners by Catrionia Wright
  • New Tab by Guillaume Morissette
  • Closer to Home: The Author and the Author Portrait by Terence Byrnes
  • Niko by Dimitri Nasrallah

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If there's something you know I make that isn't offered here (kombucha? all-natural skincare products? tarot readings?), please contact me and we can arrange something!

story:
A Permanent Temple of Remembrance

Internationally known Temple Builder, David Best, is working with the Voigt Family Sculpture Foundation to create his first permanent temple. David is well-known for his ephemeral temples at Burning Man and elsewhere, that are burned after a few days or months. This is David's first steel temple sculpture. It is important to us to provide this powerful place where anyone can visit, experience the power of the space and deal with loss and sorrow in a context of renewal and grace. You can be part of this amazing endeavor and help create an enduring work of art. The Temple will be dedicated at Paradise Ridge Winery, our generous hosts, on Sunday, October 20 from 2 to 4 p.m. and will be free and open to the public seven days a week.

We Are Seeking Matching Funds

A 32-foot tall steel Temple is a costly undertaking. Steel alone will cost close to $50,000. And there are design and engineering costs, professional welders and fabricators, transportation, installation ... it adds up fast!

  • The Voigt Family Sculpture Foundation is providing upfront costs, organizational expertise and a location for fabrication. All donations go strictly to offset costs incurred by our 501(c)(3) charitable foundation.
  • We get it about perks and we believe we've chosen unique, useful and exciting gifts for you that reflect the creativity and impact of this amazing project.
  • We've got skin in this game too. Our foundation will match all donations.

The Impact You Can Make

In 2012, the Voigt Family Sculpture Foundation partnered with Paradise Ridge Winery to create The Spirit of the Man, a remarkable sculpture exhibition at the winery's beautiful natural setting in the hills of Sonoma County. We invited David Best to build a wooden temple, and after a long winter, burned the temple in accordance with its intended life cycle.   We are immensely grateful to the Black Rock Arts Foundation for helping underwrite the first temple. They are an extraordinary partner.  

It was during and after the burn when we realized the immense impact that this structure had on people, who came and expressed the most powerful feelings. It became clear to us that, somehow we had to create a more enduring structure, as our gift to you.

Our foundation has a long track record of installing sculpture in publicly accessible places throughout Sonoma County. The art we install is world class, but it's not locked up in galleries. Anyone can experience it!

We invite you to share our vision.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute, you can still help!

  • Please help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Post a link on Facebook or Twitter, email your friends or tell people in coffee shops.
  • You can also use the Indiegogo share tools.

Thanks so much for checking us out.


A special thanks to http://tag-film.com/ for the video and http://www.norvilleparchment.com/ for the music!

story:
DesignTAXI Publication Monday 21st of April 2014 (here)

"French designerAdrien Colombié is on a mission to document the fingerprints of people from all over the world for his ambitious project ‘Humans of the World.’ 

Described as “an artistic survey of earth’s inhabitants”, Colombié’s goal is to connect the stories of different strangers together with their fingerprints, and bring them together in a book. 

Starting 30 July, he will approach and interview a different person each day over a period of 365 days, gathering their experiences and stories in the form of photographs, videos and fingerprints. Each fingerprint represents a personal connection between the reader and the person. 

The book is a compilation of 50 of the most memorable people he meets, and will consist of notes about each person, their hopes, dreams and achievements, amongst others. 

Besides interviewing ordinary humans, he plans to meet around 30 colorful characters including “a famous DJ in Hong Kong to a former prisoner in Bangkok, to an entrepreneur from the favelas.”

What I need & What You get

10,000€ is my first goal, This allows me to fund the book, buy the frames and produce the digital content all along the year. 100% Of the funds go for two purposes: 1. Fund the entire book project. 2. Produce and send the frames.


Every piece comes with the story of the person who carries this fingerprint capturing the essence of their individuality.It's a unique and intimate bridge, a personal connection between you and a stranger from somewhere in the world.

If you take 2 steps back, they are all the same young, old, black, white, poor, rich, African or Asian. But if you get closer some of them look like clouds, some of them look like stones, they are all singular, unique and unrivaled like humanity.


The Book - Discover 50 inhabitants of the World


Editorial standpoint
The book will be a compilation of the 50 most memorable humans I meet.  It will be composed of notes, photos, maps and obviously, the humans' fingerprints. 

Each reportage will also include a list of facts on each person: what they do, have done, think, who they love, what they hate, the things they dream of, etc.. With this, I will be able to create the most objective possible image of their lives, work and words. Quite simply, I will capture the essence of the human beings that they are.

I will be guided by a list of questions and also follow a common method for all of them.  I will share moments of their lives with them and spend time observing, listening and basically being curious. I will also plan about thirty meetings with "notorious" people. From a famous DJ in Hong Kong to a former prisoner in Bangkok, to an entrepreneur from the favelas. The full list is coming soon... 

This approach was partiality inspired by Humans of New York but mainly by anthropological researchers of the previous century. They were adventurers, journalists and artists all at once. These explorers of the unknown went to meet the new world by trying to understand it and describe it as objectively as possible. 

Prologue

"What do you do with your liberty?" This question will be part of all of my interviews and the answers will compose the prologue of this book. After centuries of battles and bloody wars for freedom, it is legitimate to ask people about their liberty. How do they enjoy their liberty? Are they still fighting for it? If so, what is their battle? All of these will be answered along my journey.




Delivery

Frames: It's a limited series, only 365 Frames (one-a-day), first come, first served.  I will be sending the frame every 2 weeks, and as soon as you pre-order one I will send you an estimated date of delivery.

Books: I will work on the book during the project, to send you updates and previews the more often possible and also to be able to print directly the 356th day and to send you the book the sooner possible.

Stretch Goal:
15,000€ - Hard cover for the BookStretch Goal:
25,000€ - Digital Experience with more interactive & rich media

More about the creator

I'm Adrien Colombie, I’m a french designer currently working in NYC via Bordeaux, Barcelona and Paris. I build up my life and project thanks to values, discovered in sport. While i was practicing competitive rowing, l learned sense of sharing, competition, but also taste of discovery and exploration. To quench my thirst of knowledge and experimentation, i embarked myself in a multitude of projects : creative collectives, Freelance, Conferences, Travel, Art... Today, this thirst for discovery made me navigate in America, to New-York City. There, it's a daily sharpening up of my "savoir-faire". But there is still a entire world to discover...

More information on www.adriencolombie.com

Sharing is helping !

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help,
You can follow and share the project’s progress on Facebook.
I’ll be updating daily. facebook - Humans of the World


Any questions? Adriencolombie@gmail.com

But if you get closer some of them look like clouds, some of them look like stones, they are all singular, unique and unrivaled like humanity.The Book - Discover 50 inhabitants of the World
Editorial standpoint
The book will be a compilation of the 50 most memorable humans I meet.  It will be composed of notes, photos, maps and obviously, the humans' fingerprints. Each reportage will also include a list of facts on each person: what they do, have done, think, who they love, what they hate, the things they dream of, etc.. With this, I will be able to create the most objective possible image of their lives, work and words. Quite simply, I will capture the essence of the human beings that they are.I will be guided by a list of questions and also follow a common method for all of them.  I will share moments of their lives with them and spend time observing, listening and basically being curious. I will also plan about thirty meetings with "notorious" people. From a famous DJ in Hong Kong to a former prisoner in Bangkok, to an entrepreneur from the favelas. The full list is coming soon... This approach was partiality inspired by Humans of New York but mainly by anthropological researchers of the previous century. They were adventurers, journalists and artists all at once. These explorers of the unknown went to meet the new world by trying to understand it and describe it as objectively as possible. Prologue "What do you do with your liberty?" This question will be part of all of my interviews and the answers will compose the prologue of this book. After centuries of battles and bloody wars for freedom, it is legitimate to ask people about their liberty. How do they enjoy their liberty? Are they still fighting for it? If so, what is their battle? All of these will be answered along my journey.DeliveryFrames: It's a limited series, only 365 Frames (one-a-day), first come, first served.  I will be sending the frame every 2 weeks, and as soon as you pre-order one I will send you an estimated date of delivery.Books: I will work on the book during the project, to send you updates and previews the more often possible and also to be able to print directly the 356th day and to send you the book the sooner possible.Stretch Goal: 15,000€ - Hard cover for the BookStretch Goal: 25,000€ - Digital Experience with more interactive & rich mediaMore about the creatorI'm Adrien Colombie, I’m a french designer currently working in NYC via Bordeaux, Barcelona and Paris. I build up my life and project thanks to values, discovered in sport. While i was practicing competitive rowing, l learned sense of sharing, competition, but also taste of discovery and exploration. To quench my thirst of knowledge and experimentation, i embarked myself in a multitude of projects : creative collectives, Freelance, Conferences, Travel, Art... Today, this thirst for discovery made me navigate in America, to New-York City. There, it's a daily sharpening up of my "savoir-faire". But there is still a entire world to discover...More information on www.adriencolombie.comSharing is helping !Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help,You can follow and share the project’s progress on Facebook. I’ll be updating daily. facebook - Humans of the WorldAny questions? Adriencolombie@gmail.com

story:
What is Right Brain Child?

Right Brain Child is a team of creative practitioners (That's Adam and Robin!) that have vast experience of working with children and young adults in a variety of educational and non educational settings. We are passionate about art and all things creative. We want to share our passion and knowledge and inspire our future generations by delivering inspirational and inventive art activities to children and young people that will nurture and inspire creativity.

Our Key Initiatives are to…

  • Develop self expression, confidence and self-esteem.

  •  Encourage team-work, co-operation and communication.

  • Enhance awareness of art forms, other cultures and use of art techniques.

  • Provide a worthwhile and memorable experience.

  • Enrich curriculum learning.

We work closely with professional bodies and organisations, drawing on knowledge, skills and research to enhance our own understanding and practice of working with children. We are dedicated to professional development of our company’s practice, ethos, and program through continuous training and development.

What We Need & What You Get

We are opening up a brick and mortar location in North Bay Ontario to begin offering weekly classes for students.  This will be able to increase the accessibility to arts education in the North.  This fundraising campaign is to help us raise the funds to cover some of those costs associated with first starting up, such as:

-Tables, chairs, eisles

-Light tables

-Renovations to the new space

- Art supplies, etc.

By helping us with our campaign, you will not only have our lifetime of thanks, but you can also receive a variety of thank you gifts that correspond with each donation amount. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you are unable to contribute financially, please help us promote arts education in the North. Please share this campaign with anyone you think might be interested in promoting arts education.

Check out our website for more info: www.rightbrainchild.ca

story:
Who Is This Dashing Young Group of Fellows, You Ask?

My name is David Perry, and I am the creator and lead artist/writer for Petty Torture Productions, an Indianapolis-based illustration company still in its infancy. Other creative minds within our ranks include Matthew Gambill, Noah Heckaman, Garrett Harriman, and Brittany May.

We've done work for the internet musical chap-hop sensation Professor Elemental, including album cover art for Father of Invention, comic illustrations and story writing, full album sleeve graphic design work for his upcoming album, "The Giddy Limit," and various other smaller projects. Aside from this, we've done work for the web-based Christian organization "World Prayr" (not a typo), the Indianapolis-based preparatory school The Todd Academy, and other smaller projects.

We also have a number of our own conceptual cartoons series', such as Space Pirates, Scratch, Intelligent Life, Afrocalypse and the VooDoo Bear, and Doodle Grove. Information for these can be viewed on our website:

www.pettytortureproductions.com

But enough shameless self-promotion. This campaign has been created to raise funds for an exhibition booth at the local Indianapolis Comic Con and to have issues printed of the recently published issue #0.5 of the "Scratch" anime-styled comic for auctioning at the convention. This will be the first major local comic convention that Petty Torture Productions might attend, depending on you fine folks.

Give to Us, and We'll Give to You!

We're asking for the minimum amount of $500 because that's all we really need. The exhibition booths run about $350, and we can get a good amount of prints on the Scratch comic with the remaining funds.

If you view our perks below, you'll notice that there's quite a bit of signed and dated material to be owned. The higher perks even offer posters, photos of the staff drinking to your honor, and a personal video thank you from all of us here at Petty Torture Productions.

One lucky person will even be chosen at random to own a signed and dated googly-eyed squid hat! SQUID HAT!

In the event that we do not reach our entire goal, the funds will still be used toward Petty Torture Productions creations and adverts and whatnot. If we get close enough to the goal, it'll still be used for the exhibitor's booth and comic prints. Regardless of this possibility, all perks will be honored to those who donate the appropriated amounts listed in the perks below.

The Impact

If we reach our goal, you fine folks will have launched us well into the local scene. While we've done some international work for others, our own concepts are still quite hidden from the public. This will give us the opportunity to advertise our own ideas, as well as attract interested clients who need illustration work done.

If You Can't Contribute Money

You can still be awesome by advertising our work. If you like what we do, share our website with your friends and family. You never know who might need some crazy cartoons for their projects or businesses. Money is great, but advertising is its predecessor, and we hold quite dearly those who put us out in the world.

story:
Idiosyncrasy is a multifunctional art space located in Brooklyn, NY dedicated to bringing exposure to emerging artists.

 Upon moving to New York I was quickly amazed by the incredible amount of talent all around me.  It also didn't take long for me to discover that in a city full of want to be artists, designers, etc, most of us "trying to make it" creatives have at least two jobs: the one we do because we have to, typically the one that pays the rent, and then the one we do because we love it and because we can't seem to stop.  It's in this creative process and its culmination that many of us feel we find value.  It's such a shame every time I hear someone venting their frustrations about dedicating most of their energy to their job (whether it's working retail, waiting tables, bar tending, whatever) and having little left for the work they really care about.  In so many cases these are wonderfully talented individuals whose work, I know, would be well received if it could ever be seen or shown.  Therefore, I had the idea to create Idiosyncrasy.  A space that aims specifically to give emerging artists a chance to have their work seen in a quality venue. 

 

We're so close!

We have successfully completed over 50% of the Idiosyncrasy art space.  So far, we've built several small studio spaces and a study/library that we're filling with resources for creatives.  All of this being said, we still have more to do! The basement of Idiosyncrasy contains a 900+square foot room that we are converting into a gallery/ exhibition space. We've already begun lining up some incredibly talented artists to install their work for solo shows this upcoming spring.  With each show, Idiosycnrasy will host an opening with refreshments and music.  This will give the artist a chance to add to his artist's cv and showcase his talent.  Meanwhile, it will give the public an opportunity to view and purchase these works at an affordable price.    To complete the gallery space, we intend to do the following:

  • Build and paint 2 large wall spaces for exhibition. Estimated cost:$1,600.
  • Add bathroom for gallery guests.  Just a simple slop sink and toilet.  Estimated cost: $2,500.

 

If we are able to raise more funds than our goal (which we are really hoping for!!), we will do the following:

  • Redo the gallery floor (~900 sqft).  Nothing fancy, just something affordable and practical.
  • Add track lighting directed at the gallery exhibition walls. 
  • Add an 8 foot awning to mark the exterior gallery entrance. 
  • Purchase two projectors for the gallery.  These would be used for film screenings and video installations. 
  • Purchase a large format printer for Idiosyncrasy.  This would be used for advertising and marketing for the gallery.

 

What we can offer you:

We're really excited about the gifts we have for contributors! 

  • For a donation of $25+ you will receive a subscription to our Idiosyncrasy digital magazine which will arrive to you via email 3 times annually and will showcase the gallery's newest talent and works from recent exhibitions.  
  • For a donation of $100+ you will receive a limited edition print of work by artist, Nick Reynolds, for whom idiosyncrasy is named in memory of.  His beautiful works include whimsical, vibrant watercolor and ink on paper.  Sized 8in x10in.
  • For a donation of $500+ you will receive a limited edition print of work by artist, Nick Reynolds, for whom idiosyncrasy is named in memory of.  His beautiful works include whimsical, vibrant watercolor and ink on paper.  Sized 11 in x14 in and custom framed.  

 

Other ways you can help:

We understand not everyone can contribute financially, but here are some other ways you can help out!

  • Spread the word about the campaign.  Have any family or friends that you think would be interested in contributing?  Shoot them an email with a link to our indiegogo.  You can use IndiGoGo's "share" tools to do this!
  • Like us on facebook.  http://www.facebook.com/Idiosyncrasybiz
  • Check out idiosyncrasyBk.com  http://www.idiosyncrasyBk.com
